speaker: धृतराष्ट्र
sanskrit: धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः| मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय  || 1.1 ||
translation: Dhritarashtra said, "What did my people and the sons of Pandu do when they had assembled together, eager for battle, on the holy plain of Kurukshetra, O Sanjaya?"
question: How does the Gita start?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा| आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत्  || 1.2 ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Having seen the army of the Pandavas drawn up in battle array, King Duryodhana approached his teacher, Drona, and spoke these words.
question: In the Mahabharata war, whom did Duryodhana first talk to?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम्| व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता  || 1.3 ||
translation: Behold, O Teacher! This mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, thy wise disciple.
question: What did Duryodhana say to his teacher, Drona?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि| युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः  || 1.4 ||
translation: Here are heroes, mighty archers, equal in battle to Bhima and Arjuna, Yuyudhana (Satyaki), Virata, and Drupada—all mighty warriors.
question: Which warriors from the Pandava army did Duryodhana first talk about?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान्| पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः  || 1.5 ||
translation: Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, the valiant king of Kasi, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, and Saibya—the best of men.
question: Who was the king from Kashi who fought in the Mahabharata war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान्| सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः  ||  || 1.6 ||
translation: The strong Yudhamanyu and the brave Uttamaujas, the son of Subhadra (Abhimanyu, the son of Subhadra and Arjuna), and the sons of Draupadi, all of them great charioteers (great heroes)."
question: Which other warriors from the Pandava army did Duryodhana talk about?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम| नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते  || 1.7 ||
translation: Know also, O best among the twice-born! the names of those who are the most distinguished amongst ourselves, the leaders of my army; these I name to you for your information.
question: Why was Duryodhana taking names of all the warriors in the Mahabharata war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः| अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च  || 1.8 ||
translation: "Thou thyself, Bhishma, Karna, Kripa, the victorious in war, Asvatthama, Vikarna, and Bhurisrava, the son of Somadatta—all these are ready for battle."
question: Who were the warriors on the Kaurava side that Duryodhana mentioned about?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः| नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः  || 1.9 ||
translation: And also many other heroes, ready to give up their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons and missiles, all well-skilled in battle.
question: What did Duryodhana say about the warriors on his side in the Mahabharata war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम्| पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम्  || 1.10 ||
translation: Our army, marshalled by Bhishma, is insufficient, whereas theirs, marshalled by Bhima, is sufficient.
question: What did Duryodhana say while comparing his army with the Pandava army?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः| भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि  || 1.11 ||
translation: Therefore, do all of you, stationed in your respective positions in the several divisions of the army, protect Bhishma alone.
question: What did Duryodhana ask Drona to primarily do during the war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: तस्य संजनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः| सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान्  || 1.12 ||
translation: His glorious grandsire, the oldest of the Kauravas, roared like a lion to cheer Duryodhana and blew his conch.
question: What did Bhishma do to cheer up Duryodhana during the Mahabharata war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः| सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत्  || 1.13 ||
translation: Then, suddenly, conches, kettledrums, tabors, drums, and cow horns blared forth from the Kaurava side, and the sound was tremendous.
question: What happened after Bhishma blew his conch?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ| माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः  || 1.14 ||
translation: Then, Madhava (Krishna) and the son of Pandu (Arjuna), seated in the magnificent chariot yoked with white horses, blew divine conches.
question: Who was the first person from the Pandava side to blow the conch?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनंजयः| पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः  || 1.15 ||
translation: Hrishikesha blew the Panchajanya, Arjuna blew the Devadatta, and Bhima, the wolf-bellied doer of terrible deeds, blew the great conch Paundra.
question: What were the names of the conches of Krishna, Arjuna and Bhima?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः| नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ  || 1.16 ||
translation: King Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, blew the Anantavijaya; Nakula and Sahadeva blew the Sughosha and the Manipushpaka.
question: What were the names of the conches of Yudhisthira, Nakula and Sahadeva?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः| धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः  || 1.17 ||
translation: The king of Kasi, an excellent archer, Sikhandi, the mighty car-warrior, Dhrishtadyumna, Virata, and Satyaki, the unconquered.
question: Who else fought from the Pandava side?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते| सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक्  || 1.18 ||
translation: Drupada and the sons of Draupadi, O Lord of the Earth, and the son of Subhadra, the mighty-armed, blew their conches each separately.
question: Who else from the Pandava side blow their conch?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत्| नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन्  || 1.19 ||
translation: The tumultuous sound rent the hearts of Dhritarashtra's party, reverberating through both heaven and earth.
question: What was the reaction of Kauravas after the Pandava side blew their conches?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अथ व्यवस्थितान् दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान्कपिध्वजः| प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसंपाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः  || 1.20 ||
translation: Then, seeing the people of Dhritarashtra's party standing arrayed and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna, the son of Pandu whose ensign was a monkey, took up his bow and said the following to Krishna, O Lord of the Earth.
question: What was depicted on Arjuna's chariot flag?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते| सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत  || 1.21 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."
question: What did Arjuna first ask Krishna to do in the Mahabharata war?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान्| कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन्रणसमुद्यमे  || 1.22 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, place my chariot in the middle between the two armies, so that I may behold those who stand here, desirous to fight, and know with whom I must fight when the battle is about to commence."
question: Why did Arjuna want Krishna to draw his chariot between the two armies?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: योत्स्यमानानवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः| धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर्युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः  || 1.23 ||
translation: For I desire to observe those who are assembled here to fight, wishing to please in battle the evil-minded Duryodhana—the son of Dhritarashtra.
question: What did Arjuna want to observe at the beginning of the war?

speaker: संजय
sanskrit: एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत| सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम्  || 1.24 ||
translation: Sanjaya said, Thus addressed by Arjuna, Krishna stationed the best of chariots, O Dhritarashtra, in the midst of the two armies.
question: Where did Krishna place the chariot?

speaker: संजय
sanskrit: भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम्| उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान्समवेतान्कुरूनिति  || 1.25 ||
translation: In front of Bhishma and Drona, and all the rulers of the earth, he said: "O Arjuna, son of Pritha, behold these Kurus gathered together."
question: In front of whom did Krishna place the chariot?

speaker: संजय
sanskrit: तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान्पार्थः पितृ़नथ पितामहान्| आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातृ़न्पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा  || 1.26 ||
translation: Then, Arjuna (son of Pritha) saw there (in the armies) stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and friends.
question: Which relatives did Arjuna see on the other side in the war?

speaker: संजय
sanskrit: श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि| तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान्  || 1.27 ||
translation: He saw fathers-in-law and friends in both the armies. The son of Kunti, Arjuna, seeing all those kinsmen thus standing arrayed, spoke sorrowfully, deeply filled with pity.
question: Whom did Arjuna see when Krishna placed his chariot in the middle of the two armies?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कृपया परयाऽऽविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत्| दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम्  || 1.28 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, seeing my kinsmen arrayed here, eager to fight,
question: Seeing whom did Arjuna become emotional during the war?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति| वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते  || 1.29 ||
translation: My limbs fail, my mouth is parched, my body quivers, and my hair stands on end.
question: What happened to Arjuna's limbs when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते| न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः  || 1.30 ||
translation: The Gandiva slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over; I am unable to stand, and my mind is reeling, as it were.
question: What happened to Arjuna's bow when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव| न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे  || 1.31 ||
translation: And I see ill omens, O Kesava. I do not see any good in slaying my kinsmen in battle.
question: What was Arjuna's reaction when he saw so many relatives in the enemy's army?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च| किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा  || 1.32 ||
translation:
I desire not victory, O Krishna, nor kingdom, nor pleasures.
What use is dominion to us, O Krishna, or pleasures or even life?
question: Where in the Gita does Arjuna say that he has no desire for empire or victory?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च| त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणांस्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च  || 1.33 ||
translation: Those for whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and pleasures stand here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.
question: Why did Arjuna say that he has no desire for victory or the empire?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः| मातुलाः श्चशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा  || 1.34 ||
translation: Teachers, fathers, sons, and grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives—
question: What did Arjuna say about the way teachers and relatives are to be treated?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन| अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते  || 1.35 ||
translation: These I do not wish to kill, O Krishna, even though they kill me, for the sake of dominion over the three worlds; leave alone killing them for the sake of the earth."
question: Where in the Gita does Arjuna say that he will not kill his relatives even if they kill him?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन| पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान्हत्वैतानाततायिनः  || 1.36 ||
translation: By killing these sons of Dhritarashtra, what pleasure could be ours, O Janardana? Only sin would accrue to us from killing these felons.
question: What did Arjuna say will happen if he killed his own relatives?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान्स्वबान्धवान्| स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव  || 1.37 ||
translation: Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhritarashtra, our relatives; for how can we be happy by killing our own kin, O Madhava (Krishna)?
question: What according to Arjuna is the effect of killing our own kin?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः| कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम्  || 1.38 ||
translation: Though they, with intelligence overpowered by greed, see no evil in the destruction of families and no sin in hostility to friends,
question: What did Arjuna say about the nature of Kauravas?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम्| कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन  || 1.39 ||
translation: Why should we not, who clearly see the evil in the destruction of families, learn to turn away from this sin, O Janardana (Krishna)?
question: Why did Arjuna want to turn away from the battle?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः| धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत  || 1.40 ||
translation: In the destruction of a family, the immemorial religious rites of that family perish; on the destruction of spirituality, impiety indeed, overwhelms the whole family.
question: What did Arjuna say would happen to his family if he kills his own clan?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः| स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः  || 1.41 ||
translation: O Krishna, by the prevalence of impiety, the women of the family become corrupt; and, when women are corrupted, O Varshenya (descendant of Vrishni), intermingling of castes arises.
question: What did Arjuna say would happen to the women if he kills his own clan?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च| पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः  || 1.42 ||
translation: Confusion of castes leads to hell for the slayers of the family, for their forebears fall, deprived of the offerings of rice-balls and libations of water.
question: What leads to hell according to Arjuna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः| उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः  || 1.43 ||
translation: By these evil deeds of the destroyers of the family, which cause confusion of castes, the eternal religious rites of the caste and the family are destroyed.
question: What did Arjuna say would happen if there is inter mixing in the clans?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन| नरकेऽनियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम  || 1.44 ||
translation: We have heard, O Janardana, that those men in whose families the religious practices have been destroyed are inevitably destined to dwell in hell for an unknown period.
question: What did Arjuna say would happen to those whose clans are destroyed?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम्| यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः  || 1.45 ||
translation: Alas! We are involved in a great sin, for we are prepared to kill our kinsmen, out of greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.
question: Why did Arjuna say that he was about to commit a sin?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः| धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत्  || 1.46 ||
translation: If the sons of Dhritarashtra, with weapons in hand, should slay me in battle, unresisting and unarmed, that would be better for me.
question: Why did Arjuna want to be killed by the enemy Kauravas?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वाऽर्जुनः संख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत्| विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः  || 1.47 ||
translation: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken in the midst of the battlefield, Arjuna cast away his bow and arrow and, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow, sat down on the seat of the chariot.
question: What did Arjuna do after arguing that he will prefer being killed instead of killing his own relatives?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: तं तथा कृपयाऽविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम्| विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः || 2.1 ||
translation: Sanjaya said: To him, who was thus overcome with pity, despondent, with eyes full of tears and agitated, Madhusudana (the destroyer of Madhu) or Krishna spoke these words.
question: What did Sanjaya say about the state of Arjuna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम्| अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन || 2.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "From whence has this perilous strait come upon you, this dejection which is unworthy of you, disgraceful, and which will close the gates of heaven upon you, O Arjuna?"
question: What were Krishna's first words on seeing the weak state of Arjuna after he refused to fight the war?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते| क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप || 2.3 ||
translation: Do not yield to impotence, O Arjuna, son of Pritha. It does not befit you. Cast off this mean weakness of the heart! Stand up, O conqueror of foes!
question: What did Krishna say to encourage Arjuna to fight the war? How can I become strong?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कथं भीष्ममहं संख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन| इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन || 2.4 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Madhusudana, how can I fight in battle with arrows against Bhishma and Drona, who are worthy of being worshipped, O destroyer of enemies?"
question: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at Bhishma and Drona?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके|  हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् || 2.5 ||
translation: Better it is, indeed, in this world to accept alms than to slay the most noble teachers. But if I were to kill them, even in this world, all my enjoyments of wealth and fulfilled desires would be stained with their blood.
question: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at his teachers?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः| यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषाम स्तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः || 2.6 ||
translation: I can hardly tell which would be better, that we should conquer them or that they should conquer us. Even the sons of Dhritarashtra, whom we do not wish to slay, stand facing us.
question: Why was Arjuna reluctant to shoot arrows at Kauravas (sons of Dhrtarastra)?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभाव: पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेता: | यच्छ्रेय: स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम्  ||  2.7 ||
translation: My heart is overpowered by the taint of pity; my mind is confused as to my duty. I ask Thee: Tell me decisively what is good for me. I am Thy disciple; instruct me, who has taken refuge in Thee.
question: When did Arjuna first admis that he is confused?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्या द्यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम्| अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धम्रा ज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् || 2.8 ||
translation: I do not see that this sorrow that burns up my senses would be removed, even if I were to attain prosperous and unrivaled dominion on earth or lordship over the gods.
question: Why was Arjuna so grief stricken?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप| न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह || 2.9 ||
translation: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Hrishikesha, the Lord of the senses, Arjuna, the conqueror of sleep and destroyer of foes, said, "I will not fight," and became silent.
question: Where in the Gita did Arjuna say that he will not fight?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत| सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः || 2.10 ||
translation: To him who was despondent in the midst of the two armies, Krishna, smiling, O Bharata, spoke these words.
question: What was Krishna's first reaction on seeing the grief stricken state of Arjuna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे| गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः || 2.11 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "You have grieved for those who should not be grieved for; yet, you speak words of wisdom. The wise grieve neither for the living nor for the dead."
question: Is it suitable for wise people to grieve?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः| न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् || 2.12 ||
translation: Nor, at any time, was I not, nor thou, nor these rulers of men; nor, verily, shall we ever cease to be hereafter.
question: Do human beings cease to exist when they die?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा| तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति || 2.13 ||
translation: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, so too does it pass into another body; the steadfast one does not grieve over this.
question: What happens to the soul or Atman after death of the body? Does the soul transmigrate after death of the body? What is transmigration of the soul?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः| आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत || 2.14 ||
translation: The contact of the senses with the objects, O son of Kunti, which causes heat and cold, pleasure and pain, has a beginning and an end; they are impermanent; endure them bravely, O Arjuna.
question: How do various feelings of pleasure and pain arise?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ| समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते || 2.15 ||
translation: That firm man, whom surely these afflictions do not, O chief among men, to whom pleasure and pain are the same, is fit for attaining immortality.
question: What is the sign of a steadfast human? Where does Krishna talk about impermanence of pleasure and pain?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः| उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः || 2.16 ||
translation: The unreal has no being; there is no non-being of the real; the truth about both has been seen by the knowers of the truth (or the seers of the essence).
question: What is the real and unreal?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम्| विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित् कर्तुमर्हति ||  2.17 ||
translation: Know that to be indestructible, by which all this is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of that, the Imperishable.
question: Is there anything that immutable and indestructible in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः| अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत || 2.18 ||
translation: These bodies of the embodied Self, which are eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable, are said to have an end. Therefore, fight, O Arjuna.
question: Does the Jiva also die when the body dies?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम्| उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते || 2.19 ||
translation: He who takes the Self to be the slayer and he who thinks it is slain, neither of them knows. It does not slay, nor is it slain.
question: What is the sign of ignorance in a human?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचि न्नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः| अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे || 2.20 ||
translation: It is not born, nor does it ever die; after having been, it again does not cease to be; unborn, eternal, changeless, and ancient, it is not killed when the body is killed.
question: What are the properties of the soul or atman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम्| कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् || 2.21 ||
translation: Whoever knows it to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and inexhaustible, how can that person slay, O Arjuna, or cause to be slain?
question: Can a Jiva be killed by anyone? Can the soul be killed by anyone?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि| तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णा- न्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही || 2.22 ||
translation: Just as a man casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, so too the embodied Self casts off worn-out bodies and enters others that are new.
question: What happens to the soul after the body dies? What happens to the soul after death? What happens to the self after the body dies? What happens to the self after death?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः| न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः || 2.23 ||
translation: Weapons cannot cut it, fire cannot burn it, water cannot wet it, wind cannot dry it.
question: Can the soul or self or atman be burnt or destroyed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च| नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः || 2.24 ||
translation: This Self cannot be cut, burned, wetted, nor dried up; it is eternal, all-pervasive, stable, immovable, and ancient.
question: Can the soul be dried up?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते| तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि || 2.25 ||
translation: This Self is said to be unmanifested, unthinkable, and unchangeable. Therefore, knowing this to be so, you should not grieve.
question: Is grieving suitable for those who know the Self or soul or atman? What are the characteristics of the Self? What is the soul? What is the Self? What are the characteristics of the soul? Who am I? What is atma? What is the atma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम्| तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैवं शोचितुमर्हसि || 2.26 ||
translation: But even if thou thinkest of It as constantly being born and constantly dying, even then, O mighty-armed one, thou shouldst not grieve.
question: Is grieving suitable for even those who do not believe in an eternal soul or self or atman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च| तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि || 2.27 ||
translation: For the born, death is certain, and for the dead, birth is certain; therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.
question: Why is grieving unsuitable even for those who do not believe in an eternal soul or self? Can you explain the cycle of birth and death?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत| अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना ||  2.28 ||
translation: Beings are unmanifest in their beginning, manifest in their middle state, O Arjuna, and unmanifest again in their end. What is there to grieve about?
question: Do beings have a definite beginning and end?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेन माश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः| आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः श्रृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् || 2.29 ||
translation: One sees this (the Self) as a wonder; another speaks of it as a wonder; another hears of it as a wonder; yet, having heard, none understands it at all.
question: What is so wonderful about the soul or the self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत| तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि || 2.30 ||
translation: This indweller in the body of everyone is ever indestructible, O Arjuna; therefore, you should not grieve for any creature.
question: Are all the selves eternal and indestructible?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि| धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाछ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते || 2.31 ||
translation: Further, having regard to your duty, you should not waver, for there is nothing higher for a Kshatriya than a righteous war.
question: What is the greatest duty of a Kshatriya warrior?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम्| सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् || 2.32 ||
translation: Happy are the Kshatriyas, O Arjuna! who are called to fight in such a battle that comes of its own accord as an open door to heaven.
question: What leads a Kshatriya warrior to heaven?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अथ चैत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं संग्रामं न करिष्यसि| ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि || 2.33 ||
translation: But if you will not fight this righteous war, then having abandoned your own duty and reputation, you will incur sin.
question: What happens to Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम्| संभावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते || 2.34 ||
translation: People will also recount your everlasting dishonor; and for one who has been honored, dishonor is worse than death.
question: What do people treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः| येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् || 2.35 ||
translation: The great chariot-warriors will think that you have withdrawn from the battle out of fear, and you will be held in low esteem by those who have held you in high regard.
question: What do other warriors treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून् वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः| निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम् || 2.36 ||
translation: Your enemies, scoffing at your power, will speak many abusive words—what could be more painful than this?
question: What do the enemies treat Kshatriya warriors who turn away from their duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम्| तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः || 2.37 ||
translation: Slain, you will obtain heaven; victorious, you will enjoy the earth; therefore, stand up, O son of Kunti, resolved to fight.
question: What would have happened if Arjuna lost the Mahabharata war?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ| ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि || 2.38 ||
translation: Having made pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat equal, engage in battle for the sake of battle; thus, you shall not incur sin.
question: How can Arjuna make sure that he does not incur any sin by fighting the war?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एषा तेऽभिहिता सांख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां श्रृणु| बुद्ध्यायुक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि || 2.39 ||
translation: This, which has been taught to you, is wisdom concerning Sankhya. Now listen to wisdom concerning Yoga, endowed with which, O Arjuna, you shall cast off the bonds of action.
question: Where does Krishna start telling about Karma Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते| स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् || 2.40 ||
translation: In this, there is no loss of effort, nor is there any harm produced, nor any transgression. Even a little of this knowledge protects one from great fear.
question: Does the practice of Karma Yoga protect from evil? How to get rid of fear?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन| बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् || 2.41 ||
translation: Here, O joy of the Kurus, there is only one single-pointed determination; many-branched and endless are the thoughts of the indecisive.
question: How is the nature of the mind and intellect of a Karma Yogi?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः| वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः || 2.42 ||
translation: The unwise, taking pleasure in the eulogizing words of the Vedas, utter flowery speech, saying, "There is nothing else," O Arjuna.
question: What happens to people who are engrossed in the rituals of the Vedas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम्| क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति || 2.43 ||
translation: Full of desires, with heaven as their goal, (they speak words that are directed to ends) leading to new births as the result of their works, and prescribe various methods abounding in specific actions, for the attainment of pleasure and power.
question: What is wrong with people who are engrossed in the rituals of the Vedas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम्| व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते || 2.44 ||
translation: For those who are attached to pleasure and power, whose minds are drawn away by such teachings, their determinate reason is not formed which is steadily bent on meditation and Samadhi (superconscious state).
question: What is the greatest limitation of people whose minds cling to pleasure and power?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन| निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् || 2.45 ||
translation: The Vedas deal with the three attributes; be thou above these three attributes. O Arjuna, free yourself from the pairs of opposites and ever remain in the quality of Sattva, freed from acquisition and preservation, and be established in the Self.
question: What are the characteristics of a person who is free from the three Gunas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः संप्लुतोदके| तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः || 2.46 ||
translation: To the Brahmana who has known the Self, all the Vedas are of as much use as a reservoir of water would be in a place where there is a flood.
question: Are the Vedas useful for a person with knowledge of the Self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन| मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि || 2.47 ||
translation: Your right is only to work, but not to its results; do not let the results of action be your motive, nor let your attachment be to inaction.
question: What is the crux of Karma Yoga? What is Karma? What is Karma Yoga? How should we work? What is the secret of work? What is the secret of Karma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय| सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते || 2.48 ||
translation: Perform action, O Arjuna, being steadfast in Yoga, abandoning attachment and balanced in success and failure; evenness of mind is called Yoga.
question: What is evenness of mind or equanimity? What is the importance of equanimity?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय| बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः || 2.49 ||
translation: Far lower than the Yoga of wisdom is action, O Arjuna. Seek thou refuge in wisdom; wretched are those whose motive is the fruit.
question: How should action or karma be performed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते| तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् || 2.50 ||
translation: Endowed with wisdom and evenness of mind, one casts off in this life both good and evil deeds; therefore, devote yourself to Yoga; Yoga is skill in action.
question: What is the definition of Yoga? What is Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः| जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् || 2.51 ||
translation: The wise, possessing knowledge, having abandoned the fruits of their actions, and being freed from the bonds of birth, go to the place which is beyond all evil.
question: What happens to those who possess evenness of mind and are equanimous?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति| तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च || 2.52 ||
translation: When your intellect passes beyond the mire of delusion, then you will attain indifference to what has been heard and what has yet to be heard.
question: What happens to those who have gone beyond the tangle of delusion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला| समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि || 2.53 ||
translation: When your intellect, which is perplexed by the Vedic texts you have read, stands immovable and steady in the Self, then you will attain Self-realization.
question: What happens to those whose whose intellect has been enlightened?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव| स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् || 2.54 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, what is the description of one who has steady wisdom and is merged in the superconscious state? How does one of steady wisdom speak, how do they sit, and how do they walk?"
question: What was Arjuna's first question after hearing about Karma Yoga and the state of equanimity?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रजहाति यदा कामान् सर्वान् पार्थ मनोगतान्| आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते || 2.55 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "When a man completely casts off, O Arjuna, all the desires of the mind and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is said to be one of steady wisdom."
question: Who is said to possess firm wisdom? Who is considered to be a sthitaprajna? Who is considered to be equanimous?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः| वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते || 2.56 ||
translation: He whose mind is not shaken by adversity, who does not long for pleasures, and is free from attachment, fear, and anger, is called a sage of steady wisdom.
question: What is the state of a person whose mind is not perturbed by pain?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम्| नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.57 ||
translation: He who is everywhere without attachment, upon encountering anything good or bad, neither rejoices nor hastens; his wisdom is firm.
question: What is the state of a person who is unbiased?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.58 ||
translation: When, like the tortoise which withdraws all its limbs on all sides, he withdraws his senses from the sense-objects, then his wisdom becomes steady.
question: When is a person's wisdom said to be firmly established?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः| रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते || 2.59 ||
translation: The objects of the senses turn away from the abstinent man, leaving the longing behind; but his longing also turns away upon seeing the Supreme.
question: What happens to the senses when the Self becomes known?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः| इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः || 2.60 ||
translation: The turbulent senses, O Arjuna, can violently carry away the mind of a wise person, even though they are striving to control them.
question: How powerful are the senses?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः| वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.61 ||
translation: Having restrained them all, he should sit steadfast, intent on Me; his wisdom is steady whose senses are under control.
question: Why do we need to control the senses?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते| सङ्गात् संजायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते || 2.62 ||
translation: When one thinks of objects, attachment to them arises; from attachment, desire is born; from desire, anger arises.
question: What happens when we think about sense objects? What is wrong with attachment? Why is detachment necessary for spiritual progress? What is the effect of work with attachment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: क्रोधाद्भवति संमोहः संमोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः| स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति || 2.63 ||
translation: Anger leads to delusion, which causes loss of memory; this, in turn, leads to the destruction of discrimination, resulting in destruction.
question: What happens when we get angry? Why do we make wrong decisions when we are angry?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन्| आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति || 2.64 ||
translation: But the self-controlled man, moving among objects with the senses restrained and free from attraction and repulsion, attains peace.
question: What happens to those who have control over their sense objects? How can we get over anger? How can we become serene?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते| प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते || 2.65 ||
translation: In that peace, all pains are destroyed; for the intellect of the tranquil-minded soon becomes steady.
question: How is the state of a serene person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना| न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् || 2.66 ||
translation: There is no knowledge of the Self for the unsteady, and no meditation is possible for the unsteady, and no peace for the unmeditative, and how can there be happiness for one who has no peace?
question: Why is the importance of contemplation of the Self or soul?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनुविधीयते| तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि || 2.67 ||
translation: For the mind, which follows in the wake of the wandering senses, carries away his discrimination, as the wind carries away a boat on the waters.
question: What happens to the mind when it follows the senses?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता || 2.68 ||
translation: Therefore, O mighty-armed Arjuna, his knowledge is steady whose senses are completely restrained from sense objects.
question: What happens to the one whose senses are restrained?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी| यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः || 2.69 ||
translation: That which is night to all beings, in that the self-controlled man is awake; when all beings are awake, that is night for the sage who sees.
question: What is the difference between discerning sages and others?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत्| तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी || 2.70 ||
translation: He attains peace into whom all desires enter, just as waters enter the ocean which, filled from all sides, remains unmoved; but not the man who is full of desires.
question: Where is the analogy with an undisturbed sea mentioned in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः| निर्ममो निरहंकारः स शांतिमधिगच्छति || 2.71 ||
translation: That person attains peace who, abandoning all desires, moves about without longing, without the sense of ownership, and without egoism.
question: How can we attain peace?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति| स्थित्वाऽस्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति || 2.72 ||
translation: O son of Pritha, this is the eternal state, the Brahmic seat. Attaining this, one is not deluded. Being established in it, one attains oneness with Brahman even at the end of life.
question: What is the Brahmic state?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit:
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन|
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव || 3.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said: If Thou thinkest that knowledge is superior to action, O Krishna, why then, O Kesava, doest Thou ask me to engage in this terrible action?
question: What was Arjuna's confusion about knowledge and action?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे| तदेकं वद निश्िचत्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् || 3.2 ||
translation: With this seemingly perplexing speech, you seem to be confusing my understanding; therefore, tell me one certain way by which I may attain bliss.
question: What was Arjuna's confusion on hearing about the Yoga of knowledge and the Yoga of action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ| ज्ञानयोगेन सांख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् || 3.3 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "In this world, there is a twofold path, as I said before, O sinless one: the path of knowledge of the Sankhyas and the path of action of the Yogins."
question: Is there any mention of Sankhya Yoga in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते| न च संन्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति || 3.4 ||
translation: Man does not reach actionlessness by not performing actions; nor does he attain perfection by mere renunciation.
question: Does renunciation of work lead to liberation or salvation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न हि कश्िचत्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत्| कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः || 3.5 ||
translation: Verily, no one can remain for even a moment without performing action; for everyone is made to act helplessly, indeed, by the qualities born of Nature.
question: Can any person avoid doing action or work even for a moment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन्| इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते || 3.6 ||
translation: He who, restraining the organs of action, sits thinking of the sense-objects in his mind, he of deluded understanding is called a hypocrite.
question: Who is a deluded person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन| कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते || 3.7 ||
translation: But whoever, controlling the senses by the mind, O Arjuna, engages himself in Karma Yoga with the organs of action, without attachment, he excels.
question: Who is an excellent person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः| शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः || 3.8 ||
translation: Perform your bounden duty, for action is superior to inaction, and even the maintenance of the body would not be possible for you through inaction.
question: Is action superior to inaction? Why is it important to perform one's duties?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः| तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसंगः समाचर || 3.9 ||
translation: The world is bound by actions other than those performed for the sake of sacrifice; do thou, therefore, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), perform actions for that sake alone, free from attachment.
question: When does work or action lead to bondage?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः| अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् || 3.10 ||
translation: The Creator, having in the beginning created mankind together with sacrifice, said, "By this shall you propagate; let this be the milch cow of your desires—the cow that yields all the desired objects."
question: Why should we propagate our species?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः| परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ || 3.11 ||
translation: With this, nourish the gods, and may the gods nourish you; thus, nourishing each other, you shall attain the highest good.
question: What is the duty of ordinary human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः| तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः || 3.12 ||
translation: The gods, nourished by the sacrifice, will give you the desired objects. So, he who enjoys the objects given by the gods without offering anything in return is indeed a thief.
question: Who is a thief?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः| भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मकारणात् || 3.13 ||
translation: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all sins; but those sinful ones who cook food solely for their own sake indeed consume sin.
question: How can pious people remain free from sin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः| यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः || 3.14 ||
translation: From food come forth beings; from rain, food is produced; from sacrifice arises rain, and sacrifice is born of action.
question: What is the importance of food?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम्| तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् || 3.15 ||
translation: Know that action comes from Brahma, and Brahma comes from the Imperishable. Therefore, the all-pervasive Brahma ever rests in sacrifice.
question: Where does activity or action spring from?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः| अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति || 3.16 ||
translation: He who does not follow the wheel thus set in motion, who is of sinful life, rejoicing in the senses, lives in vain, O Arjuna.
question: Why is it important to follow the laws of nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः| आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते || 3.17 ||
translation: But for that man who rejoices only in the Self, who is satisfied with the Self and is content in the Self alone, indeed there is nothing to do.
question: Do people who are satisfied with the Self also need to perform all the worldly duties?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन| न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्िचदर्थव्यपाश्रयः || 3.18 ||
translation: For him, there is no interest whatsoever in what is done or not done; nor does he depend on any being for any purpose.
question: Is there any motivation left for people who are satisfied with the Self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर| असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः || 3.19 ||
translation: Therefore, without attachment, always perform the actions that should be done; for by performing actions without attachment, one reaches the Supreme.
question: Why is detachment important? What is the result of detachment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः| लोकसंग्रहमेवापि संपश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि || 3.20 ||
translation: Janaka and others attained perfection indeed through action alone; even with the intention of protecting the masses, you should perform action.
question: How did King Janaka reach perfection or salvation or liberation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः| स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते || 3.21 ||
translation: Whatever a great man does, others also do; whatever he establishes as the standard, the world follows.
question: What impact do great men have on others?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन| नानवाप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि || 3.22 ||
translation: There is nothing in the three worlds, O Arjuna, that needs to be done by Me, nor is there anything unattained that needs to be attained; yet I engage Myself in action.
question: Is God also bound by any duties towards the world?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः| मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 3.23 ||
translation: For, should I not ever engage myself in action, unwearied, people would in every way follow my path, O Arjuna.
question: Why does God continue to perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम्| सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः || 3.24 ||
translation: These worlds would perish if I did not perform action; I would be the author of confusion of castes and destruction of these beings.
question: What will happen if God ceases to perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत| कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्िचकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम् || 3.25 ||
translation: As the ignorant act out of attachment to action, O Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, wishing for the welfare of the world.
question: What should be the motivation for the wise men to work?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम्| जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन् || 3.26 ||
translation: Let no wise man unsettle the minds of ignorant people who are attached to action; he should engage them in all actions, himself fulfilling them with devotion.
question: How should wise men treat other human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः| अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते || 3.27 ||
translation: All actions are wrought in all cases by the qualities of Nature alone. He whose mind is deluded by egoism thinks, "I am the doer."
question: Is action performed by the individual or by nature itself?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः| गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते || 3.28 ||
translation: But he who knows the Truth, O mighty-armed Arjuna, about the divisions of the qualities and their functions, knowing that the Gunas, as senses, move amidst the Gunas, as the sense-objects, is not attached.
question: How does the knowledge of the Gunas lead to detachment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु| तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् || 3.29 ||
translation: Those deluded by the qualities of Nature are attached to the functions of the qualities. The man of perfect knowledge should not unsettle the foolish one who is of imperfect knowledge.
question: How should the ignorant be treated?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि संन्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा| निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः || 3.30 ||
translation: Renouncing all actions in Me, with the mind centered on the Self, free from hope and egoism, and from mental fever, fight thou.
question: Where does Krishna first talk about the concept of surrender?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः| श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः || 3.31 ||
translation: Those who constantly practice this teaching of Mine with faith and without caviling, they too are freed from actions.
question: Where does Krishna first talk about the concept of faith?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम्| सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः || 3.32 ||
translation: But those who criticize My teaching and do not practice it, deprived of all knowledge and lacking discernment, know them to be doomed to destruction.
question: What happens to those who do not follow the principle of Karma Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि| प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति || 3.33 ||
translation: Even a wise man acts in accordance with his own nature; beings will follow their nature; what can restraint do?
question: Should innate desires be repressed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ| तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ || 3.34 ||
translation: Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses abide in the senses; let no one come under their sway; for, they are his enemies.
question: How should one treat his or her own senses?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्| स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः || 3.35 ||
translation: Better is one's own duty, though devoid of merit, than the duty of another well discharged. Better is death in one's own duty; the duty of another is fraught with fear.
question: Why is important to perform one's own duty? How can we become successful? How can we achieve success?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः| अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः || 3.36 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "But what compels man to commit sin, even against his wishes, O Varshneya (Krishna), as if constrained by force?"
question: What did Arjuna ask about sin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः| महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् || 3.37 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "It is desire and it is anger, both of the quality of Rajas, all-devouring and all-sinful; know this as the foe here in this world."
question: What is the primary cause of sin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथाऽऽदर्शो मलेन च| यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम् || 3.38 ||
translation: As fire is enveloped by smoke, as a mirror is covered by dust, and as an embryo is surrounded by the amniotic sac, so is this enveloped by that.
question: What is desire? What is the cause of ignorance? Is there any relation between desires and ignorance?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा| कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च || 3.39 ||
translation: O Arjuna, wisdom is enveloped by this constant enemy of the wise, in the form of desire, which is insatiable like fire.
question: Can desires be gratified? Why are desires so hard to satisfy?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते| एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम् || 3.40 ||
translation: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be its seat; through these, it deludes the embodied one, veiling their wisdom.
question: How does desire overpowers the Self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ| पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् || 3.41 ||
translation: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, control your senses first and then kill this sinful thing, which destroys knowledge and realization.
question: Why is it important to control the desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः| मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः || 3.42 ||
translation: They say that the senses are superior to the body; the mind is superior to the senses; the intellect is superior to the mind; and He (the Self) is superior even to the intellect.
question: Which is greater, the Self or the intellect?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना| जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् || 3.43 ||
translation: Thus, knowing Him who is superior to the intellect and restraining the self by the Self, slay thou, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the enemy in the form of desire, hard to conquer.
question: How can one control the desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इमं विवस्वते योगं प्रोक्तवानहमव्ययम्| विवस्वान् मनवे प्राह मनुरिक्ष्वाकवेऽब्रवीत् || 4.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "I taught this imperishable Yoga to Vivasvan; he then told it to Manu; Manu proclaimed it to Ikshvaku.
question: Whom did Krishna first teach Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं परम्पराप्राप्तमिमं राजर्षयो विदुः| स कालेनेह महता योगो नष्टः परन्तप || 4.2 ||
translation: This, handed down in regular succession by the royal sages, was known. This Yoga, however, has been lost here over time, O Parantapa (burner of the foes).
question: How did the knowledge of Yoga get lost?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स एवायं मया तेऽद्य योगः प्रोक्तः पुरातनः| भक्तोऽसि मे सखा चेति रहस्यं ह्येतदुत्तमम् || 4.3 ||
translation: That same ancient yoga has been today taught to you by me, for you are my devotee and my friend; it is the supreme secret.
question: Why was Krishna teaching Yoga to Arjuna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अपरं भवतो जन्म परं जन्म विवस्वतः| कथमेतद्विजानीयां त्वमादौ प्रोक्तवानिति || 4.4 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "Later was Thy birth, and prior to it was the birth of Vivasvan (the Sun); how am I to understand that Thou hast taught this Yoga from the beginning?"
question: What was Arjuna's reaction on hearing that Krishna taught Yoga to Vivasvan and other ancestors?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बहूनि मे व्यतीतानि जन्मानि तव चार्जुन| तान्यहं वेद सर्वाणि न त्वं वेत्थ परन्तप || 4.5 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Many births of Mine have passed, as well as of thine, O Arjuna; I know them all, but thou knowest not, O Parantapa (scorcher of foes)."
question: Does God also have multiple births?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अजोऽपि सन्नव्ययात्मा भूतानामीश्वरोऽपि सन्| प्रकृतिं स्वामधिष्ठाय संभवाम्यात्ममायया || 4.6 ||
translation: Though I am unborn and of imperishable nature, and though I am the Lord of all beings, yet, governing my own nature, I am born by my own Maya.
question: What is the concept of Avatar or reincarnation? Can God take birth in a human form? Is it possible for God to be born on this earth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा यदा हि धर्मस्य ग्लानिर्भवति भारत| अभ्युत्थानमधर्मस्य तदाऽऽत्मानं सृजाम्यहम् || 4.7 ||
translation: Whenever there is a decline of righteousness and an increase of unrighteousness, O Arjuna, then I manifest Myself.
question: When and why does God incarnate? Will Sanatana Dharma be eradicated some day? Can Hinduism be eradicated?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: परित्राणाय साधूनां विनाशाय च दुष्कृताम्| धर्मसंस्थापनार्थाय संभवामि युगे युगे || 4.8 ||
translation: For the protection of the good, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of righteousness, I am born in every age.
question: Why does God incarnate? Does God do anything to protect good people? Can good people expect any help from God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: जन्म कर्म च मे दिव्यमेवं यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः| त्यक्त्वा देहं पुनर्जन्म नैति मामेति सोऽर्जुन || 4.9 ||
translation: He who thus knows, in their true light, My divine birth and actions, having abandoned the body, is not born again; he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
question: What happens to those who know about God's incarnations or Avatars?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वीतरागभयक्रोधा मन्मया मामुपाश्रिताः| बहवो ज्ञानतपसा पूता मद्भावमागताः || 4.10 ||
translation: Freed from attachment, fear, and anger, absorbed in Me, taking refuge in Me, purified by the fire of knowledge, many have attained My Being.
question: Have people actually attained liberation or salvation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये यथा मां प्रपद्यन्ते तांस्तथैव भजाम्यहम्| मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः || 4.11 ||
translation: In whatever way men approach Me, even so do I reward them; My path do men tread in all ways, O Arjuna.
question: Is there a single path to attain God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: काङ्क्षन्तः कर्मणां सिद्धिं यजन्त इह देवताः| क्षिप्रं हि मानुषे लोके सिद्धिर्भवति कर्मजा || 4.12 ||
translation: Those who long for success in action in this world sacrifice to the gods; for success is quickly attained by men through action.
question: What happens to those who perform rituals?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: चातुर्वर्ण्यं मया सृष्टं गुणकर्मविभागशः| तस्य कर्तारमपि मां विद्ध्यकर्तारमव्ययम् || 4.13 ||
translation: The fourfold caste has been created by Me according to the differentiation of Guna and Karma; though I am the author of it, know Me as non-doer and immutable.
question: What is the concept of varna or caste?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न मां कर्माणि लिम्पन्ति न मे कर्मफले स्पृहा| इति मां योऽभिजानाति कर्मभिर्न स बध्यते || 4.14 ||
translation: Actions do not taint Me, nor do I have a desire for the fruit of actions. He who knows Me thus is not bound by actions.
question: Does God also get bound by his actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं ज्ञात्वा कृतं कर्म पूर्वैरपि मुमुक्षुभिः| कुरु कर्मैव तस्मात्त्वं पूर्वैः पूर्वतरं कृतम् || 4.15 ||
translation: Having known this, the ancient seekers of freedom also performed action; therefore, do thou also perform action, as the ancients did in days of yore.
question: Did spiritual seekers of ancient times abstain from work or action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: किं कर्म किमकर्मेति कवयोऽप्यत्र मोहिताः| तत्ते कर्म प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 4.16 ||
translation: What is action? What is inaction? Even the wise are confused about this. Therefore, I shall teach you the nature of action and inaction, by knowing which you will be liberated from the evil of Samsara, the wheel of birth and death.
question: Is it easy to understand the difference between action and inaction?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मणो ह्यपि बोद्धव्यं बोद्धव्यं च विकर्मणः| अकर्मणश्च बोद्धव्यं गहना कर्मणो गतिः || 4.17 ||
translation: For verily, the true nature of action enjoined by the scriptures should be known, as well as that of forbidden or unlawful action, and of inaction; the nature of action is hard to understand.
question: Why is the way of action so mysterious?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मण्यकर्म यः पश्येदकर्मणि च कर्म यः| स बुद्धिमान् मनुष्येषु स युक्तः कृत्स्नकर्मकृत् || 4.18 ||
translation: He who sees inaction in action and action in inaction, he is wise among men; he is a yogi and performer of all actions.
question: What is the relation between action and inaction?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्य सर्वे समारम्भाः कामसङ्कल्पवर्जिताः| ज्ञानाग्निदग्धकर्माणं तमाहुः पण्डितं बुधाः || 4.19 ||
translation: He whose undertakings are all devoid of desires and selfish purposes, and whose actions have been burned by the fire of knowledge, the wise call him a sage.
question: Who is a sage or pandit?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्यक्त्वा कर्मफलासङ्गं नित्यतृप्तो निराश्रयः| कर्मण्यभिप्रवृत्तोऽपि नैव किञ्चित्करोति सः || 4.20 ||
translation: Having abandoned attachment to the fruits of the action, ever content, depending on nothing, he does not do anything even while being engaged in activity.
question: What is the secret of inaction in action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: निराशीर्यतचित्तात्मा त्यक्तसर्वपरिग्रहः| शारीरं केवलं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् || 4.21 ||
translation: Without hope, controlling the mind and the self, having abandoned all covetousness, and performing only bodily actions, one incurs no sin.
question: How do sages stay away from evil?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदृच्छालाभसन्तुष्टो द्वन्द्वातीतो विमत्सरः| समः सिद्धावसिद्धौ च कृत्वापि न निबध्यते || 4.22 ||
translation: Content with what comes to him without effort, free from the pairs of opposites and envy, even-minded in success and failure, he acts yet is not bound.
question: How do sages remain free from bondage?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: गतसङ्गस्य मुक्तस्य ज्ञानावस्थितचेतसः| यज्ञायाचरतः कर्म समग्रं प्रविलीयते || 4.23 ||
translation: To one who is devoid of attachment, who is liberated, whose mind is established in knowledge, and who works for the sake of sacrifice (for the sake of God), the whole action is dissolved.
question: How do sages dissolve their Karma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्रह्मार्पणं ब्रह्महविर्ब्रह्माग्नौ ब्रह्मणा हुतम्| ब्रह्मैव तेन गन्तव्यं ब्रह्मकर्मसमाधिना || 4.24 ||
translation: Brahman is the oblation; Brahman is the melted butter (ghee); by Brahman is the oblation poured into the fire of Brahman; Brahman indeed shall be attained by one who always sees Brahman in action.
question: What is the concept of Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दैवमेवापरे यज्ञं योगिनः पर्युपासते| ब्रह्माग्नावपरे यज्ञं यज्ञेनैवोपजुह्वति || 4.25 ||
translation: Some yogis perform sacrifice to the gods alone; while others, who have realized the Self, offer the Self as sacrifice in the fire of Brahman alone.
question: What are the different kinds of sacrifices that Yogis perform?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रोत्रादीनीन्द्रियाण्यन्ये संयमाग्निषु जुह्वति| शब्दादीन्विषयानन्य इन्द्रियाग्निषु जुह्वति || 4.26 ||
translation: Some again offer the organ of hearing and other senses as a sacrifice in the fire of restraint; others offer sound and other objects of the senses as a sacrifice in the fire of the senses.
question: What are the different kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वाणीन्द्रियकर्माणि प्राणकर्माणि चापरे| आत्मसंयमयोगाग्नौ जुह्वति ज्ञानदीपिते || 4.27 ||
translation: Others again sacrifice all the functions of the senses and those of the breath (vital energy, or Prana) in the fire of the Yoga of self-restraint, kindled by knowledge.
question: What are the kinds of oblations that Yogis perform?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्रव्ययज्ञास्तपोयज्ञा योगयज्ञास्तथापरे| स्वाध्यायज्ञानयज्ञाश्च यतयः संशितव्रताः || 4.28 ||
translation: Others again offer wealth, austerity, and Yoga as sacrifice, while ascetics of self-restraint and rigid vows offer the study of scriptures and knowledge as sacrifice.
question: What are the kinds of sacrifices that Yogis perform?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अपाने जुह्वति प्राण प्राणेऽपानं तथाऽपरे| प्राणापानगती रुद्ध्वा प्राणायामपरायणाः || 4.29 ||
translation: Others offer as sacrifice the outgoing breath into the incoming, and the incoming into the outgoing, restraining the flow of the outgoing and the incoming breaths, solely absorbed in the restraint of the breath.
question: How do Yogis perform various austerities?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अपरे नियताहाराः प्राणान्प्राणेषु जुह्वति| सर्वेऽप्येते यज्ञविदो यज्ञक्षपितकल्मषाः || 4.30 ||
translation: Others who regulate their diet offer life-breaths in each life-breath. All these are knowers of sacrifice, whose sins are destroyed through sacrifice.
question: What happens to those who subsist on sacrificial food?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञशिष्टामृतभुजो यान्ति ब्रह्म सनातनम्| नायं लोकोऽस्त्ययज्ञस्य कुतो़ऽन्यः कुरुसत्तम || 4.31 ||
translation: Those who eat the remnants of the sacrifice, which are like nectar, go to the eternal Brahman. This world is not for the one who does not perform sacrifice; how then can they have the other, O Arjuna?
question: What happens to those who do not perform any sactifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एवं बहुविधा यज्ञा वितता ब्रह्मणो मुखे| कर्मजान्विद्धि तान्सर्वानेवं ज्ञात्वा विमोक्ष्यसे || 4.32 ||
translation: Thus, manifold sacrifices are spread out before Brahman at the face of Brahman. Know them all to be born of action, and thus knowing, you shall be liberated.
question: Is there only one correct way of performing sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रेयान्द्रव्यमयाद्यज्ञाज्ज्ञानयज्ञः परन्तप| सर्वं कर्माखिलं पार्थ ज्ञाने परिसमाप्यते || 4.33 ||
translation: Superior is wisdom-sacrifice to the sacrifice with objects, O Parantapa (scorcher of the foes). All actions in their entirety, O Arjuna, culminate in knowledge.
question: Which is the highest sacrifice?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तद्विद्धि प्रणिपातेन परिप्रश्नेन सेवया| उपदेक्ष्यन्ति ते ज्ञानं ज्ञानिनस्तत्त्वदर्शिनः || 4.34 ||
translation: Know that the wise who have realized the truth will instruct thee in that knowledge through long prostration, supplication, and service.
question: How is the sacrifice of knowledge performed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ज्ञात्वा न पुनर्मोहमेवं यास्यसि पाण्डव| येन भूतान्यशेषेण द्रक्ष्यस्यात्मन्यथो मयि || 4.35 ||
translation: Knowing that thou shalt not, O Arjuna, again be deluded like this; and by that thou shalt see all beings in thyself and also in me.
question: What happens to those who know how to perform the sacrifice of knowledge?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अपि चेदसि पापेभ्यः सर्वेभ्यः पापकृत्तमः| सर्वं ज्ञानप्लवेनैव वृजिनं सन्तरिष्यसि || 4.36 ||
translation: Even if thou art the most sinful of all sinners, yet thou shalt surely cross over all sins by the raft of knowledge.
question: How can sinners attain liberation or salvation? Is there any hope for sinners?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यथैधांसि समिद्धोऽग्निर्भस्मसात्कुरुतेऽर्जुन| ज्ञानाग्निः सर्वकर्माणि भस्मसात्कुरुते तथा || 4.37 ||
translation: As the blazing fire reduces fuel to ashes, O Arjuna, so does the fire of knowledge reduce all actions to ash.
question: What does knowledge do to Karma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न हि ज्ञानेन सदृशं पवित्रमिह विद्यते| तत्स्वयं योगसंसिद्धः कालेनात्मनि विन्दति || 4.38 ||
translation: Verily, there is no purifier in this world like knowledge. He who is perfected in Yoga finds it within the Self in due time.
question: Which is the best or highest purifier?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रद्धावाँल्लभते ज्ञानं तत्परः संयतेन्द्रियः| ज्ञानं लब्ध्वा परां शान्तिमचिरेणाधिगच्छति || 4.39 ||
translation: The one who is full of faith, devoted to it, and has subdued their senses obtains this knowledge; and upon obtaining the knowledge, they attain the supreme peace immediately.
question: What happens to those who have faith?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अज्ञश्चाश्रद्दधानश्च संशयात्मा विनश्यति| नायं लोकोऽस्ति न परो न सुखं संशयात्मनः || 4.40 ||
translation: The ignorant, the faithless, and the doubting self go to destruction; there is neither this world nor the other, nor happiness for the doubting one.
question: What happens to those who do not have faith?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगसंन्यस्तकर्माणं ज्ञानसंछिन्नसंशयम्| आत्मवन्तं न कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय || 4.41 ||
translation: He who has renounced actions through Yoga, whose doubts have been dispelled by knowledge, and who is self-possessed—such a one is not bound by actions, O Arjuna.
question: What happens to those who practice Karma Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मादज्ञानसंभूतं हृत्स्थं ज्ञानासिनाऽऽत्मनः| छित्त्वैनं संशयं योगमातिष्ठोत्तिष्ठ भारत || 4.42 ||
translation: Therefore, with the sword of knowledge (of the Self), cut asunder the doubt of the self, born of ignorance, residing in your heart, and take refuge in Yoga. Arise, O Arjuna!
question: How to get rid of doubts about the Self?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: संन्यासं कर्मणां कृष्ण पुनर्योगं च शंससि| यच्छ्रेय एतयोरेकं तन्मे ब्रूहि सुनिश्िचतम् || 5.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, you praise renunciation of actions and also yoga. Please tell me conclusively which is better of the two."
question: What did Arjuna ask after knowing in detail about the path of knowledge and the path of action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: संन्यासः कर्मयोगश्च निःश्रेयसकरावुभौ| तयोस्तु कर्मसंन्यासात्कर्मयोगो विशिष्यते || 5.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Renunciation and the Yoga of action both lead to the highest bliss; but of the two, the Yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action."
question: Is Karma Yoga better than renunciation of actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञेयः स नित्यसंन्यासी यो न द्वेष्टि न काङ्क्षति| निर्द्वन्द्वो हि महाबाहो सुखं बन्धात्प्रमुच्यते || 5.3 ||
translation: He should be known as a perpetual Sannyasi who neither hates nor desires; for, free from the pairs of opposites, O mighty-armed Arjuna, he is easily freed from bondage.
question: How can one be free from bondage?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सांख्ययोगौ पृथग्बालाः प्रवदन्ति न पण्डिताः| एकमप्यास्थितः सम्यगुभयोर्विन्दते फलम् || 5.4 ||
translation: Children, not the wise, speak of knowledge and the Yoga of action, or the performance of action, as though they are distinct and different; he who is truly established in one, obtains the fruits of both.
question: Is Sankhya Yoga different from Karma Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्सांख्यैः प्राप्यते स्थानं तद्योगैरपि गम्यते| एकं सांख्यं च योगं च यः पश्यति स पश्यति || 5.5 ||
translation: That place which is reached by the Sankhyas or the Jnanis is also reached by the Yogis (Karma Yogis). He who sees knowledge and the performance of action (Karma Yoga) as one, sees truly.
question: Do the Sankhya Yogis reach the same state as the Karma Yogis?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: संन्यासस्तु महाबाहो दुःखमाप्तुमयोगतः| योगयुक्तो मुनिर्ब्रह्म नचिरेणाधिगच्छति || 5.6 ||
translation: But, O mighty-armed Arjuna, renunciation is hard to attain without Yoga; the sage who is in harmony with Yoga quickly goes to Brahman.
question: Why is renunciation so hard?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगयुक्तो विशुद्धात्मा विजितात्मा जितेन्द्रियः| सर्वभूतात्मभूतात्मा कुर्वन्नपि न लिप्यते || 5.7 ||
translation: He who is devoted to the path of action, whose mind is pure, who has conquered the self, who has subdued his senses, and who realizes his Self as the Self in all beings, though acting, is not tainted.
question: How can one remain untainted and detached while performing action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नैव किंचित्करोमीति युक्तो मन्येत तत्त्ववित्| पश्यन् श्रृणवन्स्पृशञ्जिघ्रन्नश्नन्गच्छन्स्वपन् श्वसन् || 5.8 ||
translation: "I do nothing at all," thus would the harmonized knower of Truth think, seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, eating, going, sleeping, and breathing.
question: How should one perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रलपन्विसृजन्गृह्णन्नुन्मिषन्निमिषन्नपि| इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेषु वर्तन्त इति धारयन् || 5.9 ||
translation: Speaking, letting go, seizing, opening, and closing the eyes, one should be convinced that the senses move among the sense-objects.
question: Can the senses perceive the mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्रह्मण्याधाय कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा करोति यः| लिप्यते न स पापेन पद्मपत्रमिवाम्भसा || 5.10 ||
translation: He who does actions, offering them to Brahman and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus leaf is not tainted by water.
question: What happens to those who act without attachment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कायेन मनसा बुद्ध्या केवलैरिन्द्रियैरपि| योगिनः कर्म कुर्वन्ति सङ्गं त्यक्त्वाऽऽत्मशुद्धये || 5.11 ||
translation: Yogis, having abandoned attachment, perform actions only through the body, mind, intellect, and even the senses, for the purification of the self.
question: Why do Yogis perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: युक्तः कर्मफलं त्यक्त्वा शान्तिमाप्नोति नैष्ठिकीम्| अयुक्तः कामकारेण फले सक्तो निबध्यते || 5.12 ||
translation: The one who is united (the well-poised or harmonized) having abandoned the fruit of action attains eternal peace; whereas the one who is not united (the unsteady or unbalanced), impelled by desire and attached to the fruit, is bound.
question: What is the difference between a Yogi and an ordinary person? What happens to a Yogi who has renounced all fruits of his actions? What happens to a detached Yogi? What happens to a person who is unable to give up attachment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वकर्माणि मनसा संन्यस्यास्ते सुखं वशी| नवद्वारे पुरे देही नैव कुर्वन्न कारयन् || 5.13 ||
translation: Mentally renouncing all actions and being self-controlled, the embodied one happily rests in the nine-gated city, neither acting nor causing others (body and senses) to act.
question: What kind of attitude should one have towards work and duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न कर्तृत्वं न कर्माणि लोकस्य सृजति प्रभुः| न कर्मफलसंयोगं स्वभावस्तु प्रवर्तते || 5.14 ||
translation: Neither does the Lord create agency nor actions for the world, nor union with the fruits of actions; rather, it is Nature that acts.
question: Does the Self create actions and their fruits or results?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नादत्ते कस्यचित्पापं न चैव सुकृतं विभुः| अज्ञानेनावृतं ज्ञानं तेन मुह्यन्ति जन्तवः || 5.15 ||
translation: The Lord takes neither the demerit nor the merit of any; knowledge is enveloped by ignorance, and beings are deluded.
question: Does God keep track of a person's sins and merits?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानेन तु तदज्ञानं येषां नाशितमात्मनः| तेषामादित्यवज्ज्ञानं प्रकाशयति तत्परम् || 5.16 ||
translation: But to those whose ignorance is destroyed by knowledge of the Self, like the sun, knowledge reveals the Supreme Brahman.
question: How can ignorance be destroyed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तद्बुद्धयस्तदात्मानस्तन्निष्ठास्तत्परायणाः| गच्छन्त्यपुनरावृत्तिं ज्ञाननिर्धूतकल्मषाः || 5.17 ||
translation: Their intellect absorbed in That, their self being That, established in That, with That as their supreme goal, they go whence there is no return, their sins dispelled by knowledge.
question: How can impurities be removed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विद्याविनयसंपन्ने ब्राह्मणे गवि हस्तिनि| शुनि चैव श्वपाके च पण्डिताः समदर्शिनः || 5.18 ||
translation: Sages look with an equal eye on a Brahmana endowed with learning and humility, on a cow, an elephant, a dog, and even an outcaste.
question: How do sages look upon saints and sinners?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इहैव तैर्जितः सर्गो येषां साम्ये स्थितं मनः| निर्दोषं हि समं ब्रह्म तस्माद्ब्रह्मणि ते स्थिताः || 5.19 ||
translation: Even here in this world, those whose minds rest in reality overcome birth; Brahman is indeed spotless and real; therefore they are established in Brahman.
question: How do equanimous people see the world?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न प्रहृष्येत्प्रियं प्राप्य नोद्विजेत्प्राप्य चाप्रियम्| स्थिरबुद्धिरसम्मूढो ब्रह्मविद्ब्रह्मणि स्थितः || 5.20 ||
translation: Resting in Brahman, with a steady intellect and undeluded, the knower of Brahman neither rejoices upon obtaining what is pleasant nor grieves upon obtaining what is unpleasant.
question: How do equanimous people react towards pleasure and pain?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बाह्यस्पर्शेष्वसक्तात्मा विन्दत्यात्मनि यत्सुखम्| स ब्रह्मयोगयुक्तात्मा सुखमक्षयमश्नुते || 5.21 ||
translation: With the self unattached to external contacts, he finds happiness in the Self; with the self engaged in the meditation of Brahman, he attains endless happiness.
question: How can one enjoy endless happiness?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये हि संस्पर्शजा भोगा दुःखयोनय एव ते| आद्यन्तवन्तः कौन्तेय न तेषु रमते बुधः || 5.22 ||
translation: The enjoyments that arise from contact are only sources of pain, for they have a beginning and an end, O Arjuna; the wise do not rejoice in them.
question: Why is it necessary to be detached from pleasure?

speaker: भगवान
