sanskrit: शक्नोतीहैव यः सोढुं प्राक्शरीरविमोक्षणात्| कामक्रोधोद्भवं वेगं स युक्तः स सुखी नरः || 5.23 ||
translation: He who is able, while still here in this world, to withstand the impulse born out of desire and anger before the liberation from the body, he is a Yogi, and he is a happy man.
question: Who is a Yogi? Who is happy? What beings happiness? What brings joy?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योऽन्तःसुखोऽन्तरारामस्तथान्तर्ज्योतिरेव यः| स योगी ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं ब्रह्मभूतोऽधिगच्छति || 5.24 ||
translation: He who is happy within, who rejoices within, and who is illuminated within, that Yogi attains absolute freedom, or Moksha, becoming Brahman himself.
question: Who attains Moksha? Who attains absolute freedom?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: लभन्ते ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृषयः क्षीणकल्मषाः| छिन्नद्वैधा यतात्मानः सर्वभूतहिते रताः || 5.25 ||
translation: The sages obtain absolute freedom or Moksha when their sins have been destroyed, their dualities have been torn asunder, they are self-controlled, and they are intent on the welfare of all beings.
question: Who attains the bliss of Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कामक्रोधवियुक्तानां यतीनां यतचेतसाम्| अभितो ब्रह्मनिर्वाणं वर्तते विदितात्मनाम् || 5.26 ||
translation: Absolute freedom exists on all sides for those self-controlled ascetics who are free from desire and anger, who have controlled their thoughts, and who have realized the Self.
question: Who achieves absolute freedom?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स्पर्शान्कृत्वा बहिर्बाह्यांश्चक्षुश्चैवान्तरे भ्रुवोः| प्राणापानौ समौ कृत्वा नासाभ्यन्तरचारिणौ || 5.27 ||
translation: Shutting out all external contacts and fixing the gaze between the eyebrows, realizing the outgoing and incoming breaths moving within the nostrils.
question: How should one meditate?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यतेन्द्रियमनोबुद्धिर्मुनिर्मोक्षपरायणः| विगतेच्छाभयक्रोधो यः सदा मुक्त एव सः || 5.28 ||
translation: With the senses, mind, and intellect ever controlled, having liberation as their supreme goal, free from desire, fear, and anger, the sage is truly liberated forever.
question: How does a sage become eternally free?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भोक्तारं यज्ञतपसां सर्वलोकमहेश्वरम्| सुहृदं सर्वभूतानां ज्ञात्वा मां शान्तिमृच्छति || 5.29 ||
translation: He who knows Me as the enjoyer of sacrifices and austerities, the great Lord of all the worlds, and the friend of all beings, attains peace.
question: How do the sages view God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनाश्रितः कर्मफलं कार्यं कर्म करोति यः| स संन्यासी च योगी च न निरग्निर्न चाक्रियः || 6.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: He who performs his bounden duty without depending on the fruits of his actions—he is a sannyasi and a yogi, not he who is without fire and without action.
question: Who is a sannyasin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यं संन्यासमिति प्राहुर्योगं तं विद्धि पाण्डव| न ह्यसंन्यस्तसङ्कल्पो योगी भवति कश्चन || 6.2 ||
translation: Do you, O Arjuna, know that Yoga is what they call renunciation; no one indeed becomes a Yogi who has not renounced their thoughts.
question: what is the difference between the path of knowledge and Karma Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आरुरुक्षोर्मुनेर्योगं कर्म कारणमुच्यते| योगारूढस्य तस्यैव शमः कारणमुच्यते || 6.3 ||
translation: For a sage who wishes to attain to Yoga, action is said to be the means; for the same sage who has attained Yoga, inaction is said to be the means.
question: for how long should a yogi continue to perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा हि नेन्द्रियार्थेषु न कर्मस्वनुषज्जते| सर्वसङ्कल्पसंन्यासी योगारूढस्तदोच्यते || 6.4 ||
translation: When a person is not attached to the sense-objects or to actions, having renounced all thoughts, then they are said to have attained Yoga.
question: when is a person said to be established in Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उद्धरेदात्मनाऽऽत्मानं नात्मानमवसादयेत्| आत्मैव ह्यात्मनो बन्धुरात्मैव रिपुरात्मनः || 6.5 ||
translation: One should raise oneself by one's own self alone; let not one lower oneself; for the self alone is one's own friend, and the self alone is one's own enemy.
question: Can our self be our enemy? Can I be my own enemy? Who is our enemy?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बन्धुरात्माऽऽत्मनस्तस्य येनात्मैवात्मना जितः| अनात्मनस्तु शत्रुत्वे वर्तेतात्मैव शत्रुवत् || 6.6 ||
translation: The Self is the friend of the self of him by whom the Self has been conquered; but to the unconquered self, this Self stands in the position of an enemy, like an external foe.
question: who is our friend and who is our enemy?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: जितात्मनः प्रशान्तस्य परमात्मा समाहितः| शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु तथा मानापमानयोः || 6.7 ||
translation: The Supreme Self of him who is self-controlled and peaceful remains balanced in cold and heat, pleasure and pain, as well as in honor and dishonor.
question: what are the traits of a person with self control?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानविज्ञानतृप्तात्मा कूटस्थो विजितेन्द्रियः| युक्त इत्युच्यते योगी समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः || 6.8 ||
translation: The Yogi who is satisfied with the knowledge and wisdom of the Self, who has conquered the senses, and to whom a clod of earth, a piece of stone, and gold are all the same, is said to have attained Nirvikalpa Samadhi.
question: who is a real saint?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सुहृन्मित्रार्युदासीनमध्यस्थद्वेष्यबन्धुषु| साधुष्वपि च पापेषु समबुद्धिर्विशिष्यते || 6.9 ||
translation: He who is of the same mind towards the good-hearted, friends, enemies, the indifferent, the neutral, the hateful, the relatives, the righteous, and the unrighteous, excels.
question: how should we treat our enemies and haters?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगी युञ्जीत सततमात्मानं रहसि स्थितः| एकाकी यतचित्तात्मा निराशीरपरिग्रहः || 6.10 ||
translation: Let the yogi constantly strive to keep the mind steady, remaining in solitude, alone, with the body and mind controlled, and free from hope and greed.
question: how can a yogi control his mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शुचौ देशे प्रतिष्ठाप्य स्थिरमासनमात्मनः| नात्युच्छ्रितं नातिनीचं चैलाजिनकुशोत्तरम् || 6.11 ||
translation: In a clean spot, having established a firm seat of his own, neither too high nor too low, made of cloth, skin, and kusha grass layered one over the other.
question: how should we sit for meditation? While meditating should we sit on the floor or on a chair or on the bed? Can I meditate while sitting in a chair? Can I meditate while sleeping in my bed? Can I meditate while sitting on my bed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्रैकाग्रं मनः कृत्वा यतचित्तेन्द्रियक्रियः| उपविश्यासने युञ्ज्याद्योगमात्मविशुद्धये || 6.12 ||
translation: There, having made the mind one-pointed, with the actions of the mind and senses controlled, let him, seated on the seat, practice Yoga for the purification of the self.
question: what is the best way to meditate?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: समं कायशिरोग्रीवं धारयन्नचलं स्थिरः| संप्रेक्ष्य नासिकाग्रं स्वं दिशश्चानवलोकयन् || 6.13 ||
translation: Let him firmly hold his body, head, and neck erect and still, gazing at the tip of his nose without looking around.
question: how should we hold our body during meditation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रशान्तात्मा विगतभीर्ब्रह्मचारिव्रते स्थितः| मनः संयम्य मच्चित्तो युक्त आसीत मत्परः || 6.14 ||
translation: Serene-minded, fearless, firm in the vow of a Brahmachari, having controlled their mind, thinking of Me and balanced in mind, let them sit, having Me as their supreme goal.
question: what should we think during meditation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदाऽऽत्मानं योगी नियतमानसः| शान्तिं निर्वाणपरमां मत्संस्थामधिगच्छति || 6.15 ||
translation: Thus, always keeping the mind balanced, the yogi, with the mind controlled, attains the peace abiding in Me, culminating in liberation.
question: What is the benefit of meditation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नात्यश्नतस्तु योगोऽस्ति न चैकान्तमनश्नतः| न चातिस्वप्नशीलस्य जाग्रतो नैव चार्जुन || 6.16 ||
translation: Verily, Yoga is not possible for him who eats too much, nor for him who does not eat at all, nor for him who sleeps too much, nor for him who is always awake, O Arjuna.
question: how long should we sleep daily? What is the importance of moderation? Is it good to fast for a long time?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: युक्ताहारविहारस्य युक्तचेष्टस्य कर्मसु| युक्तस्वप्नावबोधस्य योगो भवति दुःखहा || 6.17 ||
translation: Yoga becomes the destroyer of pain for him who is moderate in eating and recreation (such as walking, etc.), who exercises moderation in action, and who is moderate in sleep and wakefulness.
question: is it good to be a workaholic? Is overeating a bad idea?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा विनियतं चित्तमात्मन्येवावतिष्ठते| निःस्पृहः सर्वकामेभ्यो युक्त इत्युच्यते तदा || 6.18 ||
translation: When the perfectly controlled mind rests in the Self alone, free from longing for any of the objects of desire, then it is said, 'He is united'.
question: who is truly spiritual?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यथा दीपो निवातस्थो नेङ्गते सोपमा स्मृता| योगिनो यतचित्तस्य युञ्जतो योगमात्मनः || 6.19 ||
translation: As a lamp placed in a windless spot does not flicker, so is the Yogi of a controlled mind, who practices Yoga in the Self, compared.
question: what is a simple analogy for the mind of a yogi? Where in the Gita is the analogy of a lamp in the wind? What are the attributes of a meditative mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्रोपरमते चित्तं निरुद्धं योगसेवया| यत्र चैवात्मनाऽऽत्मानं पश्यन्नात्मनि तुष्यति || 6.20 ||
translation: When the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, attains quietude, and when one sees the Self by the Self, they are satisfied in their own Self.
question: what happens when the mind is controlled by the practice of Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सुखमात्यन्तिकं यत्तद्बुद्धिग्राह्यमतीन्द्रियम्| वेत्ति यत्र न चैवायं स्थितश्चलति तत्त्वतः || 6.21 ||
translation: When he (the Yogi) feels that infinite bliss which can be grasped by the pure intellect and which transcends the senses, and is established therein, never moving away from the reality.
question: what is absolute happiness?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यं लब्ध्वा चापरं लाभं मन्यते नाधिकं ततः| यस्मिन्स्थितो न दुःखेन गुरुणापि विचाल्यते || 6.22 ||
translation: Having obtained it, he thinks there is no other gain superior to it; established in it, he is not moved even by heavy sorrow.
question: do Yogis also have desires? How can we handle sorrow? How can we handle grief?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तं विद्याद् दुःखसंयोगवियोगं योगसंज्ञितम्| स निश्चयेन योक्तव्यो योगोऽनिर्विण्णचेतसा || 6.23 ||
translation: Let this be known by the name of Yoga, the severance from union with pain. This Yoga should be practiced with determination and with an undespairing mind.
question: how can we get rid of sorrow and pain? How can we get rid of misery?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सङ्कल्पप्रभवान्कामांस्त्यक्त्वा सर्वानशेषतः| मनसैवेन्द्रियग्रामं विनियम्य समन्ततः || 6.24 ||
translation: Abandoning unreservedly all desires born of Sankalpa (thought and imagination) and completely restraining the whole group of senses by the mind from all sides.
question: How should we handle our desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शनैः शनैरुपरमेद् बुद्ध्या धृतिगृहीतया| आत्मसंस्थं मनः कृत्वा न किञ्चिदपि चिन्तयेत् || 6.25 ||
translation: Little by little, let him attain steadiness of the intellect by holding it firmly; having made the mind establish itself in the Self, let him not think of anything else.
question: how can we withdraw the senses from the objects?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यतो यतो निश्चरति मनश्चञ्चलमस्थिरम्| ततस्ततो नियम्यैतदात्मन्येव वशं नयेत् || 6.26 ||
translation: From whatever cause the restless and unsteady mind wanders away, let him restrain it from that and bring it under the control of the Self alone.
question: How can I control my unsteady and fickle mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रशान्तमनसं ह्येनं योगिनं सुखमुत्तमम्| उपैति शान्तरजसं ब्रह्मभूतमकल्मषम् || 6.27 ||
translation: Supreme Bliss indeed comes to this Yogi whose mind is made peaceful, whose passion is quelled, who has become Brahman, and who is free from sin.
question: Is it possible to become free from evil?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: युञ्जन्नेवं सदाऽऽत्मानं योगी विगतकल्मषः| सुखेन ब्रह्मसंस्पर्शमत्यन्तं सुखमश्नुते || 6.28 ||
translation: The yogi, always engaging the mind thus (in the practice of yoga), is freed from sins and easily enjoys the infinite bliss of contact with Brahman (the Eternal).
question: What happens when the mind becomes free from impurities?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थमात्मानं सर्वभूतानि चात्मनि| ईक्षते योगयुक्तात्मा सर्वत्र समदर्शनः || 6.29 ||
translation: With the mind harmonized by Yoga, he sees the Self abiding in all beings and all beings in the Self; he sees the same everywhere.
question: How can we experience the same Self in all beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यो मां पश्यति सर्वत्र सर्वं च मयि पश्यति| तस्याहं न प्रणश्यामि स च मे न प्रणश्यति || 6.30 ||
translation: He who sees Me everywhere and sees everything in Me, never becomes separated from Me, nor do I from him.
question: Where can we find God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वभूतस्थितं यो मां भजत्येकत्वमास्थितः| सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि स योगी मयि वर्तते || 6.31 ||
translation: He who, being established in unity, worships Me, who dwells in all beings, that yogi abides in Me, whatever their mode of living may be.
question: Do all Yogis live in the same way?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आत्मौपम्येन सर्वत्र समं पश्यति योऽर्जुन| सुखं वा यदि वा दुःखं सः योगी परमो मतः || 6.32 ||
translation: He who, through the likeness of the Self, O Arjuna, sees reality everywhere, be it pleasure or pain, is regarded as the highest Yogi.
question: Who is the highest Yogi?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: योऽयं योगस्त्वया प्रोक्तः साम्येन मधुसूदन| एतस्याहं न पश्यामि चञ्चलत्वात् स्थितिं स्थिराम् || 6.33 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O Krishna, I do not see how this Yoga of equanimity, which you have taught me, can be maintained steadily, due to the restlessness of the mind."
question: Was Arjuna convinced that the fickle mind can be controlled?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: चञ्चलं हि मनः कृष्ण प्रमाथि बलवद्दृढम्| तस्याहं निग्रहं मन्ये वायोरिव सुदुष्करम् || 6.34 ||
translation: The mind is indeed restless, turbulent, strong, and unyielding, O Krishna; I consider it as difficult to control as controlling the wind.
question: Why did Arjuna think that controlling the mind is very difficult?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असंशयं महाबाहो मनो दुर्निग्रहं चलं| अभ्यासेन तु कौन्तेय वैराग्येण च गृह्यते || 6.35 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed Arjuna, the mind is difficult to control and restless; but with practice and dispassion, it can be restrained."
question: What are the primary ingredients required to control the mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असंयतात्मना योगो दुष्प्राप इति मे मतिः| वश्यात्मना तु यतता शक्योऽवाप्तुमुपायतः || 6.36 ||
translation: I think Yoga is hard to be attained by one with an uncontrolled self, but the self-controlled and striving one can attain it by the appropriate means.
question: What kind of person can attain Yoga?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अयतिः श्रद्धयोपेतो योगाच्चलितमानसः| अप्राप्य योगसंसिद्धिं कां गतिं कृष्ण गच्छति || 6.37 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "He who is unable to control himself, even though he has faith, and whose mind wanders away from Yoga, what end does he meet, having failed to attain perfection in Yoga, O Krishna?"
question: What did Arjuna ask about those who are unable to control themselves?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कच्चिन्नोभयविभ्रष्टश्छिन्नाभ्रमिव नश्यति| अप्रतिष्ठो महाबाहो विमूढो ब्रह्मणः पथि || 6.38 ||
translation: Fallen from both, does he not perish like a rent cloud, supportless, O mighty-armed one, deluded on the path of Brahman?
question: What did Arjuna ask about those who fail to attain perfection in Yoga?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: एतन्मे संशयं कृष्ण छेत्तुमर्हस्यशेषतः| त्वदन्यः संशयस्यास्य छेत्ता न ह्युपपद्यते || 6.39 ||
translation: O Krishna, please completely dispel this doubt of mine, for it is not possible for anyone but You to do so.
question: Did Arjuna have full faith in Krishna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पार्थ नैवेह नामुत्र विनाशस्तस्य विद्यते| नहि कल्याणकृत्कश्िचद्दुर्गतिं तात गच्छति || 6.40 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, neither in this world nor in the next will there be destruction for him; none, indeed, who does good, O my son, ever comes to grief."
question: Do those who fail to attain perfection in Yoga end up suffering like others?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्राप्य पुण्यकृतां लोकानुषित्वा शाश्वतीः समाः| शुचीनां श्रीमतां गेहे योगभ्रष्टोऽभिजायते || 6.41 ||
translation: Having attained to the worlds of the righteous and having dwelt there for everlasting years, he who fell from Yoga is born in a house of the pure and wealthy.
question: How can we attain birth in a pure family?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अथवा योगिनामेव कुले भवति धीमताम्| एतद्धि दुर्लभतरं लोके जन्म यदीदृशम् || 6.42 ||
translation: Or he is born in a family of even the wisest of yogis; verily, such a birth is very difficult to obtain in this world.
question: What happens to those who fail to attain perfection in Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्र तं बुद्धिसंयोगं लभते पौर्वदेहिकम्| यतते च ततो भूयः संसिद्धौ कुरुनन्दन || 6.43 ||
translation: Then he comes into contact with the knowledge acquired in his former body and strives even more for perfection, O Arjuna.
question: Does the good effects of our Yoga practice get carried forward to next birth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पूर्वाभ्यासेन तेनैव ह्रियते ह्यवशोऽपि सः| जिज्ञासुरपि योगस्य शब्दब्रह्मातिवर्तते || 6.44 ||
translation: By that same former practice, he is borne on in spite of himself. Even he who merely wishes to know Yoga goes beyond the Brahmanic word.
question: Does our practice of Yoga in this life get carried forward to the next life?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रयत्नाद्यतमानस्तु योगी संशुद्धकिल्बिषः| अनेकजन्मसंसिद्धस्ततो याति परां गतिम् || 6.45 ||
translation: But the Yogi who strives assiduously, purified of sins and perfected gradually over many births, reaches the highest goal.
question: Is it possible to attain the state of Yoga in just one human birth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तपस्विभ्योऽधिको योगी ज्ञानिभ्योऽपि मतोऽधिकः| कर्मिभ्यश्चाधिको योगी तस्माद्योगी भवार्जुन || 6.46 ||
translation: The yogi is thought to be superior to the ascetics, even superior to those who have knowledge obtained through the study of scriptures; he is also superior to men of action; therefore, be thou a yogi, O Arjuna.
question: Are Yogis higher than the ritualists?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: योगिनामपि सर्वेषां मद्गतेनान्तरात्मना| श्रद्धावान्भजते यो मां स मे युक्ततमो मतः || 6.47 ||
translation: And among all the Yogis, he who, full of faith and with his inner self merged in Me, worships Me is deemed by Me to be the most devoted.
question: Who is the best Yogi?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मय्यासक्तमनाः पार्थ योगं युञ्जन्मदाश्रयः| असंशयं समग्रं मां यथा ज्ञास्यसि तच्छृणु || 7.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, hear how you shall, without doubt, know Me fully, with your mind intent on Me, practicing Yoga and taking refuge in Me."
question: Did Arjuna get to hear the full knowledge of Yoga in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानं तेऽहं सविज्ञानमिदं वक्ष्याम्यशेषतः| यज्ज्ञात्वा नेह भूयोऽन्यज्ज्ञातव्यमवशिष्यते || 7.2 ||
translation: I will declare to you in full this knowledge combined with realization, after knowing which nothing else remains to be known here.
question: Did Krishna reveal the full knowledge of Yoga in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मनुष्याणां सहस्रेषु कश्िचद्यतति सिद्धये| यततामपि सिद्धानां कश्िचन्मां वेत्ति तत्त्वतः || 7.3 ||
translation: Among thousands of men, one may perchance strive for perfection; even among those successful strivers, only one may perchance know Me in essence.
question: Is it easy to know the truth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भूमिरापोऽनलो वायुः खं मनो बुद्धिरेव च| अहङ्कार इतीयं मे भिन्ना प्रकृतिरष्टधा || 7.4 ||
translation: Earth, water, fire, air, ether, mind, intellect, and egoism—thus is My Nature divided eightfold.
question: How many parts does Prakriti have? What is Prakriti? What are the constituents of Prakriti? What is Prakriti composed of?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अपरेयमितस्त्वन्यां प्रकृतिं विद्धि मे पराम्| जीवभूतां महाबाहो ययेदं धार्यते जगत् || 7.5 ||
translation: O mighty-armed Arjuna, this is the inferior Prakriti; know it as distinct from My higher Prakriti, the very life-element, by which this world is upheld.
question: Is there something beyond or deeper than the physical world we see around us?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एतद्योनीनि भूतानि सर्वाणीत्युपधारय| अहं कृत्स्नस्य जगतः प्रभवः प्रलयस्तथा || 7.6 ||
translation: Know that these two are the womb of all beings; thus, I am the source and dissolution of the whole universe.
question: What is the source of birth of all beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मत्तः परतरं नान्यत्किञ्चिदस्ति धनञ्जय| मयि सर्वमिदं प्रोतं सूत्रे मणिगणा इव || 7.7 ||
translation: There is nothing higher than Me, O Arjuna. All this is strung on Me, like clusters of gems on a string.
question: Is there anything higher than God in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रसोऽहमप्सु कौन्तेय प्रभास्मि शशिसूर्ययोः| प्रणवः सर्ववेदेषु शब्दः खे पौरुषं नृषु || 7.8 ||
translation: I am the flavor in water, O Arjuna; I am the light in the moon and the sun; I am the syllable Om in all the Vedas, sound in the ether and virility in men.
question: What is Om? What is AUM?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पुण्यो गन्धः पृथिव्यां च तेजश्चास्मि विभावसौ| जीवनं सर्वभूतेषु तपश्चास्मि तपस्विषु || 7.9 ||
translation: I am the sweet fragrance in the earth and the brilliance in the fire, the life in all beings, and I am the austerity of ascetics.
question: What can God be compared with in the physical world?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बीजं मां सर्वभूतानां विद्धि पार्थ सनातनम्| बुद्धिर्बुद्धिमतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम् || 7.10 ||
translation: Know Me, O Arjuna, as the eternal seed of all beings; I am the intelligence of the intelligent, and the splendour of the splendid objects.
question: What is intelligence?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बलं बलवतां चाहं कामरागविवर्जितम्| धर्माविरुद्धो भूतेषु कामोऽस्मि भरतर्षभ || 7.11 ||
translation: Of the strong, I am the strength devoid of desire and attachment, and in all beings, I am the desire in accordance with Dharma, O Arjuna.
question: Can we compare God with desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये चैव सात्त्विका भावा राजसास्तामसाश्च ये| मत्त एवेति तान्विद्धि नत्वहं तेषु ते मयि || 7.12 ||
translation: Whatever beings (and objects) that are pure, active, and inert, know that they proceed from Me. They are in Me, yet I am not in them.
question: What are the three states of physical matter or Prakriti?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्रिभिर्गुणमयैर्भावैरेभिः सर्वमिदं जगत्| मोहितं नाभिजानाति मामेभ्यः परमव्ययम् || 7.13 ||
translation: Deluded by these Natures, composed of the three qualities of Nature, all this world does not know Me as distinct from them and immutable.
question: Why is it so difficult to know God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दैवी ह्येषा गुणमयी मम माया दुरत्यया| मामेव ये प्रपद्यन्ते मायामेतां तरन्ति ते || 7.14 ||
translation: Verily, this divine illusion of Mine, composed of the three qualities, is difficult to cross over; those who take refuge in Me alone, can cross over this illusion.
question: How can we overcome the delusion caused by Maya?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न मां दुष्कृतिनो मूढाः प्रपद्यन्ते नराधमाः| माययापहृतज्ञाना आसुरं भावमाश्रिताः || 7.15 ||
translation: The evil-doers and the deluded, who are the lowest of men, do not seek Me; those whose knowledge is destroyed by illusion follow the ways of demons.
question: What is a sign of ignorance in human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: चतुर्विधा भजन्ते मां जनाः सुकृतिनोऽर्जुन| आर्तो जिज्ञासुरर्थार्थी ज्ञानी च भरतर्षभ || 7.16 ||
translation: Four kinds of virtuous men worship Me, O Arjuna, and they are the distressed, the seekers of knowledge, the seekers of wealth, and the wise, O Lord of the Bharatas.
question: What kind of people worship God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तेषां ज्ञानी नित्ययुक्त एकभक्ितर्विशिष्यते| प्रियो हि ज्ञानिनोऽत्यर्थमहं स च मम प्रियः || 7.17 ||
translation: Of them, the wise who are ever steadfast and devoted to the One, excel; for I am exceedingly dear to the wise, and they are dear to Me.
question: Who is dearest to God? Are the wise dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उदाराः सर्व एवैते ज्ञानी त्वात्मैव मे मतम्| आस्थितः स हि युक्तात्मा मामेवानुत्तमां गतिम् || 7.18 ||
translation: Indeed, all these are noble; however, I consider the wise man as My very Self; for, he is steadfast in mind and established in Me alone as the supreme goal.
question: Who is closest to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बहूनां जन्मनामन्ते ज्ञानवान्मां प्रपद्यते| वासुदेवः सर्वमिति स महात्मा सुदुर्लभः || 7.19 ||
translation: At the end of many births, the wise man comes to Me, realizing that all this is Vaasudeva (the innermost Self); such a great soul (Mahatma) is very hard to find.
question: Is it easy to find a man of knowledge?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कामैस्तैस्तैर्हृतज्ञानाः प्रपद्यन्तेऽन्यदेवताः| तं तं नियममास्थाय प्रकृत्या नियताः स्वया || 7.20 ||
translation: Those whose wisdom has been taken away by this or that desire, go to other gods, following this or that rite, led by their own nature.
question: How do worldly minded people worship God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यो यो यां यां तनुं भक्तः श्रद्धयार्चितुमिच्छति| तस्य तस्याचलां श्रद्धां तामेव विदधाम्यहम् || 7.21 ||
translation: Whatever form any devotee desires to worship with faith, I make that same faith of his firm and unflinching.
question: Is there only way to worship God? Can we worship God in any way we like?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स तया श्रद्धया युक्तस्तस्याराधनमीहते| लभते च ततः कामान्मयैव विहितान् हि तान् || 7.22 ||
translation: Endowed with that faith, he engages in the worship of that form and obtains his desired outcome, which is ordained by Me alone.
question: Does God answer prayers for fulfilment of material desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्तवत्तु फलं तेषां तद्भवत्यल्पमेधसाम्| देवान्देवयजो यान्ति मद्भक्ता यान्ति मामपि || 7.23 ||
translation: Verily, the reward (fruit) that accrues to those men of small intelligence is finite. The worshippers of the gods go to them, whereas My devotees come to Me.
question: What is the highest form of prayer?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अव्यक्तं व्यक्ितमापन्नं मन्यन्ते मामबुद्धयः| परं भावमजानन्तो ममाव्ययमनुत्तमम् || 7.24 ||
translation: The foolish think of Me, the Unmanifest, as having manifestation, not knowing My higher, immutable, and most excellent nature.
question: How do ignorant people view an Avatar?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नाहं प्रकाशः सर्वस्य योगमायासमावृतः| मूढोऽयं नाभिजानाति लोको मामजमव्ययम् || 7.25 ||
translation: I am not manifest to all, veiled as I am by the Yoga-Maya. This deluded world does not know Me, who am unborn and imperishable.
question: Can deluded people understand God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वेदाहं समतीतानि वर्तमानानि चार्जुन| भविष्याणि च भूतानि मां तु वेद न कश्चन || 7.26 ||
translation: I know, O Arjuna, the beings of the past, the present, and the future; however, no one knows Me.
question: Is it possible for the human mind to understand God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इच्छाद्वेषसमुत्थेन द्वन्द्वमोहेन भारत| सर्वभूतानि संमोहं सर्गे यान्ति परन्तप || 7.27 ||
translation: O Bharata, all beings are subject to delusion at birth due to the delusion of the pairs of opposites arising from desire and aversion, O Parantapa.
question: What is the primary cause of delusion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: येषां त्वन्तगतं पापं जनानां पुण्यकर्मणाम्| ते द्वन्द्वमोहनिर्मुक्ता भजन्ते मां दृढव्रताः || 7.28 ||
translation: But those men of virtuous deeds, whose sins have come to an end and who are freed from the delusion of the pairs of opposites, worship Me steadfastly, with their vows.
question: How do pray to God once they are free from delusions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: जरामरणमोक्षाय मामाश्रित्य यतन्ति ये| ते ब्रह्म तद्विदुः कृत्स्नमध्यात्मं कर्म चाखिलम् || 7.29 ||
translation: Those who strive for liberation from old age and death, taking refuge in Me, realize in full that Brahman, the whole knowledge of the Self, and all action.
question: What should we ask for from God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: साधिभूताधिदैवं मां साधियज्ञं च ये विदुः| प्रयाणकालेऽपि च मां ते विदुर्युक्तचेतसः || 7.30 ||
translation: Those who know Me with the Adhibhuta (pertaining to the elements), Adhidaiva (pertaining to the gods), and the Adhiyajna (pertaining to the sacrifice) know Me even at the time of death, remaining steadfast in mind.
question: Is it possible to remember God at the time of death?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: किं तद्ब्रह्म किमध्यात्मं किं कर्म पुरुषोत्तम| अधिभूतं च किं प्रोक्तमधिदैवं किमुच्यते || 8.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "What is Brahman? What is Adhyatma? What is action, O best among men? What is Adhibhuta declared to be? And, what is Adhidaiva said to be?"
question: What did Arjuna want to know about Brahman?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अधियज्ञः कथं कोऽत्र देहेऽस्मिन्मधुसूदन| प्रयाणकाले च कथं ज्ञेयोऽसि नियतात्मभिः || 8.2 ||
translation: Who and how is Adhiyajna here in this body, O destroyer of Madhu? And how, at the time of death, are You to be known by the self-controlled?
question: What did Arjuna want to know about sacrifice?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अक्षरं ब्रह्म परमं स्वभावोऽध्यात्ममुच्यते| भूतभावोद्भवकरो विसर्गः कर्मसंज्ञितः || 8.3 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Brahman is the Imperishable, the Supreme; its essential nature is called Self-knowledge; the offering (to the gods) that causes the existence and manifestation of beings and sustains them is called action."
question: What is Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अधिभूतं क्षरो भावः पुरुषश्चाधिदैवतम्| अधियज्ञोऽहमेवात्र देहे देहभृतां वर || 8.4 ||
translation: Adhibhuta—knowledge of the elements—pertains to My perishable nature, and the Purusha, or the Soul, is the Adhidaiva; I alone am the Adhiyajna here in this body, O best among the embodied.
question: Can God exist in a human body? What is the Purusha? Who is Purusha?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्तकाले च मामेव स्मरन्मुक्त्वा कलेवरम्| यः प्रयाति स मद्भावं याति नास्त्यत्र संशयः || 8.5 ||
translation: And whoever, leaving their body, goes forth remembering Me alone at the time of death, they will attain My Being; there is no doubt about this.
question: What is the best way to die?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यं यं वापि स्मरन्भावं त्यजत्यन्ते कलेवरम्| तं तमेवैति कौन्तेय सदा तद्भावभावितः || 8.6 ||
translation: Whoever at the end leaves the body, thinking of any being, to that being only does he go, O son of Kunti (Arjuna), due to his constant thought of that being.
question: How is the next birth of a person decided?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु मामनुस्मर युध्य च| मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्मामेवैष्यस्यसंशयम् || 8.7 ||
translation: Therefore, at all times, remember Me only and fight. With your mind and intellect fixed on Me, you will undoubtedly come to Me alone.
question: Why should we think about God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अभ्यासयोगयुक्तेन चेतसा नान्यगामिना| परमं पुरुषं दिव्यं याति पार्थानुचिन्तयन् || 8.8 ||
translation: With the mind not moving towards any other thing, made steadfast through the practice of habitual meditation, and constantly meditating, one goes to the Supreme Person, the Resplendent, O Arjuna.
question: What happens if we meditate and do Yoga with focus?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कविं पुराणमनुशासितार मणोरणीयांसमनुस्मरेद्यः| सर्वस्य धातारमचिन्त्यरूप मादित्यवर्णं तमसः परस्तात् || 8.9 ||
translation: Whosoever meditates on the Omniscient, the Ancient, the Ruler of the whole world, minuter than an atom, the supporter of all, of inconceivable form, effulgent like the sun and beyond the darkness of ignorance.
question: What happens to those who meditate on God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रयाणकाले मनसाऽचलेन भक्त्या युक्तो योगबलेन चैव| भ्रुवोर्मध्ये प्राणमावेश्य सम्यक् स तं परं पुरुषमुपैति दिव्यम् || 8.10 ||
translation: At the time of death, with an unwavering mind, endowed with devotion, by the power of Yoga, fixing the whole life-breath in the middle of the two eyebrows, he reaches that resplendent Supreme Person.
question: How should one leave one's body while dying?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदक्षरं वेदविदो वदन्ति विशन्ति यद्यतयो वीतरागाः| यदिच्छन्तो ब्रह्मचर्यं चरन्ति तत्ते पदं संग्रहेण प्रवक्ष्ये || 8.11 ||
translation: That which is declared to be Imperishable by those who know the Vedas, that which the self-controlled (ascetics or Sannyasins) and passion-free enter, that goal, desiring which celibacy is practised, I will declare to thee in brief.
question: Is there any imperishable goal in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वद्वाराणि संयम्य मनो हृदि निरुध्य च| मूर्ध्न्याधायात्मनः प्राणमास्थितो योगधारणाम् || 8.12 ||
translation: Having closed all the gates, confined the mind in the heart, and fixed the life-breath in the head, engage in the practice of concentration.
question: How should one do Yoga? How to practice concentration?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ओमित्येकाक्षरं ब्रह्म व्याहरन्मामनुस्मरन्| यः प्रयाति त्यजन्देहं स याति परमां गतिम् || 8.13 ||
translation: Uttering the one-syllabled Om, the Brahman, and remembering Me, he who departs, leaving the body, attains the Supreme Goal.
question: What is the best way to leave the body after death?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनन्यचेताः सततं यो मां स्मरति नित्यशः| तस्याहं सुलभः पार्थ नित्ययुक्तस्य योगिनः || 8.14 ||
translation: I am easily attainable by that ever-steadfast yogi who constantly and daily remembers me for a long time, not thinking of anything else with a single-minded or one-pointed focus, O Partha.
question: What happens to those who remember God uninterruptedly?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मामुपेत्य पुनर्जन्म दुःखालयमशाश्वतम्| नाप्नुवन्ति महात्मानः संसिद्धिं परमां गताः || 8.15 ||
translation: Having attained Me, these great souls do not take birth again here—a place of pain and impermanence—but have reached the highest perfection of liberation.
question: Are Yogis who have attained the higher perfection in this life once again born in a human body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आब्रह्मभुवनाल्लोकाः पुनरावर्तिनोऽर्जुन| मामुपेत्य तु कौन्तेय पुनर्जन्म न विद्यते || 8.16 ||
translation: All the worlds, including the world of Brahma, are subject to return again, O Arjuna; but he who reaches Me, O son of Kunti, has no rebirth.
question: Is there rebirth for a person who has reached God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सहस्रयुगपर्यन्तमहर्यद्ब्रह्मणो विदुः| रात्रिं युगसहस्रान्तां तेऽहोरात्रविदो जनाः || 8.17 ||
translation: Those who know the day of Brahma, which lasts a thousand Yugas, and the night, which also lasts a thousand Yugas, know day and night.
question: How long is one day of Brahma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अव्यक्ताद्व्यक्तयः सर्वाः प्रभवन्त्यहरागमे| रात्र्यागमे प्रलीयन्ते तत्रैवाव्यक्तसंज्ञके || 8.18 ||
translation: From the Unmanifested, all the manifested worlds proceed upon the arrival of the 'day'; upon the arrival of the 'night', they dissolve indeed into that which is known as the Unmanifested.
question: How does the universe manifest from the unmanifested?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भूतग्रामः स एवायं भूत्वा भूत्वा प्रलीयते| रात्र्यागमेऽवशः पार्थ प्रभवत्यहरागमे || 8.19 ||
translation: This same multitude of beings, being born again and again, helplessly dissolves, O Arjuna, into the Unmanifested at the coming of the night and comes forth at the coming of the day.
question: What makes a soul born again and again?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: परस्तस्मात्तु भावोऽन्योऽव्यक्तोऽव्यक्तात्सनातनः| यः स सर्वेषु भूतेषु नश्यत्सु न विनश्यति || 8.20 ||
translation: But verily, there exists higher than this Unmanifested, another Unmanifested Eternal, which is not destroyed even when all beings are destroyed.
question: Is there anything eternal in this every changing universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अव्यक्तोऽक्षर इत्युक्तस्तमाहुः परमां गतिम्| यं प्राप्य न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम || 8.21 ||
translation: What is known as the Unmanifested and the Imperishable, That is said to be the highest goal. Those who reach It do not return (to this Samsara). That is My supreme abode (place or state).
question: What happens to those who have reached God's abode?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पुरुषः स परः पार्थ भक्त्या लभ्यस्त्वनन्यया| यस्यान्तःस्थानि भूतानि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् || 8.22 ||
translation: That highest Purusha, O Arjuna, is attainable by unswerving devotion to Him alone, within Whom all beings dwell and by Whom all this is pervaded.
question: What is the benefit of developing devotion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्र काले त्वनावृत्तिमावृत्तिं चैव योगिनः| प्रयाता यान्ति तं कालं वक्ष्यामि भरतर्षभ || 8.23 ||
translation: Now I will tell you, O chief of the Bharatas, the times of departure at which the Yogis will return or not return.
question: Is there any significance of time in the attainment of Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अग्निर्ज्योतिरहः शुक्लः षण्मासा उत्तरायणम्| तत्र प्रयाता गच्छन्ति ब्रह्म ब्रह्मविदो जनाः || 8.24 ||
translation: Fire, light, daytime, the bright fortnight, the six months of the northern path of the sun (the northern solstice) departing, then men who know Brahman go to Brahman.
question: What is the path in time followed by those who attain Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: धूमो रात्रिस्तथा कृष्णः षण्मासा दक्षिणायनम्| तत्र चान्द्रमसं ज्योतिर्योगी प्राप्य निवर्तते || 8.25 ||
translation: Attaining the lunar light through smoke, night time, the dark fortnight, and the six months of the southern path of the sun (the southern solstice), the yogi returns.
question: What happens after the Yogi attains the lunar light?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शुक्लकृष्णे गती ह्येते जगतः शाश्वते मते| एकया यात्यनावृत्तिमन्ययाऽऽवर्तते पुनः || 8.26 ||
translation: The bright and dark paths of the world are thought to be eternal; one leads to no return, and the other leads to return.
question: What are the two black and white paths of the world?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नैते सृती पार्थ जानन्योगी मुह्यति कश्चन| तस्मात्सर्वेषु कालेषु योगयुक्तो भवार्जुन || 8.27 ||
translation: Knowing these paths, O Arjuna, no yogi is deluded; therefore, at all times, be steadfast in yoga.
question: Why should we practice Yoga steadfastly?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वेदेषु यज्ञेषु तपःसु चैव दानेषु यत्पुण्यफलं प्रदिष्टम्| अत्येति तत्सर्वमिदं विदित्वा योगी परं स्थानमुपैति चाद्यम् || 8.28 ||
translation: Whatever fruit of merit is declared (in the scriptures) to accrue from (the study of) the Vedas, (the performance of) sacrifices, (the practice of) austerities, and gifts, beyond all this goes the Yogi, having known this; and he attains to the Supreme, Primeval (first or ancient) Abode.
question: Is it possible to transcend the rituals of the Vedas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इदं तु ते गुह्यतमं प्रवक्ष्याम्यनसूयवे| ज्ञानं विज्ञानसहितं यज्ज्ञात्वा मोक्ष्यसेऽशुभात् || 9.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "I shall now declare to thee, who does not cavil, the greatest secret—the knowledge combined with experience (Self-realisation). Having known this, thou shalt be free from evil."
question: Why did Krishna reveal such deep knowledge and truth to Arjuna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: राजविद्या राजगुह्यं पवित्रमिदमुत्तमम्| प्रत्यक्षावगमं धर्म्यं सुसुखं कर्तुमव्ययम् || 9.2 ||
translation: This is the royal science, the royal secret, the supreme purifier, realizable by direct intuitive knowledge, according to righteousness, very easy to perform and imperishable.
question: Is there something beyond the reach of science?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अश्रद्दधानाः पुरुषा धर्मस्यास्य परन्तप| अप्राप्य मां निवर्तन्ते मृत्युसंसारवर्त्मनि || 9.3 ||
translation: Those who have no faith in this Dharma, O Parantapa, return to the path of this world without attaining Me.
question: What happens to those who don't have faith?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मया ततमिदं सर्वं जगदव्यक्तमूर्तिना| मत्स्थानि सर्वभूतानि न चाहं तेष्ववस्थितः || 9.4 ||
translation: All of this world is pervaded by Me in My unmanifest aspect; all beings exist within Me, but I do not dwell within them.
question: Where does God live?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न च मत्स्थानि भूतानि पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम्| भूतभृन्न च भूतस्थो ममात्मा भूतभावनः || 9.5 ||
translation: Nor do beings exist in Me (in reality); behold, My divine Yoga, which supports all beings, but does not dwell in them, is My Self, the efficient cause of beings.
question: Does God exist in all beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यथाऽऽकाशस्थितो नित्यं वायुः सर्वत्रगो महान्| तथा सर्वाणि भूतानि मत्स्थानीत्युपधारय || 9.6 ||
translation: As the mighty wind, moving everywhere, always rests in the ether, so too, know that all beings rest in Me.
question: What is the relation between God and invidual human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वभूतानि कौन्तेय प्रकृतिं यान्ति मामिकाम्| कल्पक्षये पुनस्तानि कल्पादौ विसृजाम्यहम् || 9.7 ||
translation: All beings, O Arjuna, go into My Nature at the end of a Kalpa; I send them forth again at the beginning of the next Kalpa.
question: How does the cycle of time proceed?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकृतिं स्वामवष्टभ्य विसृजामि पुनः पुनः| भूतग्राममिमं कृत्स्नमवशं प्रकृतेर्वशात् || 9.8 ||
translation: Animating My Nature, I again and again send forth all this multitude of beings, helpless under the force of Nature.
question: Who or what causes human beings to be born?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न च मां तानि कर्माणि निबध्नन्ति धनञ्जय| उदासीनवदासीनमसक्तं तेषु कर्मसु || 9.9 ||
translation: These acts do not bind Me, O Arjuna, sitting as one indifferent, unattached to those acts.
question: Does God get tangled in the web of Karma?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मयाऽध्यक्षेण प्रकृतिः सूयते सचराचरम्| हेतुनाऽनेन कौन्तेय जगद्विपरिवर्तते || 9.10 ||
translation: Under Me, as supervisor, Nature produces the moving and the unmoving; therefore, O Arjuna, the world revolves.
question: Is God involved in the birth and death of living beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अवजानन्ति मां मूढा मानुषीं तनुमाश्रितम्| परं भावमजानन्तो मम भूतमहेश्वरम् || 9.11 ||
translation: Fools disregard Me, clad in human form, not knowing My higher Being as the great Lord of all beings.
question: Is it wise to believe in God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मोघाशा मोघकर्माणो मोघज्ञाना विचेतसः| राक्षसीमासुरीं चैव प्रकृतिं मोहिनीं श्रिताः || 9.12 ||
translation: They are possessed of the deceitful nature of demons and undivine beings, filled with vain hopes, vain actions, and vain knowledge that is senseless.
question: What is the nature of deluded people?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: महात्मानस्तु मां पार्थ दैवीं प्रकृतिमाश्रिताः| भजन्त्यनन्यमनसो ज्ञात्वा भूतादिमव्ययम् || 9.13 ||
translation: But the great souls, O Arjuna, partaking of My divine nature, worship Me with a single-minded devotion, knowing Me as the imperishable source of all beings.
question: How do wise people view God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सततं कीर्तयन्तो मां यतन्तश्च दृढव्रताः| नमस्यन्तश्च मां भक्त्या नित्ययुक्ता उपासते || 9.14 ||
translation: Always glorifying Me, striving, firm in their vows, prostrating themselves before Me, they worship Me with steadfast devotion.
question: How do wise people treat God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानयज्ञेन चाप्यन्ये यजन्तो मामुपासते| एकत्वेन पृथक्त्वेन बहुधा विश्वतोमुखम् || 9.15 ||
translation: Others also, sacrificing with the wisdom-sacrifice, worship Me, the All-Faced, as one, distinct, and manifold.
question: How else can one worship God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहं क्रतुरहं यज्ञः स्वधाऽहमहमौषधम्| मंत्रोऽहमहमेवाज्यमहमग्निरहं हुतम् || 9.16 ||
translation: I am Kratu; I am Yajna; I am the offering to the manes; I am the medicinal herbs and all plants; I am the Mantra; I am also the ghee or melted butter; I am the fire; I am the oblation.
question: What are the characteristics of God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पिताऽहमस्य जगतो माता धाता पितामहः| वेद्यं पवित्रमोंकार ऋक् साम यजुरेव च || 9.17 ||
translation: I am the father of this world, the mother, the dispenser of the fruits of actions, and the grandfather; the one thing to be known, the purifier, the sacred monosyllable (Om), and also the Rik, Sama, and Yajur Vedas.
question: Who is the father of this world? Who is the mother of this world? Who is the dispenser of the fruits of action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: गतिर्भर्ता प्रभुः साक्षी निवासः शरणं सुहृत्| प्रभवः प्रलयः स्थानं निधानं बीजमव्ययम् || 9.18 ||
translation: I am the goal, the supporter, the Lord, the witness, the abode, the shelter, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the foundation, the treasure-house, and the imperishable seed.
question: Who is the supporter of this universe? Who is the witness of this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तपाम्यहमहं वर्षं निगृह्णाम्युत्सृजामि च| अमृतं चैव मृत्युश्च सदसच्चाहमर्जुन || 9.19 ||
translation: As the sun, I give heat; I withhold and send forth the rain; I am immortality and also death, existence and non-existence, O Arjuna.
question: Who is the cause of immortality and death?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्रैविद्या मां सोमपाः पूतपापा यज्ञैरिष्ट्वा स्वर्गतिं प्रार्थयन्ते| ते पुण्यमासाद्य सुरेन्द्रलोक मश्नन्ति दिव्यान्दिवि देवभोगान् || 9.20 ||
translation: The knowers of the three Vedas, the drinkers of Soma, purified of all sins, worshipping Me through sacrifices, pray for the way to heaven; they reach the holy world of the Lord of the gods and enjoy the divine pleasures of the gods in heaven.
question: How can we reach heaven?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ते तं भुक्त्वा स्वर्गलोकं विशालं क्षीणे पुण्ये मर्त्यलोकं विशन्ति| एव त्रयीधर्ममनुप्रपन्ना गतागतं कामकामा लभन्ते || 9.21 ||
translation: They, having enjoyed the vast heaven, enter the world of mortals when their merit is exhausted; thus abiding by the injunctions of the three (Vedas) and desiring objects of desires, they attain to the state of coming and going.
question: Is heaven eternal?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनन्याश्चिन्तयन्तो मां ये जनाः पर्युपासते| तेषां नित्याभियुक्तानां योगक्षेमं वहाम्यहम् || 9.22 ||
translation: For those men who worship Me alone, thinking of no one else, for those ever-united, I secure what they have not already possessed and preserve what they already possess.
question: Does God take care of those who worship him or her?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: येऽप्यन्यदेवता भक्ता यजन्ते श्रद्धयाऽन्विताः| तेऽपि मामेव कौन्तेय यजन्त्यविधिपूर्वकम् || 9.23 ||
translation: Even those devotees who, endowed with faith, worship other gods, worship Me alone, O Arjuna, but by the wrong method.
question: Are the Gods of all religions the same?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहं हि सर्वयज्ञानां भोक्ता च प्रभुरेव च| न तु मामभिजानन्ति तत्त्वेनातश्च्यवन्ति ते || 9.24 ||
translation: For I alone am the enjoyer and Lord of all sacrifices; but they do not know Me in reality, and thus they return to this mortal world.
question: Who is the lord of all the sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यान्ति देवव्रता देवान् पितृ़न्यान्ति पितृव्रताः| भूतानि यान्ति भूतेज्या यान्ति मद्याजिनोऽपि माम् || 9.25 ||
translation: The worshippers of the gods go to them; the ancestor-worshippers go to the manes; the worshippers of the deities who preside over the elements go to them; but My devotees come to Me.
question: Do all religious people reach the same God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पत्रं पुष्पं फलं तोयं यो मे भक्त्या प्रयच्छति| तदहं भक्त्युपहृतमश्नामि प्रयतात्मनः || 9.26 ||
translation: Whoever offers Me with devotion a leaf, a flower, a fruit, or a little water, that, so offered devotedly by the pure-minded, I accept.
question: What should we give to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्करोषि यदश्नासि यज्जुहोषि ददासि यत्| यत्तपस्यसि कौन्तेय तत्कुरुष्व मदर्पणम् || 9.27 ||
translation: Whatever you do, whatever you eat, whatever you offer in sacrifice, whatever you give, whatever austerity you practice, O Arjuna, do it as an offering to Me.
question: What kind of attitude should we have towards God? How should we eat our food? What is devotion? What is love? What is Bhakti? What is faith? How can I best utilise my time? What is the best use of time? What is the best way to live?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शुभाशुभफलैरेवं मोक्ष्यसे कर्मबन्धनैः| संन्यासयोगयुक्तात्मा विमुक्तो मामुपैष्यसि || 9.28 ||
translation: Thus, you shall be freed from the bonds of actions yielding good and evil fruits; with the mind steadfast in the Yoga of renunciation, and liberated, you shall come to Me.
question: Can we get rid of the bad results of our actions or Karma and keep only the good ones?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: समोऽहं सर्वभूतेषु न मे द्वेष्योऽस्ति न प्रियः| ये भजन्ति तु मां भक्त्या मयि ते तेषु चाप्यहम् || 9.29 ||
translation: I am the same to all beings; there is none hateful or dear to Me; but those who worship Me with devotion are in Me, and I am also in them.
question: Does God treat everyone equally?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अपि चेत्सुदुराचारो भजते मामनन्यभाक्| साधुरेव स मन्तव्यः सम्यग्व्यवसितो हि सः || 9.30 ||
translation: Even if the most sinful worships Me, with devotion to no one else, he should indeed be regarded as righteous, for he has rightly resolved.
question: Do sinful people also have a hope for liberation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: क्षिप्रं भवति धर्मात्मा शश्वच्छान्तिं निगच्छति| कौन्तेय प्रतिजानीहि न मे भक्तः प्रणश्यति || 9.31 ||
translation: Soon he becomes righteous and attains eternal peace; O Arjuna, proclaim thou for certain that My devotee never perishes.
question: Does God take care of his devotees?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मां हि पार्थ व्यपाश्रित्य येऽपि स्युः पापयोनयः| स्त्रियो वैश्यास्तथा शूद्रास्तेऽपि यान्ति परां गतिम् || 9.32 ||
translation: For, taking refuge in Me, they who, O Arjuna, may be of a sinful birth—women, Vaisyas, and Sudras—attain the Supreme Goal.
question: Is liberation reserved only for upper caste people? Can women attain libertation? Can lower caste people attain liberation? Can shudras attain liberation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: किं पुनर्ब्राह्मणाः पुण्या भक्ता राजर्षयस्तथा| अनित्यमसुखं लोकमिमं प्राप्य भजस्व माम् || 9.33 ||
translation: How much more easily, then, do Brahmins and devoted royal saints attain the goal? Having come to this impermanent and unhappy world, do thou worship Me.
question: Can royal saints attain salvation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु| मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः || 9.34 ||
translation: Fix your mind on Me; be devoted to Me; sacrifice to Me; bow down to Me; having thus united your whole self to Me, taking Me as the supreme goal, you will come to Me.
question: What is the best way to achieve salvation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भूय एव महाबाहो श्रृणु मे परमं वचः| यत्तेऽहं प्रीयमाणाय वक्ष्यामि हितकाम्यया || 10.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, Again, O mighty-armed Arjuna, listen to my supreme word which I will declare to you, who are beloved, for your welfare.
question: Was Arjuna dear to Krishna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न मे विदुः सुरगणाः प्रभवं न महर्षयः| अहमादिर्हि देवानां महर्षीणां च सर्वशः || 10.2 ||
translation: Neither the hosts of the gods nor the great sages know My origin; for I am the source of all the gods and the great sages in every way.
question: How difficult to know and understand God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यो मामजमनादिं च वेत्ति लोकमहेश्वरम्| असम्मूढः स मर्त्येषु सर्वपापैः प्रमुच्यते || 10.3 ||
translation: He who knows Me as unborn and beginningless, as the great Lord of the worlds, he among mortals is undeluded and is liberated from all sins.
question: How can we git rid of all sin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बुद्धिर्ज्ञानमसंमोहः क्षमा सत्यं दमः शमः| सुखं दुःखं भवोऽभावो भयं चाभयमेव च || 10.4 ||
translation: Intellect, wisdom, non-delusion, forgiveness, truth, self-restraint, calmness, happiness, pain, existence or birth, non-existence or death, fear, and also fearlessness.
question: What are the qualities of a spiritual person or a devotee?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहिंसा समता तुष्टिस्तपो दानं यशोऽयशः| भवन्ति भावा भूतानां मत्त एव पृथग्विधाः || 10.5 ||
translation: Non-injury, equanimity, contentment, austerity, beneficence, fame, and ill-fame—these different qualities of beings arise from Me alone.
question: What qualities arise from God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: महर्षयः सप्त पूर्वे चत्वारो मनवस्तथा| मद्भावा मानसा जाता येषां लोक इमाः प्रजाः || 10.6 ||
translation: The seven great sages, the ancient four, and the Manus, possessing powers like Mine (due to their minds being fixed on Me), were born from My mind; from them, these creatures have been born in this world.
question: What was Manu?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एतां विभूतिं योगं च मम यो वेत्ति तत्त्वतः| सोऽविकम्पेन योगेन युज्यते नात्र संशयः || 10.7 ||
translation: He who truly knows these manifold manifestations of My Being and this Yoga-power of Mine, becomes established in unshakable Yoga; there is no doubt about it.
question: How can we become established in unshakeable Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहं सर्वस्य प्रभवो मत्तः सर्वं प्रवर्तते| इति मत्वा भजन्ते मां बुधा भावसमन्विताः || 10.8 ||
translation: I am the source of all; from me everything evolves; Understanding this, the wise, endowed with meditation, worship me.
question: What is the origin of this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मच्चित्ता मद्गतप्राणा बोधयन्तः परस्परम्| कथयन्तश्च मां नित्यं तुष्यन्ति च रमन्ति च || 10.9 ||
translation: With their minds and lives wholly absorbed in Me, they enlighten each other and ever speak of Me, being satisfied and delighted.
question: How do the Yogis live?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तेषां सततयुक्तानां भजतां प्रीतिपूर्वकम्| ददामि बुद्धियोगं तं येन मामुपयान्ति ते || 10.10 ||
translation: To those who are ever steadfast, worshipping me with love, I give the yoga of discrimination, by which they come to me.
question: Does God help those who worship him (or her)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तेषामेवानुकम्पार्थमहमज्ञानजं तमः| नाशयाम्यात्मभावस्थो ज्ञानदीपेन भास्वता || 10.11 ||
translation: Out of mere compassion for them, I, dwelling within their selves, destroy the darkness born of ignorance with the luminous lamp of knowledge.
question: Does God dispel the ignorance of those who are devoted to him (or her)?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: परं ब्रह्म परं धाम पवित्रं परमं भवान्| पुरुषं शाश्वतं दिव्यमादिदेवमजं विभुम् || 10.12 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "You are the Supreme Brahman, the supreme abode, the supreme purifier, eternal, divine Person, the primeval God, unborn, and omnipresent."
question: What did Arjuna say in praise of Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: आहुस्त्वामृषयः सर्वे देवर्षिर्नारदस्तथा| असितो देवलो व्यासः स्वयं चैव ब्रवीषि मे || 10.13 ||
translation: All the sages have thus declared Thee, as also the divine sage Narada; so also Asita, Devala, and Vyasa; and now Thou Thyself dost say so to me.
question: What did Arjuna say about Narada?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: सर्वमेतदृतं मन्ये यन्मां वदसि केशव| न हि ते भगवन् व्यक्ितं विदुर्देवा न दानवाः || 10.14 ||
translation: I believe all that You have said to me to be true, O Krishna; indeed, O blessed Lord! Neither the gods nor the demons know Your manifestation (origin).
question: Does Arjuna believe all that Krishna told him in the Gita?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: स्वयमेवात्मनाऽत्मानं वेत्थ त्वं पुरुषोत्तम| भूतभावन भूतेश देवदेव जगत्पते || 10.15 ||
translation: Verily, Thou Thyself knowest Thyself by Thyself, O Supreme Person, O source and Lord of all beings, O God of gods, O ruler of the world!
question: Did Arjuna believe in Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: वक्तुमर्हस्यशेषेण दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| याभिर्विभूतिभिर्लोकानिमांस्त्वं व्याप्य तिष्ठसि || 10.16 ||
translation: You should indeed tell, without reserve, of your divine glories by which you exist, pervading all these worlds. (No one else can do so.)
question: What more did Arjuna want to hear from Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कथं विद्यामहं योगिंस्त्वां सदा परिचिन्तयन्| केषु केषु च भावेषु चिन्त्योऽसि भगवन्मया || 10.17 ||
translation: How shall I, ever meditating, know you, O Yogin? In what aspects or things, O blessed Lord, should I think of you?
question: What did Arjuna ask about meditation?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: विस्तरेणात्मनो योगं विभूतिं च जनार्दन| भूयः कथय तृप्तिर्हि श्रृण्वतो नास्ति मेऽमृतम् || 10.18 ||
translation: Tell me again in detail, O Krishna, of your yogic power and glory; for I am not satiated with what I have heard of your life-giving and nectar-like speech.
question: Did Arjuna ever ask Krishna to repeat what he had already said?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: हन्त ते कथयिष्यामि दिव्या ह्यात्मविभूतयः| प्राधान्यतः कुरुश्रेष्ठ नास्त्यन्तो विस्तरस्य मे || 10.19 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Very well! Now I will declare to you My divine glories in their prominence, O Arjuna; there is no end to their detailed description."
question: Did Krishna ever repeat what he had already said in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहमात्मा गुडाकेश सर्वभूताशयस्थितः| अहमादिश्च मध्यं च भूतानामन्त एव च || 10.20 ||
translation: I am the Self, O Gudakesa, seated in the hearts of all beings; I am the beginning, the middle, and the end of all beings.
question: Is God same as the Self that dwells in all beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आदित्यानामहं विष्णुर्ज्योतिषां रविरंशुमान्| मरीचिर्मरुतामस्मि नक्षत्राणामहं शशी || 10.21 ||
translation: Among the twelve Adityas, I am Vishnu; among luminaries, the radiant sun; among the seven or forty-nine Maruts, I am Marichi; among stars, I am the moon.
question: Which luminous body did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वेदानां सामवेदोऽस्मि देवानामस्मि वासवः| इन्द्रियाणां मनश्चास्मि भूतानामस्मि चेतना || 10.22 ||
translation: Among the Vedas, I am the Sama-Veda; among the gods, I am Vasava; among the senses, I am the mind; and among living beings, I am intelligence.
question: Which Veda did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रुद्राणां शङ्करश्चास्मि वित्तेशो यक्षरक्षसाम्| वसूनां पावकश्चास्मि मेरुः शिखरिणामहम् || 10.23 ||
translation: And among the Rudras, I am Sankara; among the Yakshas and Rakshasas, the Lord of Wealth (Kubera); among the Vasus, I am Pavaka (Fire); and among the seven mountains, I am Meru.
question: Which mountain did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पुरोधसां च मुख्यं मां विद्धि पार्थ बृहस्पतिम्| सेनानीनामहं स्कन्दः सरसामस्मि सागरः || 10.24 ||
translation: And, among the household priests of kings, O Arjuna, know Me to be the chief, Brihaspati; among the army generals, I am Skanda; among lakes, I am the ocean.
question: Which water reservoir did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: महर्षीणां भृगुरहं गिरामस्म्येकमक्षरम्| यज्ञानां जपयज्ञोऽस्मि स्थावराणां हिमालयः || 10.25 ||
translation: Among the great sages, I am Bhrigu; among words, I am the one syllable (Om); among sacrifices, I am the sacrifice of silent repetition; among the immovable things, I am the Himalayas.
question: Which sage did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अश्वत्थः सर्ववृक्षाणां देवर्षीणां च नारदः| गन्धर्वाणां चित्ररथः सिद्धानां कपिलो मुनिः || 10.26 ||
translation: Among all the trees, I am the Peepul; among the divine sages, I am Narada; among the Gandharvas, I am Chitraratha; among the perfected, I am the sage Kapila.
question: Which tree did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उच्चैःश्रवसमश्वानां विद्धि माममृतोद्भवम्| ऐरावतं गजेन्द्राणां नराणां च नराधिपम् || 10.27 ||
translation: Know Me as Ucchaisravas, born of nectar, among horses; Airavata among lordly elephants; and the king among men.
question: Which horse and elephant did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आयुधानामहं वज्रं धेनूनामस्मि कामधुक्| प्रजनश्चास्मि कन्दर्पः सर्पाणामस्मि वासुकिः || 10.28 ||
translation: Among weapons, I am the thunderbolt; among cows, I am the wish-fulfilling cow called Kamadhenu; I am the progenitor, the god of love; among serpents, I am Vasuki.
question: Which weapon did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनन्तश्चास्मि नागानां वरुणो यादसामहम्| पितृ़णामर्यमा चास्मि यमः संयमतामहम् || 10.29 ||
translation: I am Ananta among the Nagas; I am Varuna among water-deities; Aryaman among the Manes; I am Yama among the governors.
question: Which aquatic being did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रह्लादश्चास्मि दैत्यानां कालः कलयतामहम्| मृगाणां च मृगेन्द्रोऽहं वैनतेयश्च पक्षिणाम् || 10.30 ||
translation: And I am Prahlada among the demons, I am Time among reckoners, I am the lion among beasts, and Vainateya (Garuda) among birds.
question: Which bird did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पवनः पवतामस्मि रामः शस्त्रभृतामहम्| झषाणां मकरश्चास्मि स्रोतसामस्मि जाह्नवी || 10.31 ||
translation: Among the purifiers, I am the wind; among the warriors, I am Rama; among the fishes, I am the shark; among the streams, I am the Ganga.
question: Which warrior did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्गाणामादिरन्तश्च मध्यं चैवाहमर्जुन| अध्यात्मविद्या विद्यानां वादः प्रवदतामहम् || 10.32 ||
translation: Among creations I am the beginning, the middle, and the end, O Arjuna; among the sciences, I am the science of the Self; and I am the logic among controversialists.
question: Which science did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अक्षराणामकारोऽस्मि द्वन्द्वः सामासिकस्य च| अहमेवाक्षयः कालो धाताऽहं विश्वतोमुखः || 10.33 ||
translation: Among the letters of the alphabet, I am the letter 'A' and the dual among compounds. I am verily the inexhaustible and everlasting time; I am the dispenser of the fruits of actions, having faces in all directions.
question: What letter did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मृत्युः सर्वहरश्चाहमुद्भवश्च भविष्यताम्| कीर्तिः श्रीर्वाक्च नारीणां स्मृतिर्मेधा धृतिः क्षमा || 10.34 ||
translation: And I am the all-devouring Death, and the source of prosperity for those who are to be prosperous; among the feminine qualities, I am fame, prosperity, speech, memory, intelligence, firmness, and forgiveness.
question: Which feminine quality did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बृहत्साम तथा साम्नां गायत्री छन्दसामहम्| मासानां मार्गशीर्षोऽहमृतूनां कुसुमाकरः || 10.35 ||
translation: Among the hymns, I am the Brihatsaman; among meters, I am Gayatri; among months, I am Margasirsha; among seasons, I am the flowery season.
question: Which hymn did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्यूतं छलयतामस्मि तेजस्तेजस्विनामहम्| जयोऽस्मि व्यवसायोऽस्मि सत्त्वं सत्त्ववतामहम् || 10.36 ||
translation: I am the gambling of the deceitful; I am the splendor of the splendid; I am victory; I am the resolve of the resolute; I am the goodness of the good.
question: Which fraudulent activity did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: वृष्णीनां वासुदेवोऽस्मि पाण्डवानां धनंजयः| मुनीनामप्यहं व्यासः कवीनामुशना कविः || 10.37 ||
translation: Among the Vrishnis, I am Vaasudeva; among the Pandavas, I am Arjuna; among the sages, I am Vyasa; among the poets, I am Usanas, the poet.
question: Which Pandava did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दण्डो दमयतामस्मि नीतिरस्मि जिगीषताम्| मौनं चैवास्मि गुह्यानां ज्ञानं ज्ञानवतामहम् || 10.38 ||
translation: Of those who punish, I am the scepter; among those who seek victory, I am statesmanship; and among secrets, I am silence; I am knowledge among knowers.
question: Which secret did Krishna compare God with?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यच्चापि सर्वभूतानां बीजं तदहमर्जुन| न तदस्ति विना यत्स्यान्मया भूतं चराचरम् || 10.39 ||
translation: And whatever is the seed of all beings, that too am I, O Arjuna; there is no being, be it moving or unmoving, that can exist without Me.
question: Can anything exist without God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नान्तोऽस्ति मम दिव्यानां विभूतीनां परंतप| एष तूद्देशतः प्रोक्तो विभूतेर्विस्तरो मया || 10.40 ||
translation: There is no end to My divine glories, O Arjuna, but this is a brief statement by Me of the particulars of My divine glory.
question: What are the limitations of God and his manifestations?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यद्यद्विभूतिमत्सत्त्वं श्रीमदूर्जितमेव वा| तत्तदेवावगच्छ त्वं मम तेजोंऽशसंभवम् || 10.41 ||
translation: Whatever being there is glorious, prosperous, or powerful, know that to be a manifestation of a part of My splendor.
question: What is the source of power and energy in human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अथवा बहुनैतेन किं ज्ञातेन तवार्जुन| विष्टभ्याहमिदं कृत्स्नमेकांशेन स्थितो जगत् || 10.42 ||
translation: But, of what avail is the knowledge of all these details to you, O Arjuna? I exist, supporting this whole world with one part of Myself.
question: Is it useful to have a detailed knowledge of how the universe functions?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: मदनुग्रहाय परमं गुह्यमध्यात्मसंज्ञितम्| यत्त्वयोक्तं वचस्तेन मोहोऽयं विगतो मम || 11.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, By this explanation of the highest secret concerning the Self which Thou hast spoken, for the sake of blessing me, my delusion has been dispelled.
question: Did Arjuna's delusion get dispelled?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: भवाप्ययौ हि भूतानां श्रुतौ विस्तरशो मया| त्वत्तः कमलपत्राक्ष माहात्म्यमपि चाव्ययम् || 11.2 ||
translation: The origin and destruction of beings have been heard in detail from You, O lotus-eyed Lord, and also Your inexhaustible greatness.
question: Did Arjuna hear the Gita in detail?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: एवमेतद्यथात्थ त्वमात्मानं परमेश्वर| द्रष्टुमिच्छामि ते रूपमैश्वरं पुरुषोत्तम || 11.3 ||
translation: Now, O Supreme Lord, as Thou hast thus described Thyself, O Supreme Person, I wish to behold Thy divine form.
question: When did Arjuna want to see Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: मन्यसे यदि तच्छक्यं मया द्रष्टुमिति प्रभो| योगेश्वर ततो मे त्वं दर्शयाऽत्मानमव्ययम् || 11.4 ||
translation: If Thou, O Lord, thinkest it possible for me to see it, do Thou, then, O Lord of the Yogis, show me Thy imperishable Self.
question: Where in Gita did Arjuna ask Krishna to reveal his divine form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पश्य मे पार्थ रूपाणि शतशोऽथ सहस्रशः| नानाविधानि दिव्यानि नानावर्णाकृतीनि च || 11.5 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "Behold, O Arjuna, forms of Mine, by the hundreds and thousands, of different sorts, divine, and of various colors and shapes."
question: Where in the Gita did Krishna start revealing his divine form to Arjuna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पश्यादित्यान्वसून्रुद्रानश्िवनौ मरुतस्तथा| बहून्यदृष्टपूर्वाणि पश्याऽश्चर्याणि भारत || 11.6 ||
translation: Behold the Adityas, the Vasus, the Rudras, the two Asvins, and the Maruts; behold many wonders never before seen, O Arjuna.
question: What did Arjuna first see in Krishna's divine form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इहैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं पश्याद्य सचराचरम्| मम देहे गुडाकेश यच्चान्यद्द्रष्टुमिच्छसि || 11.7 ||
translation: Now, behold, O Arjuna, in this My body, the entire universe centered in one, including the moving and the unmoving, and whatever else you desire to see.
question: Did Krishna show Arjuna the whole universe in his divine form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न तु मां शक्यसे द्रष्टुमनेनैव स्वचक्षुषा| दिव्यं ददामि ते चक्षुः पश्य मे योगमैश्वरम् || 11.8 ||
translation: But you are not able to behold Me with these your own eyes; I give you the divine eye; behold My lordly Yoga.
question: Is it possible to see God with our own eyes?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: एवमुक्त्वा ततो राजन्महायोगेश्वरो हरिः| दर्शयामास पार्थाय परमं रूपमैश्वरम् || 11.9 ||
translation: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken, O king, the great Lord of Yoga, Hari (Krishna), showed Arjuna His supreme form as the Lord.
question: What did Sanjay say on seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: अनेकवक्त्रनयनमनेकाद्भुतदर्शनम्| अनेकदिव्याभरणं दिव्यानेकोद्यतायुधम् || 11.10 ||
translation: With numerous mouths and eyes, with numerous wondrous sights, with numerous divine adornments, with numerous divine weapons uplifted, such a form He showed.
question: How did Sanjay describe Krishna's divine form?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: दिव्यमाल्याम्बरधरं दिव्यगन्धानुलेपनम्| सर्वाश्चर्यमयं देवमनन्तं विश्वतोमुखम् || 11.11 ||
translation: Wearing divine garlands and apparel, anointed with divine unguents, the all-wonderful, resplendent Being is endless with faces on all sides.
question: What was Krishna wearing when he showed his divine form?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: दिवि सूर्यसहस्रस्य भवेद्युगपदुत्थिता| यदि भाः सदृशी सा स्याद्भासस्तस्य महात्मनः || 11.12 ||
translation: If the splendour of a thousand suns were to blaze out simultaneously in the sky, that would be the splendour of that mighty being.
question: How was the splendour of Krishna's divine form?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: तत्रैकस्थं जगत्कृत्स्नं प्रविभक्तमनेकधा| अपश्यद्देवदेवस्य शरीरे पाण्डवस्तदा || 11.13 ||
translation: There, in the body of the God of gods, Arjuna then saw the entire universe resting in one, with its myriad of divisions.
question: How vast was Krishna's divine form?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: ततः स विस्मयाविष्टो हृष्टरोमा धनञ्जयः| प्रणम्य शिरसा देवं कृताञ्जलिरभाषत || 11.14 ||
translation: Then, Arjuna, filled with wonder and his hair standing on end, bowed his head to the God and spoke with palms joined.
question: What was Arjuna's physical reaction on seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: पश्यामि देवांस्तव देव देहे सर्वांस्तथा भूतविशेषसङ्घान्| ब्रह्माणमीशं कमलासनस्थ मृषींश्च सर्वानुरगांश्च दिव्यान् || 11.15 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O God, I see all the gods in Your body, as well as hosts of various classes of beings, Brahma the Lord seated on the lotus, all the sages, and the celestial serpents."
question: Did Arjuna see other Gods in Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अनेकबाहूदरवक्त्रनेत्रं पश्यामि त्वां सर्वतोऽनन्तरूपम्| नान्तं न मध्यं न पुनस्तवादिं पश्यामि विश्वेश्वर विश्वरूप || 11.16 ||
translation: I see You with boundless form on every side, with many arms, stomachs, mouths, and eyes; neither the end nor the middle nor the beginning do I see, O Lord of the Universe, O Cosmic Form.
question: Did Krishna's divine form have a beginning and an end? What is the proof of God's existence? What is the proof of God? How do we know that God exists?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रिणं च तेजोराशिं सर्वतोदीप्तिमन्तम्| पश्यामि त्वां दुर्निरीक्ष्यं समन्ता द्दीप्तानलार्कद्युतिमप्रमेयम् || 11.17 ||
translation: I see You with the diadem, club, and discus, a mass of radiance shining everywhere, very hard to look at, blazing all around like a burning fire and the sun, and immeasurable.
question: How can we describe Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: त्वमक्षरं परमं वेदितव्यं त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्| त्वमव्ययः शाश्वतधर्मगोप्ता सनातनस्त्वं पुरुषो मतो मे || 11.18 ||
translation: You are the Imperishable, the Supreme Being, worthy of being known. You are the great treasure-house of this universe; You are the imperishable protector of the eternal Dharma; You are the Primal Person, I believe.
question: After seeing Krishna's divine form, was Arjuna convinced that he indeed is the supreme God?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अनादिमध्यान्तमनन्तवीर्य मनन्तबाहुं शशिसूर्यनेत्रम्| पश्यामि त्वां दीप्तहुताशवक्त्रम् स्वतेजसा विश्वमिदं तपन्तम् || 11.19 ||
translation: I see You without beginning, middle, or end, infinite in power, with endless arms, the sun and moon as Your eyes, the burning fire Your mouth, heating the entire universe with Your radiance.
question: How many arms and eyes did Krishna's divine form have?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: द्यावापृथिव्योरिदमन्तरं हि व्याप्तं त्वयैकेन दिशश्च सर्वाः| दृष्ट्वाऽद्भुतं रूपमुग्रं तवेदं लोकत्रयं प्रव्यथितं महात्मन् || 11.20 ||
translation: This space between the earth and the heavens, and all the quarters, is filled by You alone; having seen this, Your wonderful and terrible form, the three worlds are trembling with fear, O great-souled Being.
question: Did Krishna's divine form invoke love or fear?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अमी हि त्वां सुरसङ्घा विशन्ति केचिद्भीताः प्राञ्जलयो गृणन्ति| स्वस्तीत्युक्त्वा महर्षिसिद्धसङ्घाः स्तुवन्ति त्वां स्तुतिभिः पुष्कलाभिः || 11.21 ||
translation: Verily, these hosts of gods enter into Thee; some extol Thee with joined palms in fear, saying, 'May it be well!' Bands of great sages and perfected ones praise Thee with complete hymns.
question: Are the devas afraid of the supreme God?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: रुद्रादित्या वसवो ये च साध्या विश्वेऽश्िवनौ मरुतश्चोष्मपाश्च| गन्धर्वयक्षासुरसिद्धसङ्घा वीक्षन्ते त्वां विस्मिताश्चैव सर्वे || 11.22 ||
translation: The Rudras, Adityas, Vasus, Sadhyas, Visvedevas, the two Asvins, Maruts, the Manus, and the hosts of celestial singers, Yakshas, demons, and the perfected ones, all look upon Thee with great amazement.
question: How do the Devas look upon God?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: रूपं महत्ते बहुवक्त्रनेत्रं महाबाहो बहुबाहूरुपादम्| बहूदरं बहुदंष्ट्राकरालं दृष्ट्वा लोकाः प्रव्यथितास्तथाऽहम् || 11.23 ||
translation: Having seen Your immeasurable form with many mouths and eyes, O mighty-armed one, with many arms, thighs, and feet, with many stomachs and fearsome with many teeth, the worlds are terrified, and so am I.
question: Was Arjuna terrified after seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: नभःस्पृशं दीप्तमनेकवर्णं व्यात्ताननं दीप्तविशालनेत्रम्| दृष्ट्वा हि त्वां प्रव्यथितान्तरात्मा धृतिं न विन्दामि शमं च विष्णो || 11.24 ||
translation: On seeing Thee, touching the sky, shining in many colors, with mouths wide open, with large fiery eyes, I am terrified at heart and find neither courage nor peace, O Vishnu.
question: Why was Arjuna scared after seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: दंष्ट्राकरालानि च ते मुखानि दृष्ट्वैव कालानलसन्निभानि| दिशो न जाने न लभे च शर्म प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास || 11.25 ||
translation: Having seen Thy mouths fearful with teeth blazing like the fires of cosmic dissolution, I know not the four quarters, nor do I find peace. Have mercy, O Lord of the gods, O abode of the universe.
question: Did Arjuna feel comfortable on seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अमी च त्वां धृतराष्ट्रस्य पुत्राः सर्वे सहैवावनिपालसङ्घैः| भीष्मो द्रोणः सूतपुत्रस्तथाऽसौ सहास्मदीयैरपि योधमुख्यैः || 11.26 ||
translation: All the sons of Dhritarashtra, along with the hosts of kings of the earth, Bhishma, Drona, and Karna, as well as the chief among our warriors.
question: Did Arjuna see the Kauravas inside Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: वक्त्राणि ते त्वरमाणा विशन्ति दंष्ट्राकरालानि भयानकानि| केचिद्विलग्ना दशनान्तरेषु संदृश्यन्ते चूर्णितैरुत्तमाङ्गैः || 11.27 ||
translation: Some hurry into Your mouths with their terrible teeth, fearful to behold. Some are found stuck in the gaps between the teeth, their heads crushed to powder.
question: Did Arjuna see warriors being crushed by Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यथा नदीनां बहवोऽम्बुवेगाः समुद्रमेवाभिमुखा द्रवन्ति| तथा तवामी नरलोकवीरा विशन्ति वक्त्राण्यभिविज्वलन्ति || 11.28 ||
translation: Verily, just as many torrents of rivers flow towards the ocean, so too these heroes in the world of men enter Thy flaming mouths.
question: What did Arjuna compare Krishna's mouth with?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यथा प्रदीप्तं ज्वलनं पतङ्गा विशन्ति नाशाय समृद्धवेगाः| तथैव नाशाय विशन्ति लोका स्तवापि वक्त्राणि समृद्धवेगाः || 11.29 ||
translation: As moths hurriedly rush into a blazing fire, leading to their own destruction, so too these creatures hurry into Your mouths, leading to their own destruction.
question: What did Arjuna compare the creatures entering Krishna's mouth with?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: लेलिह्यसे ग्रसमानः समन्ता ल्लोकान्समग्रान्वदनैर्ज्वलद्भिः| तेजोभिरापूर्य जगत्समग्रं भासस्तवोग्राः प्रतपन्ति विष्णो || 11.30 ||
translation: Thou lickest up, devouring all the worlds on every side with Thy flaming mouths. Thy fierce rays, filling the whole world with radiance, burn, O Vishnu!
question: How did Arjuna describe various living beings entering Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: आख्याहि मे को भवानुग्ररूपो नमोऽस्तु ते देववर प्रसीद| विज्ञातुमिच्छामि भवन्तमाद्यं न हि प्रजानामि तव प्रवृत्तिम् || 11.31 ||
translation: Tell me, who you are, so fierce of form. I offer my salutations to you, O God Supreme; have mercy on me. I desire to know you, the original Being. I do not indeed know your workings.
question: What did Arjuna ask Krishna to do after seeing his terrifying divine form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कालोऽस्मि लोकक्षयकृत्प्रवृद्धो लोकान्समाहर्तुमिह प्रवृत्तः| ऋतेऽपि त्वां न भविष्यन्ति सर्वे येऽवस्थिताः प्रत्यनीकेषु योधाः || 11.32 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "I am the full-grown, world-destroying Time, now engaged in destroying the worlds. Even without you, none of the warriors arrayed in the hostile armies will live."
question: Were the warriors in the Mahabharata war destined to die?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मात्त्वमुत्तिष्ठ यशो लभस्व जित्वा शत्रून् भुङ्क्ष्व राज्यं समृद्धम्| मयैवैते निहताः पूर्वमेव निमित्तमात्रं भव सव्यसाचिन् || 11.33 ||
translation: Therefore, stand up and obtain fame. Conquer the enemies and enjoy the unparalleled kingdom. Verily, by Me they have already been slain; be thou a mere instrument, O Arjuna.
question: Was Arjuna merely an intrument in the war to carry out mass termination of human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्रोणं च भीष्मं च जयद्रथं च कर्णं तथाऽन्यानपि योधवीरान्| मया हतांस्त्वं जहि मा व्यथिष्ठा युध्यस्व जेतासि रणे सपत्नान् || 11.34 ||
translation: Drona, Bhishma, Jayadratha, Karna, and other brave warriors have already been slain by Me; do not be distressed with fear; fight and you shall conquer your enemies in battle.
question: How did Krishna convince Arjuna that he is going to win in the war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: एतच्छ्रुत्वा वचनं केशवस्य कृताञ्जलिर्वेपमानः किरीटी| नमस्कृत्वा भूय एवाह कृष्णं सगद्गदं भीतभीतः प्रणम्य || 11.35 ||
translation: Sanjaya said, Having heard that speech of Lord Krishna, Arjuna, with joined palms, trembling, prostrated himself, again addressing Krishna in a choked voice, bowing down, overwhelmed with fear.
question: Was Arjuna choked with emotion on seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: स्थाने हृषीकेश तव प्रकीर्त्या जगत् प्रहृष्यत्यनुरज्यते च| रक्षांसि भीतानि दिशो द्रवन्ति सर्वे नमस्यन्ति च सिद्धसङ्घाः || 11.36 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "It is fitting, O Krishna, that the world delights and rejoices in Your praise; demons fly in fear in all directions and the hosts of the perfected ones bow to You."
question: Who is afraid of God?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कस्माच्च ते न नमेरन्महात्मन् गरीयसे ब्रह्मणोऽप्यादिकर्त्रे| अनन्त देवेश जगन्निवास त्वमक्षरं सदसत्तत्परं यत् || 11.37 ||
translation: And why should they not, O great Soul, bow to Thee Who art greater than all else, the primal cause even of the Creator (Brahma), O Infinite Being, O Lord of the gods, O Abode of the universe; Thou art the imperishable, the Being, the non-being, and That which is supreme—that which is beyond the Being and the non-being.
question: Why do the sages bow down to God?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: त्वमादिदेवः पुरुषः पुराण स्त्वमस्य विश्वस्य परं निधानम्| वेत्तासि वेद्यं च परं च धाम त्वया ततं विश्वमनन्तरूप || 11.38 ||
translation: You are the primal God, the ancient Purusha, the supreme refuge of this universe, the knower, the knowable, and the supreme Abode. Through You, the universe is pervaded, O Being of infinite forms.
question: who is the knower as well as the object of knowledge?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: वायुर्यमोऽग्निर्वरुणः शशाङ्कः प्रजापतिस्त्वं प्रपितामहश्च| नमो नमस्तेऽस्तु सहस्रकृत्वः पुनश्च भूयोऽपि नमो नमस्ते || 11.39 ||
translation: You are Vayu, Yama, Agni, Varuna, the moon, the Creator, and the great-grandfather. I offer my salutations to You a thousand times, and again I offer my salutations to You.
question: What does Arjuna compare Krishna with?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: नमः पुरस्तादथ पृष्ठतस्ते नमोऽस्तु ते सर्वत एव सर्व| अनन्तवीर्यामितविक्रमस्त्वं सर्वं समाप्नोषि ततोऽसि सर्वः || 11.40 ||
