translation: Salutations to You in front and behind! Salutations to You on every side! O All! You, infinite in power and prowess, pervade all; therefore You are all.
question: Did Arjuna finally realise that Krishna was God himself?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: सखेति मत्वा प्रसभं यदुक्तं हे कृष्ण हे यादव हे सखेति| अजानता महिमानं तवेदं मया प्रमादात्प्रणयेन वापि || 11.41 ||
translation: Whatever I have presumptuously said from carelessness or love, addressing You as O Krishna! O Yadava! O Friend! regarding You merely as a friend, unknowing of Your greatness.
question: When did Arjuna develop devotion towards Krishna?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: यच्चावहासार्थमसत्कृतोऽसि विहारशय्यासनभोजनेषु| एकोऽथवाप्यच्युत तत्समक्षं तत्क्षामये त्वामहमप्रमेयम् || 11.42 ||
translation: In whatever way I may have insulted You for the sake of fun, while at play, reposing, sitting, or at meals, when alone (with You), O Krishna, or in company, that I implore You, immeasurable one, to forgive.
question: Did Arjuna ever treat Krishna with disrespect?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: पितासि लोकस्य चराचरस्य त्वमस्य पूज्यश्च गुरुर्गरीयान्| न त्वत्समोऽस्त्यभ्यधिकः कुतोऽन्यो लोकत्रयेऽप्यप्रतिमप्रभाव || 11.43 ||
translation: Thou art the Father of this world, both moving and unmoving. Thou art to be adored by this world; Thou, the greatest Guru; for none exists who is equal to Thee; how then could there be another superior to Thee in the three worlds, O Being of unrivaled power?
question: Did Arjuna realise that Krishna was the highest being?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: तस्मात्प्रणम्य प्रणिधाय कायं प्रसादये त्वामहमीशमीड्यम्| पितेव पुत्रस्य सखेव सख्युः प्रियः प्रियायार्हसि देव सोढुम् || 11.44 ||
translation: Therefore, bowing down and prostrating my body, I crave Thy forgiveness, O adorable Lord. As a father forgives his son, a friend his dear friend, a lover his beloved, even so may Thou forgive me, O God.
question: When did Arjuna ask for Krishna's mercy?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: अदृष्टपूर्वं हृषितोऽस्मि दृष्ट्वा भयेन च प्रव्यथितं मनो मे| तदेव मे दर्शय देव रूपं प्रसीद देवेश जगन्निवास || 11.45 ||
translation: I am delighted, having seen something never seen before; yet my mind is distressed with fear. Show me that form only, O God; have mercy, O God of gods, O Abode of the universe.
question: Was Arjuna delighted after seeing Krishna's divine form?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: किरीटिनं गदिनं चक्रहस्त मिच्छामि त्वां द्रष्टुमहं तथैव| तेनैव रूपेण चतुर्भुजेन सहस्रबाहो भव विश्वमूर्ते || 11.46 ||
translation: I desire to see You as before, crowned, bearing a mace, with the discus in hand, in Your former form only, having four arms, O thousand-armed, Cosmic Being.
question: When did Arjuna ask Krishna to show his gracious form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मया प्रसन्नेन तवार्जुनेदं रूपं परं दर्शितमात्मयोगात्| तेजोमयं विश्वमनन्तमाद्यं यन्मे त्वदन्येन न दृष्टपूर्वम् || 11.47 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this Cosmic Form has graciously been shown to you by Me through My own Yogic power. It is full of splendour, primeval, and infinite; this Cosmic Form of Mine has never been seen before by anyone other than you."
question: Had anyone seen Krishna's divine form before Arjuna?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न वेदयज्ञाध्ययनैर्न दानै र्न च क्रियाभिर्न तपोभिरुग्रैः| एवंरूपः शक्य अहं नृलोके द्रष्टुं त्वदन्येन कुरुप्रवीर || 11.48 ||
translation: Neither by the study of the Vedas, nor by gifts, nor by sacrifices, nor by severe austerities, can I be seen in this form in the world of men by any other than yourself, O great hero of the Kurus (Arjuna).
question: Can we get to see Krishna's divine form through austerities? Can we get to see God through austerities?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मा ते व्यथा मा च विमूढभावो दृष्ट्वा रूपं घोरमीदृङ्ममेदम्| व्यपेतभीः प्रीतमनाः पुनस्त्वं तदेव मे रूपमिदं प्रपश्य || 11.49 ||
translation: Do not be afraid, nor be bewildered on seeing such a terrible form of Mine; with your fear dispelled and with a gladdened heart, now behold again this former form of Mine.
question: Did Krishna get back to his usual form in the war?

speaker: सञ्जय
sanskrit: इत्यर्जुनं वासुदेवस्तथोक्त्वा स्वकं रूपं दर्शयामास भूयः| आश्वासयामास च भीतमेनं भूत्वा पुनः सौम्यवपुर्महात्मा || 11.50 ||
translation: Sanjaya said, Having thus spoken to Arjuna, Krishna again showed His own form. The great Soul, assuming His gentle form, then consoled Arjuna, who was terrified.
question: When Krishna get back to his usual form in the war?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: दृष्ट्वेदं मानुषं रूपं तवसौम्यं जनार्दन| इदानीमस्मि संवृत्तः सचेताः प्रकृतिं गतः || 11.51 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "Having seen this Thy gentle human form, O Krishna, now I am composed and have been restored to my own nature."
question: When did Arjuna gain his composure after seeing the divine form?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सुदुर्दर्शमिदं रूपं दृष्टवानसि यन्मम| देवा अप्यस्य रूपस्य नित्यं दर्शनकाङ्क्षिणः || 11.52 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "It is very hard indeed to see this form of Mine which thou hast seen; even the gods are ever longing to behold it."
question: Is it easy to get to see God's divine  form? Is it easy to get to see God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नाहं वेदैर्न तपसा न दानेन न चेज्यया| शक्य एवंविधो द्रष्टुं दृष्टवानसि मां यथा || 11.53 ||
translation: Neither by the Vedas, nor by austerity, nor by gift, nor by sacrifice can I be seen in this form as thou hast seen Me so easily.
question: Can we get to see Krishna's divine form through rituals?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: भक्त्या त्वनन्यया शक्य अहमेवंविधोऽर्जुन| ज्ञातुं दृष्टुं च तत्त्वेन प्रवेष्टुं च परंतप || 11.54 ||
translation: But by single-minded devotion, I can be known, seen, and entered into in reality, O Arjuna.
question: Is devotion necessary to know God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मत्कर्मकृन्मत्परमो मद्भक्तः सङ्गवर्जितः| निर्वैरः सर्वभूतेषु यः स मामेति पाण्डव || 11.55 ||
translation: He who does all actions for Me, who regards Me as the Supreme, who is devoted to Me, who is free from attachment, who bears no enmity towards any creature, he comes to Me, O Arjuna.
question: What happens to those who have no enemies?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: एवं सततयुक्ता ये भक्तास्त्वां पर्युपासते| येचाप्यक्षरमव्यक्तं तेषां के योगवित्तमाः || 12.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "Which of them are better versed in Yoga—those who steadfastly worship You, or those who worship the imperishable and the unmanifested?"
question: When did Arjuna start asking about devotion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मय्यावेश्य मनो ये मां नित्ययुक्ता उपासते| श्रद्धया परयोपेतास्ते मे युक्ततमा मताः || 12.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "In My opinion, those who fix their minds on Me, worship Me ever steadfastly, and are endowed with supreme faith, are the best in Yoga."
question: Who is considered to be the highest among Yogis?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ये त्वक्षरमनिर्देश्यमव्यक्तं पर्युपासते| सर्वत्रगमचिन्त्यं च कूटस्थमचलं ध्रुवम् || 12.3 ||
translation: Those who worship the imperishable, the indefinable, the unmanifest, the omnipresent, the unthinkable, the immovable, and the eternal.
question: What happens to those who meditate on formless God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: संनियम्येन्द्रियग्रामं सर्वत्र समबुद्धयः| ते प्राप्नुवन्ति मामेव सर्वभूतहिते रताः || 12.4 ||
translation: Having restrained all the senses, being even-minded everywhere, and intent on the welfare of all beings, they verily come unto Me.
question: What happens after we have controlled our senses?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
क्लेशोऽधिकतरस्तेषामव्यक्तासक्तचेतसाम्|

अव्यक्ता हि गतिर्दुःखं देहवद्भिरवाप्यते || 12.5 ||
translation: Greater is their trouble whose minds are set on the unmanifested, for the goal of the unmanifested is very hard for the embodied to reach.
question: Is God with form or formless?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
ये तु सर्वाणि कर्माणि मयि संन्यस्य मत्पराः|

अनन्येनैव योगेन मां ध्यायन्त उपासते || 12.6 ||
translation: But to those who worship Me, renouncing all actions in Me, regarding Me as the supreme goal, meditating on Me with single-minded yoga.
question: What is the use of having faith in God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
तेषामहं समुद्धर्ता मृत्युसंसारसागरात्|

भवामि नचिरात्पार्थ मय्यावेशितचेतसाम् || 12.7 ||
translation: To those whose minds are set on Me, O Arjuna, verily I soon become the savior out of the ocean of Samsara.
question: Is it useful to pray to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
मय्येव मन आधत्स्व मयि बुद्धिं निवेशय|

निवसिष्यसि मय्येव अत ऊर्ध्वं न संशयः || 12.8 ||
translation: Fix your mind on Me, and your intellect in Me. Then you will certainly live in Me alone hereafter.
question: What should we fix our mind on during meditation? Where does Krishna talk about surrender? Where does Gita talk about surrender?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
अथ चित्तं समाधातुं न शक्नोषि मयि स्थिरम्|

अभ्यासयोगेन ततो मामिच्छाप्तुं धनञ्जय || 12.9 ||
translation: If you are unable to fix your mind steadily on Me, then seek to reach Me through the yoga of constant practice, O Arjuna.
question: What do I do if I am unable to focus my mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
अभ्यासेऽप्यसमर्थोऽसि मत्कर्मपरमो भव|

मदर्थमपि कर्माणि कुर्वन् सिद्धिमवाप्स्यसि || 12.10 ||
translation: If you are unable to practice even this Abhyasa Yoga, be intent on doing actions for My sake; even by doing actions for My sake, you will attain perfection.
question: What do I do if I am unable to practice Yoga?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
अथैतदप्यशक्तोऽसि कर्तुं मद्योगमाश्रितः|

सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं ततः कुरु यतात्मवान् || 12.11 ||
translation: If you are unable to do even this, then, resort to union with Me and renounce the fruits of all actions with self-control.
question: What do I do if I am unable to do selfless service?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
श्रेयो हि ज्ञानमभ्यासाज्ज्ञानाद्ध्यानं विशिष्यते|

ध्यानात्कर्मफलत्यागस्त्यागाच्छान्तिरनन्तरम् || 12.12 ||
translation: Better indeed is knowledge than practice; better than knowledge is meditation; better than meditation is the renunciation of the fruits of actions: peace immediately follows renunciation.
question: Is there anything better than meditation for spiritual growth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
अद्वेष्टा सर्वभूतानां मैत्रः करुण एव च|

निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः समदुःखसुखः क्षमी || 12.13 ||
translation: He who hates no creature, is friendly and compassionate to all, is free from attachment and egoism, is balanced in pleasure and pain, and is forgiving.
question: Why should we develop compassion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
सन्तुष्टः सततं योगी यतात्मा दृढनिश्चयः|

मय्यर्पितमनोबुद्धिर्यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः || 12.14 ||
translation: Ever content, steady in meditation, self-controlled, possessing firm conviction, with the mind and intellect dedicated to Me, he, My devotee, is dear to Me.
question: Are people with a firm conviction dear to God? Who is dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
यस्मान्नोद्विजते लोको लोकान्नोद्विजते च यः|

हर्षामर्षभयोद्वेगैर्मुक्तो यः स च मे प्रियः || 12.15 ||
translation: He whom the world does not agitate, and who cannot be agitated by the world, and who is freed from joy, anger, fear, and anxiety—he is dear to Me.
question: Are people free from fear and aversion dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
अनपेक्षः शुचिर्दक्ष उदासीनो गतव्यथः|

सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी यो मद्भक्तः स मे प्रियः || 12.16 ||
translation: He who is free from wants, pure, expert, unconcerned, and free from pain, renouncing all undertakings and commencements, he who is devoted to Me is dear to Me.
question: Are people free from desires and agony dear to God? Who is a true devotee?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
यो न हृष्यति न द्वेष्टि न शोचति न काङ्क्षति|

शुभाशुभपरित्यागी भक्ितमान्यः स मे प्रियः || 12.17 ||
translation: He who neither rejoices nor hates, nor grieves nor desires, renouncing both good and evil, and who is full of devotion, is dear to Me.
question: Are people free from hatred and full of devotion dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
समः शत्रौ च मित्रे च तथा मानापमानयोः|

शीतोष्णसुखदुःखेषु समः सङ्गविवर्जितः || 12.18 ||
translation: He who is the same to foe and friend, and also in honor and dishonor, who is the same in cold and heat, in pleasure and pain, and who is free from attachment.
question: Are people free from all attachment dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
तुल्यनिन्दास्तुतिर्मौनी सन्तुष्टो येनकेनचित्|

अनिकेतः स्थिरमतिर्भक्ितमान्मे प्रियो नरः || 12.19 ||
translation: He to whom censure and praise are equal, who is silent, content with anything, homeless, of a steady mind, and full of devotion; that man is dear to me.
question: Are people with a firm mind dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit:
ये तु धर्म्यामृतमिदं यथोक्तं पर्युपासते|

श्रद्दधाना मत्परमा भक्तास्तेऽतीव मे प्रियाः || 12.20 ||
translation: They who follow this immortal Dharma, endowed with faith and regarding Me as their supreme goal, are exceedingly dear to Me.
question: Are people with faith dear to God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इदं शरीरं कौन्तेय क्षेत्रमित्यभिधीयते| एतद्यो वेत्ति तं प्राहुः क्षेत्रज्ञ इति तद्विदः || 13.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "O Arjuna, this body is called the field; he who knows it is called the knower of the field by those who know them."
question: What is the concept of kshetra (field) and kshetrajna (knower of the field)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: क्षेत्रज्ञं चापि मां विद्धि सर्वक्षेत्रेषु भारत| क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोर्ज्ञानं यत्तज्ज्ञानं मतं मम || 13.2 ||
translation: Do thou also know Me as the knower of the field in all fields, O Arjuna. Knowledge of both the field and the knower of the field is considered by Me to be the knowledge.
question: Who is the kshetrajna (knower of all fields)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्क्षेत्रं यच्च यादृक् च यद्विकारि यतश्च यत्| स च यो यत्प्रभावश्च तत्समासेन मे श्रृणु || 13.3 ||
translation: Hear from Me in brief what the field is, of what nature it is, what its modifications are, whence it is, who He is, and what His powers are.
question: What are the properties of the kshetra (field)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ऋषिभिर्बहुधा गीतं छन्दोभिर्विविधैः पृथक्| ब्रह्मसूत्रपदैश्चैव हेतुमद्भिर्विनिश्िचतैः || 13.4 ||
translation: Sages have sung in many ways, with various distinctive chants and also with suggestive words indicative of the Absolute, full of reasoning and decisive.
question: Which is the most conclusive reference for learning Vedanta?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: महाभूतान्यहङ्कारो बुद्धिरव्यक्तमेव च| इन्द्रियाणि दशैकं च पञ्च चेन्द्रियगोचराः || 13.5 ||
translation: The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses, and one mind, and the five objects of the senses.
question: What are the various elements of Prakriti (physical nature)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इच्छा द्वेषः सुखं दुःखं सङ्घातश्चेतनाधृतिः| एतत्क्षेत्रं समासेन सविकारमुदाहृतम् || 13.6 ||
translation: Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (body), intelligence, and fortitude—the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.
question: What all constitutes the kshetra (field)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अमानित्वमदम्भित्वमहिंसा क्षान्तिरार्जवम्| आचार्योपासनं शौचं स्थैर्यमात्मविनिग्रहः || 13.7 ||
translation: Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service to the teacher, purity, steadfastness, and self-control.
question: Are humility and sincerity useful for spiritual growth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इन्द्रियार्थेषु वैराग्यमनहङ्कार एव च| जन्ममृत्युजराव्याधिदुःखदोषानुदर्शनम् || 13.8 ||
translation: Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perceiving the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness, and pain.
question: Is ego a hindrance in spiritual growth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असक्ितरनभिष्वङ्गः पुत्रदारगृहादिषु| नित्यं च समचित्तत्वमिष्टानिष्टोपपत्तिषु || 13.9 ||
translation: Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home, and the rest, and constant even-mindedness in the face of the attainment of both desirable and undesirable.
question: Is attachment to family members a hindrance to spiritual growth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मयि चानन्ययोगेन भक्ितरव्यभिचारिणी| विविक्तदेशसेवित्वमरतिर्जनसंसदि || 13.10 ||
translation: Unswerving devotion to Me through the Yoga of non-separation, resorting to solitary places, and a distaste for the company of people.
question: Does solitude help in spiritual growth?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अध्यात्मज्ञाननित्यत्वं तत्त्वज्ञानार्थदर्शनम्| एतज्ज्ञानमिति प्रोक्तमज्ञानं यदतोन्यथा || 13.11 ||
translation: Constancy in Self-knowledge, the perception of the end of true knowledge—this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.
question: What is true knowledge?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञेयं यत्तत्प्रवक्ष्यामि यज्ज्ञात्वाऽमृतमश्नुते| अनादिमत्परं ब्रह्म न सत्तन्नासदुच्यते || 13.12 ||
translation: I will declare that which is to be known, knowing which one attains immortality; the beginningless Supreme Brahman, which is neither being nor non-being.
question: How can I obtain freedom from death?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वतः पाणिपादं तत्सर्वतोऽक्षिशिरोमुखम्| सर्वतः श्रुतिमल्लोके सर्वमावृत्य तिष्ठति || 13.13 ||
translation: With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads, and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds, enveloping all.
question: How can we describe Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वेन्द्रियगुणाभासं सर्वेन्द्रियविवर्जितम्| असक्तं सर्वभृच्चैव निर्गुणं गुणभोक्तृ च || 13.14 ||
translation: Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without being attached to them; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of qualities, yet the experiencer of them.
question: What is the relation between Gunas and Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बहिरन्तश्च भूतानामचरं चरमेव च| सूक्ष्मत्वात्तदविज्ञेयं दूरस्थं चान्तिके च तत् || 13.15 ||
translation: It is within and without all beings, both the unmoving and the moving; It is subtle and unknowable, and It is near and far away.
question: Is it possible to comprehend Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अविभक्तं च भूतेषु विभक्तमिव च स्थितम्| भूतभर्तृ च तज्ज्ञेयं ग्रसिष्णु प्रभविष्णु च || 13.16 ||
translation: Undivided yet, It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of beings; It devours and It generates.
question: Is there one undivided Brahman or multiple Brahmans?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्योतिषामपि तज्ज्योतिस्तमसः परमुच्यते| ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं ज्ञानगम्यं हृदि सर्वस्य विष्ठितम् || 13.17 ||
translation: That Light of all lights is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable, and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
question: How can I attain the state of Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इति क्षेत्रं तथा ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं चोक्तं समासतः| मद्भक्त एतद्विज्ञाय मद्भावायोपपद्यते || 13.18 ||
translation: Thus, the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable, have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My being.
question: How does it help to have the knowledge of kshetra and kshetrajna? Who is fit to attain salvation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकृतिं पुरुषं चैव विद्ध्यनादी उभावपि| विकारांश्च गुणांश्चैव विद्धि प्रकृतिसंभवान् || 13.19 ||
translation: Know that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless, and know also that all modifications and qualities are born from Nature.
question: When did Prakriti and Purusha originate?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कार्यकारणकर्तृत्वे हेतुः प्रकृतिरुच्यते| पुरुषः सुखदुःखानां भोक्तृत्वे हेतुरुच्यते || 13.20 ||
translation: In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the one responsible.
question: What is the role of the Self or Purusha in human experience?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पुरुषः प्रकृतिस्थो हि भुङ्क्ते प्रकृतिजान्गुणान्| कारणं गुणसङ्गोऽस्य सदसद्योनिजन्मसु || 13.21 ||
translation: The soul seated in Nature experiences the qualities born of Nature; attachment to the qualities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.
question: Who experiences the nature around perceived through the sense organs?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उपद्रष्टाऽनुमन्ता च भर्ता भोक्ता महेश्वरः| परमात्मेति चाप्युक्तो देहेऽस्मिन्पुरुषः परः || 13.22 ||
translation: The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the observer, the permitter, the sustainer, the enjoyer, the great Lord, and the Supreme Self.
question: What is the role of the Self or seer in the human body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: य एवं वेत्ति पुरुषं प्रकृतिं च गुणैः सह| सर्वथा वर्तमानोऽपि न स भूयोऽभिजायते || 13.23 ||
translation: He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with their qualities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not reborn.
question: What is the benefit of gaining knowledge of Purusha and Prakriti?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ध्यानेनात्मनि पश्यन्ति केचिदात्मानमात्मना| अन्ये सांख्येन योगेन कर्मयोगेन चापरे || 13.24 ||
translation: Some behold the Self within themselves through meditation, others through the Yoga of knowledge, and still others through the Yoga of action.
question: What are the various ways of realising or perceiving the self within the body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अन्ये त्वेवमजानन्तः श्रुत्वाऽन्येभ्य उपासते| तेऽपि चातितरन्त्येव मृत्युं श्रुतिपरायणाः || 13.25 ||
translation: Others, too, who do not know thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the supreme refuge.
question: What happens if we have only a partial or slightly incorrect knowledge of the self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यावत्सञ्जायते किञ्चित्सत्त्वं स्थावरजङ्गमम्| क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञसंयोगात्तद्विद्धि भरतर्षभ || 13.26 ||
translation: Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union of the field and its knower.
question: Is it possible for a human or another living being to exist without the presence of the kshetrajna or self in the body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: समं सर्वेषु भूतेषु तिष्ठन्तं परमेश्वरम्| विनश्यत्स्वविनश्यन्तं यः पश्यति स पश्यति || 13.27 ||
translation: He who sees the Supreme Lord existing truly in all beings, the imperishable within the perishable, sees indeed.
question: Is it possible to see and experience things as they truly are?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: समं पश्यन्हि सर्वत्र समवस्थितमीश्वरम्| न हिनस्त्यात्मनाऽऽत्मानं ततो याति परां गतिम् || 13.28 ||
translation: For he who truly sees the same Lord dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; rather, he attains the highest goal.
question: How can we avoid injuring our own mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकृत्यैव च कर्माणि क्रियमाणानि सर्वशः| यः पश्यति तथाऽऽत्मानमकर्तारं स पश्यति || 13.29 ||
translation: He sees, who sees that all actions are performed solely by Nature and that the Self is without action.
question: Are actions done by Prakriti (nature) or by the self or soul residing in the body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा भूतपृथग्भावमेकस्थमनुपश्यति| तत एव च विस्तारं ब्रह्म सम्पद्यते तदा || 13.30 ||
translation: When a person sees all beings as resting in the One and emanating from the One alone, they then become Brahman.
question: Is it possible to perceive Brahman or consciousness in all beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनादित्वान्निर्गुणत्वात्परमात्मायमव्ययः| शरीरस्थोऽपि कौन्तेय न करोति न लिप्यते || 13.31 ||
translation: Being without beginning, devoid of any qualities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.
question: Does the Self or soul undergo changes with time?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यथा सर्वगतं सौक्ष्म्यादाकाशं नोपलिप्यते| सर्वत्रावस्थितो देहे तथाऽऽत्मा नोपलिप्यते || 13.32 ||
translation: As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, due to its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted either.
question: Can you give me an analogy to understand the immutability of consciousness or Purusha?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यथा प्रकाशयत्येकः कृत्स्नं लोकमिमं रविः| क्षेत्रं क्षेत्री तथा कृत्स्नं प्रकाशयति भारत || 13.33 ||
translation: Just as the one sun illuminates the entire world, so too does the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) illuminate the entire field, O Arjuna.
question: Can we think of consciousness like the sun which illuminates the whole world?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: क्षेत्रक्षेत्रज्ञयोरेवमन्तरं ज्ञानचक्षुषा| भूतप्रकृतिमोक्षं च ये विदुर्यान्ति ते परम् || 13.34 ||
translation: They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower, as well as the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.
question: What is the use of learning to differentiate between Purusha (consciousness) and Prakriti (physical nature)?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: परं भूयः प्रवक्ष्यामि ज्ञानानां ज्ञानमुत्तमम्| यज्ज्ञात्वा मुनयः सर्वे परां सिद्धिमितो गताः || 14.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "I will again declare to thee that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to supreme perfection after this life."
question: Does Krishna truly reveal all spiritual knowledge in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इदं ज्ञानमुपाश्रित्य मम साधर्म्यमागताः| सर्गेऽपि नोपजायन्ते प्रलये न व्यथन्ति च || 14.2 ||
translation: Those who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor disturbed at the time of dissolution.
question: What happens to those who attain unity with God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मम योनिर्महद्ब्रह्म तस्मिन् गर्भं दधाम्यहम्| संभवः सर्वभूतानां ततो भवति भारत || 14.3 ||
translation: My womb is the great Brahma; in it I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.
question: How are all living beings born in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वयोनिषु कौन्तेय मूर्तयः सम्भवन्ति याः| तासां ब्रह्म महद्योनिरहं बीजप्रदः पिता || 14.4 ||
translation: Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb, and I am the seed-giving father.
question: Who are the father and the mother of the universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सत्त्वं रजस्तम इति गुणाः प्रकृतिसंभवाः| निबध्नन्ति महाबाहो देहे देहिनमव्ययम् || 14.5 ||
translation: These qualities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body of the embodied, the indestructible: purity, passion, and inertia.
question: What are the gunas of prakriti?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्र सत्त्वं निर्मलत्वात्प्रकाशकमनामयम्| सुखसङ्गेन बध्नाति ज्ञानसङ्गेन चानघ || 14.6 ||
translation: Of these, sattva, which is luminous and healthy due to its stainlessness, binds one by attachment to happiness and knowledge, O sinless one.
question: What is sattva?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रजो रागात्मकं विद्धि तृष्णासङ्गसमुद्भवम्| तन्निबध्नाति कौन्तेय कर्मसङ्गेन देहिनम् || 14.7 ||
translation: Know, O Arjuna, that Rajas is of the nature of passion, the source of thirst and attachment; it binds fast the embodied one by attachment to action.
question: What is rajas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तमस्त्वज्ञानजं विद्धि मोहनं सर्वदेहिनाम्| प्रमादालस्यनिद्राभिस्तन्निबध्नाति भारत || 14.8 ||
translation: But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, through heedlessness, indolence, and sleep.
question: What is tamas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सत्त्वं सुखे सञ्जयति रजः कर्मणि भारत| ज्ञानमावृत्य तु तमः प्रमादे सञ्जयत्युत || 14.9 ||
translation: Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas, verily shrouding knowledge, attaches to heedlessness.
question: What are the effects of sattva, rajas and tamas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रजस्तमश्चाभिभूय सत्त्वं भवति भारत| रजः सत्त्वं तमश्चैव तमः सत्त्वं रजस्तथा || 14.10 ||
translation: Now, O Arjuna, Sattva prevails, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; then Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and then Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.
question: Which among the three gunas is the most powerful?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वद्वारेषु देहेऽस्मिन्प्रकाश उपजायते| ज्ञानं यदा तदा विद्याद्विवृद्धं सत्त्वमित्युत || 14.11 ||
translation: When the wisdom-light shines through every gate of this body, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.
question: What is sign of sattva in a person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: लोभः प्रवृत्तिरारम्भः कर्मणामशमः स्पृहा| रजस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे भरतर्षभ || 14.12 ||
translation: Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, and longing—these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.
question: What is the sign of rajas in a person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अप्रकाशोऽप्रवृत्तिश्च प्रमादो मोह एव च| तमस्येतानि जायन्ते विवृद्धे कुरुनन्दन || 14.13 ||
translation: Darkness, inertia, carelessness, and delusion—these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.
question: What is the sign of tamas in a person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदा सत्त्वे प्रवृद्धे तु प्रलयं याति देहभृत्| तदोत्तमविदां लोकानमलान्प्रतिपद्यते || 14.14 ||
translation: If the embodied one meets death when Sattva is predominant, then they attain the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.
question: What happens to a human being in whom sattva is predominant?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रजसि प्रलयं गत्वा कर्मसङ्गिषु जायते| तथा प्रलीनस्तमसि मूढयोनिषु जायते || 14.15 ||
translation: Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the thoughtless.
question: What happens to a human being in whom rajas is predominant? What happens to a human being in whom tamas is predominant?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्मणः सुकृतस्याहुः सात्त्विकं निर्मलं फलम्| रजसस्तु फलं दुःखमज्ञानं तमसः फलम् || 14.16 ||
translation: They say that the fruit of good action is Sattvic and pure; indeed, the fruit of Rajas is pain, and the fruit of Tamas is ignorance.
question: What is the result of sattvic action? What is the result of rajasic action? What is the result of tamasic action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सत्त्वात्सञ्जायते ज्ञानं रजसो लोभ एव च| प्रमादमोहौ तमसो भवतोऽज्ञानमेव च || 14.17 ||
translation: From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.
question: What does sattva lead to? What does rajas lead to? What does tamas lead to?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वं गच्छन्ति सत्त्वस्था मध्ये तिष्ठन्ति राजसाः| जघन्यगुणवृत्तिस्था अधो गच्छन्ति तामसाः || 14.18 ||
translation: Those seated in Sattva ascend; those of Rajasic nature dwell in the middle; and those of Tamasic nature, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, descend.
question: What happens to those who abide in sattva? What happens to those who abide in rajas? What happens to those who abide in tamas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नान्यं गुणेभ्यः कर्तारं यदा द्रष्टानुपश्यति| गुणेभ्यश्च परं वेत्ति मद्भावं सोऽधिगच्छति || 14.19 ||
translation: When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows that which is higher than them, he attains to My Being.
question: Who performs all the actions in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: गुणानेतानतीत्य त्रीन्देही देहसमुद्भवान्| जन्ममृत्युजरादुःखैर्विमुक्तोऽमृतमश्नुते || 14.20 ||
translation: The embodied one, having crossed beyond these three Gunas from which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay, and pain, and attains immortality.
question: What happens when the Self goes beyond the three gunas of prakriti?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: कैर्लिंगैस्त्रीन्गुणानेतानतीतो भवति प्रभो| किमाचारः कथं चैतांस्त्रीन्गुणानतिवर्तते || 14.21 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "What are the marks of one who has transcended the three qualities, O Lord? What is their conduct, and how do they go beyond these three qualities?"
question: What did Arjuna wanted to know about the three gunas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रकाशं च प्रवृत्तिं च मोहमेव च पाण्डव| न द्वेष्टि सम्प्रवृत्तानि न निवृत्तानि काङ्क्षति || 14.22 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "When light, activity, and delusion are present, he does not hate them, nor does he long for them when they are absent.
question: How does a person who has transcended the three gunas behave?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उदासीनवदासीनो गुणैर्यो न विचाल्यते| गुणा वर्तन्त इत्येव योऽवतिष्ठति नेङ्गते || 14.23 ||
translation: He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the dualities, and who, knowing that the dualities are active, is self-centered and does not move.
question: What is the attitude of a person who has transcended the three gunas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: समदुःखसुखः स्वस्थः समलोष्टाश्मकाञ्चनः| तुल्यप्रियाप्रियो धीरस्तुल्यनिन्दात्मसंस्तुतिः || 14.24 ||
translation: Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, a stone, and gold are all alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are one and the same.
question: How does a person who has transcended the three gunas treat pleasure and pain?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मानापमानयोस्तुल्यस्तुल्यो मित्रारिपक्षयोः| सर्वारम्भपरित्यागी गुणातीतः स उच्यते || 14.25 ||
translation: Who is the same in honor and dishonor, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings, he is said to have transcended the dualities.
question: How does a person who has transcended the three gunas treat honor and dishonor?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मां च योऽव्यभिचारेण भक्ितयोगेन सेवते| स गुणान्समतीत्यैतान् ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते || 14.26 ||
translation: And he who serves Me with unwavering devotion, he, crossing beyond the dualities, is fit for becoming Brahman.
question: What happens to those who serve God with unwavering devotion?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्रह्मणो हि प्रतिष्ठाऽहममृतस्याव्ययस्य च| शाश्वतस्य च धर्मस्य सुखस्यैकान्तिकस्य च || 14.27 ||
translation: For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal, immutable, and everlasting Dharma, and absolute bliss.
question: What is the relation between God and Brahman? Who is God? What is God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ऊर्ध्वमूलमधःशाखमश्वत्थं प्राहुरव्ययम्| छन्दांसि यस्य पर्णानि यस्तं वेद स वेदवित् || 15.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree, with its roots above and branches below, whose leaves are the meters or hymns; he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.
question: What does the Gita say about the inverted peepul tree? What does the Gita say about the inverted asvattha tree?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अधश्चोर्ध्वं प्रसृतास्तस्य शाखा गुणप्रवृद्धा विषयप्रवालाः| अधश्च मूलान्यनुसन्ततानि कर्मानुबन्धीनि मनुष्यलोके || 15.2 ||
translation: Its branches spread below and above, nourished by the Gunas; its buds are sense-objects, and its roots stretch forth below in the world of men, originating action.
question: What does the Krishna say about the asvattha tree?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न रूपमस्येह तथोपलभ्यते नान्तो न चादिर्न च संप्रतिष्ठा| अश्वत्थमेनं सुविरूढमूल मसङ्गशस्त्रेण दृढेन छित्त्वा || 15.3 ||
translation: Its form is not perceived here as such, nor its end, origin, foundation, or resting place; having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.
question: What is the reference about the asvattha tree in the Gita? What is the reference about the peepal tree in the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ततः पदं तत्परिमार्गितव्य यस्मिन्गता न निवर्तन्ति भूयः| तमेव चाद्यं पुरुषं प्रपद्ये यतः प्रवृत्तिः प्रसृता पुराणी || 15.4 ||
translation: Then, that goal should be sought for, to which, having gone, none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha, from whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy.
question: What is the purpose or goal of life?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: निर्मानमोहा जितसङ्गदोषा अध्यात्मनित्या विनिवृत्तकामाः| द्वन्द्वैर्विमुक्ताः सुखदुःखसंज्ञै र्गच्छन्त्यमूढाः पदमव्ययं तत् || 15.5 ||
translation: Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, they, the undeluded, reach the eternal goal.
question: Is it possible to become completely free of desires? Is it possible to become completely free of dualities of life?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न तद्भासयते सूर्यो न शशाङ्को न पावकः| यद्गत्वा न निवर्तन्ते तद्धाम परमं मम || 15.6 ||
translation: Neither does the sun illuminate there, nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone there, they do not return; that is My supreme abode.
question: What happens to those who reach the supreme abode of God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ममैवांशो जीवलोके जीवभूतः सनातनः| मनःषष्ठानीन्द्रियाणि प्रकृतिस्थानि कर्षति || 15.7 ||
translation: An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to itself the five senses, with the mind as the sixth, abiding in Nature.
question: Why do human beings feel so attracted by sensual objects?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शरीरं यदवाप्नोति यच्चाप्युत्क्रामतीश्वरः| गृहीत्वैतानि संयाति वायुर्गन्धानिवाशयात् || 15.8 ||
translation: When the Lord, as the individual soul, obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these with Him, just as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).
question: Does the soul or Self carry the mind with itself after death of the body?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रोत्रं चक्षुः स्पर्शनं च रसनं घ्राणमेव च| अधिष्ठाय मनश्चायं विषयानुपसेवते || 15.9 ||
translation: Presiding over the ears, eyes, touch, taste, smell, and mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.
question: How does the soul or self experiences the various sense objects?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उत्क्रामन्तं स्थितं वापि भुञ्जानं वा गुणान्वितम्| विमूढा नानुपश्यन्ति पश्यन्ति ज्ञानचक्षुषः || 15.10 ||
translation: The deluded do not see Him who departs, stays, and enjoys; but those who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.
question: Why can't all human beings perceive the soul or self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यतन्तो योगिनश्चैनं पश्यन्त्यात्मन्यवस्थितम्| यतन्तोऽप्यकृतात्मानो नैनं पश्यन्त्यचेतसः || 15.11 ||
translation: The yogis striving for perfection behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, do not see Him.
question: Why can't we perceive the self or soul?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदादित्यगतं तेजो जगद्भासयतेऽखिलम्| यच्चन्द्रमसि यच्चाग्नौ तत्तेजो विद्धि मामकम् || 15.12 ||
translation: That light which resides in the sun, illuminating the whole world; that which is in the moon and in the fire—know that light to be Mine.
question: Where do the sun and moon draw their illumination from?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: गामाविश्य च भूतानि धारयाम्यहमोजसा| पुष्णामि चौषधीः सर्वाः सोमो भूत्वा रसात्मकः || 15.13 ||
translation: Permeating the earth, I support all beings with My energy; and having become the watery moon, I nourish all herbs.
question: What is source of nourishment?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहं वैश्वानरो भूत्वा प्राणिनां देहमाश्रितः| प्राणापानसमायुक्तः पचाम्यन्नं चतुर्विधम् || 15.14 ||
translation: Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the bodies of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.
question: Does the soul or self also play a role in various bodily functions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वस्य चाहं हृदि सन्निविष्टो मत्तः स्मृतिर्ज्ञानमपोहनं च| वेदैश्च सर्वैरहमेव वेद्यो वेदान्तकृद्वेदविदेव चाहम् || 15.15 ||
translation: And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me come memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas.
question: What is the source of memory and knowledge in this universe?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्वाविमौ पुरुषौ लोके क्षरश्चाक्षर एव च| क्षरः सर्वाणि भूतानि कूटस्थोऽक्षर उच्यते || 15.16 ||
translation: Two Purushas there are in this world: the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are perishable, and the Kutastha—the unchanging—is called the imperishable.
question: What is the difference between kshara and akshara purusha? Are there two kinds of purushas? How many kinds of Purushas are there?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: उत्तमः पुरुषस्त्वन्यः परमात्मेत्युदाहृतः| यो लोकत्रयमाविश्य बिभर्त्यव्यय ईश्वरः || 15.17 ||
translation: But distinct is the Supreme Purusha, called the highest Self, indestructible and Lord, who pervades the three worlds and sustains them.
question: Who supports the whole universe? Who is the supreme Purusha?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्मात्क्षरमतीतोऽहमक्षरादपि चोत्तमः| अतोऽस्मि लोके वेदे च प्रथितः पुरुषोत्तमः || 15.18 ||
translation: As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.
question: Why is God called purushottama or the supreme person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यो मामेवमसम्मूढो जानाति पुरुषोत्तमम्| स सर्वविद्भजति मां सर्वभावेन भारत || 15.19 ||
translation: He who, undeluded, knows Me as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.
question: What should be our attitude towards God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इति गुह्यतमं शास्त्रमिदमुक्तं मयाऽनघ| एतद्बुद्ध्वा बुद्धिमान्स्यात्कृतकृत्यश्च भारत || 15.20 ||
translation: Thus, I have imparted to you this most secret science, O sinless one; by knowing this, one becomes wise, and all their duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.
question: What is the benefit of learning Gita? Why should we learn the Gita?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अभयं सत्त्वसंशुद्धिः ज्ञानयोगव्यवस्थितिः| दानं दमश्च यज्ञश्च स्वाध्यायस्तप आर्जवम् || 16.1 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said: Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity, and straightforwardness.
question: What are the qualities of people with a divine nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहिंसा सत्यमक्रोधस्त्यागः शान्तिरपैशुनम्| दया भूतेष्वलोलुप्त्वं मार्दवं ह्रीरचापलम् || 16.2 ||
translation: Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion for beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, and absence of fickleness.
question: What are the qualities of spiritual people?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तेजः क्षमा धृतिः शौचमद्रोहो नातिमानिता| भवन्ति सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातस्य भारत || 16.3 ||
translation: Vigor, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride—these belong to one born for a divine state, O Arjuna.
question: What are the qualities of people with a spiritual nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दम्भो दर्पोऽभिमानश्च क्रोधः पारुष्यमेव च| अज्ञानं चाभिजातस्य पार्थ सम्पदमासुरीम् || 16.4 ||
translation: Hypocrisy, arrogance, and self-conceit, anger, harshness, and ignorance—these belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha.
question: What are the qualities of a person of demonic nature? What are the qualities of a person of evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दैवी सम्पद्विमोक्षाय निबन्धायासुरी मता| मा शुचः सम्पदं दैवीमभिजातोऽसि पाण्डव || 16.5 ||
translation: The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demonic to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, for you are born with divine endowments.
question: What does divine or spiritual nature in a person lead to? What does demonic nature in a person lead to?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: द्वौ भूतसर्गौ लोकेऽस्मिन् दैव आसुर एव च| दैवो विस्तरशः प्रोक्त आसुरं पार्थ मे श्रृणु || 16.6 ||
translation: There are two types of beings in this world: the divine and the demoniacal. The divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, about the demoniacal.
question: Where in the Gita does Krishna describe people with demonic nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च जना न विदुरासुराः| न शौचं नापि चाचारो न सत्यं तेषु विद्यते || 16.7 ||
translation: The demoniacal do not know what to do and what to refrain from; they have neither purity, nor right conduct, nor truth.
question: What are the traits of people with demonic nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असत्यमप्रतिष्ठं ते जगदाहुरनीश्वरम्| अपरस्परसम्भूतं किमन्यत्कामहैतुकम् || 16.8 ||
translation: They say, "This universe is without truth, without a moral basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust as its cause; what else?"
question: What are the beliefs of people with demonic nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एतां दृष्टिमवष्टभ्य नष्टात्मानोऽल्पबुद्धयः| प्रभवन्त्युग्रकर्माणः क्षयाय जगतोऽहिताः || 16.9 ||
translation: Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds come forth as enemies of the world, intent on its destruction.
question: Why are some people so cruel and destructive? Why are some people so evil?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: काममाश्रित्य दुष्पूरं दम्भमानमदान्विताः| मोहाद्गृहीत्वासद्ग्राहान्प्रवर्तन्तेऽशुचिव्रताः || 16.10 ||
translation: Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride, and arrogance, holding evil ideas due to delusion, they work with impure intentions.
question: What is the result of insatiable desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: चिन्तामपरिमेयां च प्रलयान्तामुपाश्रिताः| कामोपभोगपरमा एतावदिति निश्िचताः || 16.11 ||
translation: Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares that end only with death, regarding the gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.
question: What motivates people with a demonic nature to act?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आशापाशशतैर्बद्धाः कामक्रोधपरायणाः| ईहन्ते कामभोगार्थमन्यायेनार्थसञ्चयान् || 16.12 ||
translation: Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain hoards of wealth by unlawful means for sensual enjoyment.
question: Why are some people so unethical and immoral?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: इदमद्य मया लब्धमिमं प्राप्स्ये मनोरथम्| इदमस्तीदमपि मे भविष्यति पुनर्धनम् || 16.13 ||
translation: "I have gained this today; I will fulfill this desire of mine; this is mine, and this wealth will be mine in the future."
question: What is the attitude of a person with demonic nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असौ मया हतः शत्रुर्हनिष्ये चापरानपि| ईश्वरोऽहमहं भोगी सिद्धोऽहं बलवान्सुखी || 16.14 ||
translation: "I have slain that enemy, and I shall slay others too. I am the Lord; I enjoy, I am perfect, powerful, and happy."
question: What is the attitude of a person with evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आढ्योऽभिजनवानस्मि कोऽन्योऽस्ति सदृशो मया| यक्ष्ये दास्यामि मोदिष्य इत्यज्ञानविमोहिताः || 16.15 ||
translation: "I am wealthy and born into a noble family. Who is my equal? I shall perform sacrifices, give charity, and rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance.
question: What is the attitude of arrogant people?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनेकचित्तविभ्रान्ता मोहजालसमावृताः| प्रसक्ताः कामभोगेषु पतन्ति नरकेऽशुचौ || 16.16 ||
translation: Bewildered by many fancies, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.
question: Eventually what happens to people with a demonic nature? Eventually what happens to people with a evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आत्मसम्भाविताः स्तब्धा धनमानमदान्विताः| यजन्ते नामयज्ञैस्ते दम्भेनाविधिपूर्वकम् || 16.17 ||
translation: Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name only for ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.
question: What is the result of sacrifices and rituals performed by people of demonic nature? What is the result of sacrifices and rituals performed by people of evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं च संश्रिताः| मामात्मपरदेहेषु प्रद्विषन्तोऽभ्यसूयकाः || 16.18 ||
translation: Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust, and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in the bodies of others.
question: How do egoistic people view God? How do evil people view God? How do demonic people view God?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तानहं द्विषतः क्रूरान्संसारेषु नराधमान्| क्षिपाम्यजस्रमशुभानासुरीष्वेव योनिषु || 16.19 ||
translation: Those cruel haters, the worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only.
question: Eventually what happens to people with a hateful nature? Eventually what happens to people with a cruel nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असुरीं योनिमापन्ना मूढा जन्मनि जन्मनि| मामप्राप्यैव कौन्तेय ततो यान्त्यधमां गतिम् || 16.20 ||
translation: Entering into demoniacal wombs and deluded, birth after birth, they do not attain Me, thus falling, O Arjuna, into a condition still lower than that.
question: Is there any possibility of salvation for people with a demonic nature? Is there any possibility of salvation for people with an evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्रिविधं नरकस्येदं द्वारं नाशनमात्मनः| कामः क्रोधस्तथा लोभस्तस्मादेतत्त्रयं त्यजेत् || 16.21 ||
translation: There are three gates to this hell, destructive of the self: lust, anger, and greed; therefore, one should abandon these three.
question: What are the gateways to hell? Is there a concept of hell and heaven in hinduism? Which people go to hell?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एतैर्विमुक्तः कौन्तेय तमोद्वारैस्त्रिभिर्नरः| आचरत्यात्मनः श्रेयस्ततो याति परां गतिम् || 16.22 ||
translation: A person who is liberated from these three gates of darkness, O Arjuna, practices what is beneficial for them and thus goes to the Supreme Goal.
question: What kind of people work for their inner development? What kind of people become spiritual? Can everyone become spiritual?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यः शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य वर्तते कामकारतः| न स सिद्धिमवाप्नोति न सुखं न परां गतिम् || 16.23 ||
translation: He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, does not attain perfection, nor happiness, nor the Supreme Goal.
question: What happens to those who do not follow the scriptures?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्माच्छास्त्रं प्रमाणं ते कार्याकार्यव्यवस्थितौ| ज्ञात्वा शास्त्रविधानोक्तं कर्म कर्तुमिहार्हसि || 16.24 ||
translation: Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act in this world.
question: Is it necessary to follow the scriptures? Are scriptures relevant for modern times?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: ये शास्त्रविधिमुत्सृज्य यजन्ते श्रद्धयाऽन्विताः| तेषां निष्ठा तु का कृष्ण सत्त्वमाहो रजस्तमः || 17.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "What is the condition of those who, disregarding the injunctions of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith—is it Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas, O Krishna?"
question: What did Arjuna want to know about people who do not follow the scriptures?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्रिविधा भवति श्रद्धा देहिनां सा स्वभावजा| सात्त्विकी राजसी चैव तामसी चेति तां श्रृणु || 17.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "There are threefold faiths inherent in the nature of the embodied: the sattvic (pure), the rajasic (passionate), and the tamasic (dark). Hear of them."
question: What are the three types of faith that people have?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सत्त्वानुरूपा सर्वस्य श्रद्धा भवति भारत| श्रद्धामयोऽयं पुरुषो यो यच्छ्रद्धः स एव सः || 17.3 ||
translation: The faith of each is in accordance with their nature, O Arjuna. People consist of their faith; as a person's faith is, so are they.
question: Does each person have faith in something? Why do different people have faith in different things? What leads to the differences in faith we see among human beings?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यजन्ते सात्त्विका देवान्यक्षरक्षांसि राजसाः| प्रेतान्भूतगणांश्चान्ये यजन्ते तामसा जनाः || 17.4 ||
translation: The sattvic, or pure, men worship the gods; the rajasic, or passionate, worship the yakshas and rakshasas; the others, the tamasic or deluded people, worship ghosts and hosts of nature-spirits.
question: What do the sattvic people worship? What do the rajasic people worship? What do the tamasic people worship?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अशास्त्रविहितं घोरं तप्यन्ते ये तपो जनाः| दम्भाहङ्कारसंयुक्ताः कामरागबलान्विताः || 17.5 ||
translation: Those men who practice terrific austerities not prescribed by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, driven by the force of lust and attachment.
question: What kind of austerities are performed by people of demonic nature? What kind of austerities are performed by people of evil nature?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कर्षयन्तः शरीरस्थं भूतग्राममचेतसः| मां चैवान्तःशरीरस्थं तान्विद्ध्यासुरनिश्चयान् || 17.6 ||
translation: Know thou these to be of demonical resolves, senselessly torturing all the elements in the body and Me who dwell in the body.
question: Is it advisable to perform extreme austerities? Is it good to perform extreme austerities? Is it beneficial to perform extreme austerities?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आहारस्त्वपि सर्वस्य त्रिविधो भवति प्रियः| यज्ञस्तपस्तथा दानं तेषां भेदमिमं श्रृणु || 17.7 ||
translation: The food that is dear to each is threefold, as well as sacrifice, austerity, and almsgiving. Hear the distinction of these.
question: How many kinds of foods are there?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: आयुःसत्त्वबलारोग्यसुखप्रीतिविवर्धनाः| रस्याः स्निग्धाः स्थिरा हृद्या आहाराः सात्त्विकप्रियाः || 17.8 ||
translation: The foods that increase life, purity, strength, health, joy, and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savory, oily, substantial, and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.
question: Which foods are considered to be sattvic? Which foods are considered to be pure? Are sweets sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कट्वम्ललवणात्युष्णतीक्ष्णरूक्षविदाहिनः| आहारा राजसस्येष्टा दुःखशोकामयप्रदाः || 17.9 ||
translation: The foods that are bitter, sour, salty, overly hot, pungent, dry, and burning are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief, and disease.
question: Which foods are considered to be rajasic? Which foods are considered to generate energy? Are sour foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यातयामं गतरसं पूति पर्युषितं च यत्| उच्छिष्टमपि चामेध्यं भोजनं तामसप्रियम् || 17.10 ||
translation: That which is stale, tasteless, putrid, rotten, rejected, and impure is the food liked by the Tamasic.
question: Which foods are considered to be tamasic? Which foods are considered to generate lethargy? Are stale foods sattvic, rajasic or tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्यज्ञो विधिदृष्टो य इज्यते| यष्टव्यमेवेति मनः समाधाय स सात्त्विकः || 17.11 ||
translation: That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward, as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that doing so is their duty, is Sattvic or pure.
question: What kind of sacrifice is considered sattvic? What kind of sacrifice is considered pure?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अभिसंधाय तु फलं दम्भार्थमपि चैव यत्| इज्यते भरतश्रेष्ठ तं यज्ञं विद्धि राजसम् || 17.12 ||
translation: The sacrifice that is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for show, know that to be a Rajasic Yajna.
question: What kind of sacrifice is considered rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विधिहीनमसृष्टान्नं मन्त्रहीनमदक्षिणम्| श्रद्धाविरहितं यज्ञं तामसं परिचक्षते || 17.13 ||
translation: They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, and which is devoid of mantras, gifts, and faith.
question: What kind of sacrifice is considered tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: देवद्विजगुरुप्राज्ञपूजनं शौचमार्जवम्| ब्रह्मचर्यमहिंसा च शारीरं तप उच्यते || 17.14 ||
translation: Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers, and the wise; purity, straightforwardness, celibacy, and non-injury are all called the austerities of the body.
question: What is considered to be austerity of the body? What is considered to be bodily austerity?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनुद्वेगकरं वाक्यं सत्यं प्रियहितं च यत्| स्वाध्यायाभ्यसनं चैव वाङ्मयं तप उच्यते || 17.15 ||
translation: Speech that causes no excitement, is truthful, pleasant, and beneficial; the practice of studying the Vedas is called austerity of speech.
question: What is considered to be austerity of speech? Is recitation of scriptures a good idea?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मनःप्रसादः सौम्यत्वं मौनमात्मविनिग्रहः| भावसंशुद्धिरित्येतत्तपो मानसमुच्यते || 17.16 ||
translation: Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, and purity of nature—this is called mental austerity.
question: What is considered to be austerity of the mind?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रद्धया परया तप्तं तपस्तत्ित्रविधं नरैः| अफलाकाङ्क्षिभिर्युक्तैः सात्त्विकं परिचक्षते || 17.17 ||
translation: This threefold austerity, practiced by steadfast men, with the utmost faith, desiring no reward, is called Sattvic.
question: What is considered to be sattvic austerity? What is considered to be austerity of sattva? What is considered to be pure austerity?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सत्कारमानपूजार्थं तपो दम्भेन चैव यत्| क्रियते तदिह प्रोक्तं राजसं चलमध्रुवम् || 17.18 ||
translation: The austerity that is practiced with the aim of gaining good reception, honor, and worship, and with hypocrisy, is said to be Rajasic, unstable, and transient.
question: What is considered to be rajasic austerity? What is considered to be austerity of rajas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मूढग्राहेणात्मनो यत्पीडया क्रियते तपः| परस्योत्सादनार्थं वा तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् || 17.19 ||
translation: That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be of the Tamasic nature.
question: What is considered to be tamasic austerity? What is considered to be austerity of tamas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दातव्यमिति यद्दानं दीयतेऽनुपकारिणे| देशे काले च पात्रे च तद्दानं सात्त्विकं स्मृतम् || 17.20 ||
translation: That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a suitable place and time to a worthy person, is held to be Sattvic.
question: What kind of gifts are considered to be sattvic? What kind of gifts are considered to be pure?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्तु प्रत्युपकारार्थं फलमुद्दिश्य वा पुनः| दीयते च परिक्लिष्टं तद्दानं राजसं स्मृतम् || 17.21 ||
translation: And, that gift which is given with the intention of receiving something in return, or expecting a reward, or begrudgingly, is considered to be Rajasic.
question: What kind of gifts are considered to be rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अदेशकाले यद्दानमपात्रेभ्यश्च दीयते| असत्कृतमवज्ञातं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् || 17.22 ||
translation: The gift that is given in the wrong place and at the wrong time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult, is declared to be of a Tamasic nature.
question: What kind of gifts are considered to be tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्सदिति निर्देशो ब्रह्मणस्त्रिविधः स्मृतः| ब्राह्मणास्तेन वेदाश्च यज्ञाश्च विहिताः पुरा || 17.23 ||
translation: "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that, the Brahmanas, the Vedas, and the sacrifices were created formerly.
question: what is the meaning and significance of om tat sat? What is the threefold designation of Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तस्मादोमित्युदाहृत्य यज्ञदानतपःक्रियाः| प्रवर्तन्ते विधानोक्ताः सततं ब्रह्मवादिनाम् || 17.24 ||
translation: Therefore, with the utterance of "Om," the acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity, as enjoined in the scriptures, are always begun by the students of Brahman.
question: What is the significance of Om? What is the meaning of Om? What is the significance of Aum? What is the meaning of AUM?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तदित्यनभिसन्धाय फलं यज्ञतपःक्रियाः| दानक्रियाश्च विविधाः क्रियन्ते मोक्षकाङ्क्षिभि: || 17.25 ||
translation: Uttering "Tat," without aiming for the fruits, are the acts of sacrifice, austerity, and the various acts of gifts performed by those seeking liberation.
question: How should we perform sacrifices? What is the best way of performing sacrifices? How should we perform rituals? What is the best way of performing rituals? What does the word tat mean?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सद्भावे साधुभावे च सदित्येतत्प्रयुज्यते| प्रशस्ते कर्मणि तथा सच्छब्दः पार्थ युज्यते || 17.26 ||
translation: The word "Sat" is used to refer to reality and goodness; likewise, O Arjuna, the word "Sat" is used to refer to an auspicious act.
question: What is the meaning of Sat?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञे तपसि दाने च स्थितिः सदिति चोच्यते| कर्म चैव तदर्थीयं सदित्येवाभिधीयते || 17.27 ||
translation: Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity, and gift is also called 'Sat', and action in connection with these, or for the sake of the Supreme, is also called 'Sat'.
question: What is the significance of sat?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अश्रद्धया हुतं दत्तं तपस्तप्तं कृतं च यत्| असदित्युच्यते पार्थ न च तत्प्रेत्य नो इह || 17.28 ||
translation: Whatever is sacrificed, given, or performed, and whatever austerity is practiced without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is of no value here or hereafter (after death).
question: what is asat or untruth?

speaker: अर्जुन
sanskrit: संन्यासस्य महाबाहो तत्त्वमिच्छामि वेदितुम्| त्यागस्य च हृषीकेश पृथक्केशिनिषूदन || 18.1 ||
translation: Arjuna said, "O mighty-armed Hrishikesa, I desire to know the essence or truth of renunciation and abandonment severally, O slayer of Kesi."
question: Was Arjuna curious about renunciation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: काम्यानां कर्मणां न्यासं संन्यासं कवयो विदुः| सर्वकर्मफलत्यागं प्राहुस्त्यागं विचक्षणाः || 18.2 ||
translation: The Blessed Lord said, "The sages understand sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions to be tyaga."
question: What is sannyasa? What is renunciation?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: त्याज्यं दोषवदित्येके कर्म प्राहुर्मनीषिणः| यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यमिति चापरे || 18.3 ||
translation: Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as evil; while others declare that acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be relinquished.
question: Should all actions be abandoned as evil?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: निश्चयं श्रृणु मे तत्र त्यागे भरतसत्तम| त्यागो हि पुरुषव्याघ्र त्रिविधः संप्रकीर्तितः || 18.4 ||
translation: Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, indeed, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.
question: How many types of tyaga are there?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यज्ञदानतपःकर्म न त्याज्यं कार्यमेव तत्| यज्ञो दानं तपश्चैव पावनानि मनीषिणाम् || 18.5 ||
translation: Acts of sacrifice, gift, and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; for sacrifice, gift, and austerity are the purifiers of the wise.
question: Should we abandon all sacrifices and austerities? What are the means of purification for the wise?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: एतान्यपि तु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलानि च| कर्तव्यानीति मे पार्थ निश्िचतं मतमुत्तमम् || 18.6 ||
translation: But even these actions should be performed, leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is my certain and most assured conviction.
question: Is there any need of performing the rituals and sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नियतस्य तु संन्यासः कर्मणो नोपपद्यते| मोहात्तस्य परित्यागस्तामसः परिकीर्तितः || 18.7 ||
translation: Verily, the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same out of delusion is declared to be Tamasic.
question: Is it good to renounce rituals and sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: दुःखमित्येव यत्कर्म कायक्लेशभयात्त्यजेत्| स कृत्वा राजसं त्यागं नैव त्यागफलं लभेत् || 18.8 ||
translation: He who abandons action out of fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by performing such Rajasic renunciation.
question: What happens to those who abandon the rituals and sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कार्यमित्येव यत्कर्म नियतं क्रियतेऽर्जुन| सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा फलं चैव स त्यागः सात्त्विको मतः || 18.9 ||
translation: Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as sattvic (pure).
question: What is a sattvic way of performing rituals and sacrifices?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न द्वेष्ट्यकुशलं कर्म कुशले नानुषज्जते| त्यागी सत्त्वसमाविष्टो मेधावी छिन्नसंशयः || 18.10 ||
translation: The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate an unpleasant task nor is he attached to a pleasant one.
question: What are the characteristics of a sattvic person? What are the characteristics of a pure person?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न हि देहभृता शक्यं त्यक्तुं कर्माण्यशेषतः| यस्तु कर्मफलत्यागी स त्यागीत्यभिधीयते || 18.11 ||
translation: Indeed, it is not possible for an embodied being to completely abandon actions; however, he who relinquishes the rewards of actions is truly called a man of renunciation.
question: Is it possible to completely abandon actions? Is it possible to completely give up actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनिष्टमिष्टं मिश्रं च त्रिविधं कर्मणः फलम्| भवत्यत्यागिनां प्रेत्य न तु संन्यासिनां क्वचित् || 18.12 ||
translation: The threefold fruit of action (evil, good, and mixed) accrues after death to those who do not abandon it, but never to those who do.
question: What are the kinds of fruits of actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पञ्चैतानि महाबाहो कारणानि निबोध मे| सांख्ये कृतान्ते प्रोक्तानि सिद्धये सर्वकर्मणाम् || 18.13 ||
translation: Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes, as declared in the Sankhya system, for the accomplishment of all actions.
question: What are the causes that lead to accomplishment of all actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अधिष्ठानं तथा कर्ता करणं च पृथग्विधम्| विविधाश्च पृथक्चेष्टा दैवं चैवात्र पञ्चमम् || 18.14 ||
translation: The body, the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various kinds, and the presiding deity—the fifth.
question: What are the causes that determine the fruits of our actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शरीरवाङ्मनोभिर्यत्कर्म प्रारभते नरः| न्याय्यं वा विपरीतं वा पञ्चैते तस्य हेतवः || 18.15 ||
translation: Whatever action a person performs with their body, speech, and mind, whether right or wrong, these five are its causes.
question: Do all actions have similar causes at a fundamental level?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: तत्रैवं सति कर्तारमात्मानं केवलं तु यः| पश्यत्यकृतबुद्धित्वान्न स पश्यति दुर्मतिः || 18.16 ||
translation: Now, such being the case, verily he who, owing to an untrained understanding, looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence does not see.
question: Can everyone perceive the self?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यस्य नाहंकृतो भावो बुद्धिर्यस्य न लिप्यते| हत्वापि स इमाँल्लोकान्न हन्ति न निबध्यते || 18.17 ||
translation: He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted by good or evil, though he slays these people, he does not slay, nor is he bound by the action.
question: What kind of attitude should we have while performing action? Who is the doer of all actions?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानं ज्ञेयं परिज्ञाता त्रिविधा कर्मचोदना| करणं कर्म कर्तेति त्रिविधः कर्मसंग्रहः || 18.18 ||
translation: Knowledge, the knowable, and the knower form the threefold impulse for action; the organ, the action, and the agent form the threefold basis of action.
question: What incites a person to act? What incites a person to perform action?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ज्ञानं कर्म च कर्ता च त्रिधैव गुणभेदतः| प्रोच्यते गुणसंख्याने यथावच्छृणु तान्यपि || 18.19 ||
translation: Knowledge, action, and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these, hear duly.
question: How many kinds of knowledge are there? How many kinds of actions are there?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सर्वभूतेषु येनैकं भावमव्ययमीक्षते| अविभक्तं विभक्तेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि सात्त्विकम् || 18.20 ||
translation: That by which one sees the indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in any of them—know that knowledge to be Sattvic.
question: Which knowledge is considered to be sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: पृथक्त्वेन तु यज्ज्ञानं नानाभावान्पृथग्विधान्| वेत्ति सर्वेषु भूतेषु तज्ज्ञानं विद्धि राजसम् || 18.21 ||
translation: But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as being distinct from one another, know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.
question: What kind of knowledge is considered to be rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्तु कृत्स्नवदेकस्मिन्कार्ये सक्तमहैतुकम्| अतत्त्वार्थवदल्पं च तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् || 18.22 ||
translation: But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without any foundation in Truth, and is trivial—that is declared to be Tamasic.
question: What kind of knowledge is considered to be tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: नियतं सङ्गरहितमरागद्वेषतः कृतम्| अफलप्रेप्सुना कर्म यत्तत्सात्त्विकमुच्यते || 18.23 ||
translation: An action that is ordained, free from attachment, done without love or hatred, and without desire for reward is declared to be Sattvic.
question: Which action is considered to be sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्तु कामेप्सुना कर्म साहङ्कारेण वा पुनः| क्रियते बहुलायासं तद्राजसमुदाहृतम् || 18.24 ||
translation: But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfillment of desires or gain with egotism or with much effort is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).
question: What kind of action is considered to be rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अनुबन्धं क्षयं हिंसामनपेक्ष्य च पौरुषम्| मोहादारभ्यते कर्म यत्तत्तामसमुच्यते || 18.25 ||
translation: That action which is undertaken from delusion, without regard for the consequences, loss, injury, and one's own ability, is declared to be Tamasic (dark).
question: What kind of action is considered to be tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: मुक्तसङ्गोऽनहंवादी धृत्युत्साहसमन्वितः| सिद्ध्यसिद्ध्योर्निर्विकारः कर्ता सात्त्विक उच्यते || 18.26 ||
translation: An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is considered to be of a Sattvic (pure) nature.
question: What kind of person is considered sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: रागी कर्मफलप्रेप्सुर्लुब्धो हिंसात्मकोऽशुचिः| हर्षशोकान्वितः कर्ता राजसः परिकीर्तितः || 18.27 ||
translation: Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of their actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic.
question: What kind of person is considered rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अयुक्तः प्राकृतः स्तब्धः शठो नैष्कृतिकोऽलसः| विषादी दीर्घसूत्री च कर्ता तामस उच्यते || 18.28 ||
translation: Unsteady, vulgar, inflexible, deceitful, malicious, lazy, despondent, and procrastinating—such an agent is called Tamasic.
question: What kind of person is considered tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बुद्धेर्भेदं धृतेश्चैव गुणतस्त्रिविधं श्रृणु| प्रोच्यमानमशेषेण पृथक्त्वेन धनञ्जय || 18.29 ||
translation: Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness, according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.
question: What are the different kinds of buddhi?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: प्रवृत्तिं च निवृत्तिं च कार्याकार्ये भयाभये| बन्धं मोक्षं च या वेत्ति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी || 18.30 ||
translation: The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what should be done and what should not be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation—that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.
question: What kind of buddhi is considered sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यया धर्ममधर्मं च कार्यं चाकार्यमेव च| अयथावत्प्रजानाति बुद्धिः सा पार्थ राजसी || 18.31 ||
translation: That by which one wrongly understands dharma and adharma, and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done—that intellect, O Arjuna, is rajasic (passionate).
question: What kind of buddhi is considered rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अधर्मं धर्ममिति या मन्यते तमसाऽऽवृता| सर्वार्थान्विपरीतांश्च बुद्धिः सा पार्थ तामसी || 18.32 ||
translation: That intellect, O Arjuna, which is enveloped in darkness and sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted, is Tamasic (dark).
question: What kind of buddhi is considered tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: धृत्या यया धारयते मनःप्राणेन्द्रियक्रियाः| योगेनाव्यभिचारिण्या धृतिः सा पार्थ सात्त्विकी || 18.33 ||
translation: The unwavering firmness, through which Yoga restrains the functions of the mind, life-force, and senses—that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
question: What kind of firmness is considered sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यया तु धर्मकामार्थान् धृत्या धारयतेऽर्जुन| प्रसङ्गेन फलाकाङ्क्षी धृतिः सा पार्थ राजसी || 18.34 ||
translation: But that, O Arjuna, by which one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures, and earning of wealth, on account of attachment and desire for reward—that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
question: What kind of firmness is considered rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यया स्वप्नं भयं शोकं विषादं मदमेव च| न विमुञ्चति दुर्मेधा धृतिः सा पार्थ तामसी || 18.35 ||
translation: That firmness, O Arjuna, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair, and conceit, is Tamasic.
question: What kind of firmness is considered tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सुखं त्विदानीं त्रिविधं श्रृणु मे भरतर्षभ| अभ्यासाद्रमते यत्र दुःखान्तं च निगच्छति || 18.36 ||
translation: And now, O Arjuna, hear from Me of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices through practice and surely comes to the end of pain.
question: How many kinds of pleasures are there?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यत्तदग्रे विषमिव परिणामेऽमृतोपमम्| तत्सुखं सात्त्विकं प्रोक्तमात्मबुद्धिप्रसादजम् || 18.37 ||
translation: That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar—that happiness is declared to be sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to self-realization.
question: What kind of pleasure is considered sattvic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विषयेन्द्रियसंयोगाद्यत्तदग्रेऽमृतोपमम्| परिणामे विषमिव तत्सुखं राजसं स्मृतम् || 18.38 ||
translation: That happiness which arises from the contact of the senses with the objects, which is initially like nectar but eventually like poison, is said to be Rajasic.
question: What kind of pleasure is considered rajasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यदग्रे चानुबन्धे च सुखं मोहनमात्मनः| निद्रालस्यप्रमादोत्थं तत्तामसमुदाहृतम् || 18.39 ||
translation: That happiness which at first, as well as in the end, deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence, and heedlessness—that is declared to be Tamasic.
question: What kind of pleasure is considered tamasic?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: न तदस्ति पृथिव्यां वा दिवि देवेषु वा पुनः| सत्त्वं प्रकृतिजैर्मुक्तं यदेभिः स्यात्ित्रभिर्गुणैः || 18.40 ||
translation: There is no being on earth or in heaven among the gods that is liberated from the three qualities born of Nature.
question: Is there anyone in this universe free from the three gunas?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्राह्मणक्षत्रियविशां शूद्राणां च परंतप| कर्माणि प्रविभक्तानि स्वभावप्रभवैर्गुणैः || 18.41 ||
translation: Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas, Vaisyas, and Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the qualities born of their own nature.
question: What is the varna system in Hinduism? What is the caste system in Hinduism? Is caste decided by birth or by personal preference? Is varna decided by birth or by personal preference?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शमो दमस्तपः शौचं क्षान्तिरार्जवमेव च| ज्ञानं विज्ञानमास्तिक्यं ब्रह्मकर्म स्वभावजम् || 18.42 ||
translation: Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness, and uprightness, as well as knowledge, realization, and belief in God, are the duties of Brahmanas, born of their own nature.
question: Who is a Brahmin? What are the qualities of a Brahmin?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: शौर्यं तेजो धृतिर्दाक्ष्यं युद्धे चाप्यपलायनम्| दानमीश्वरभावश्च क्षात्रं कर्म स्वभावजम् || 18.43 ||
translation: Prowess, splendor, firmness, dexterity, and not fleeing from battle, generosity, and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of their own nature.
question: Who is a Kshatriya? What are the qualities of a Kshatriya?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: कृषिगौरक्ष्यवाणिज्यं वैश्यकर्म स्वभावजम्| परिचर्यात्मकं कर्म शूद्रस्यापि स्वभावजम् || 18.44 ||
translation: Agriculture, cattle-rearing, and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of their own nature; and service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of their own nature.
question: Who is a shudra? What are the qualities of a shudra?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: स्वे स्वे कर्मण्यभिरतः संसिद्धिं लभते नरः| स्वकर्मनिरतः सिद्धिं यथा विन्दति तच्छृणु || 18.45 ||
translation: Each person devoted to their own duty attains perfection. How they attain perfection while being engaged in their own duty, hear now.
question: What happens to those who are devoted to their duty?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: यतः प्रवृत्तिर्भूतानां येन सर्वमिदं ततम्| स्वकर्मणा तमभ्यर्च्य सिद्धिं विन्दति मानवः || 18.46 ||
translation: He from whom all the beings have evolved and by whom all this is pervaded, worshipping Him with his own duty, one attains perfection.
question: How can we reach perfection? How can we acquire power?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात्| स्वभावनियतं कर्म कुर्वन्नाप्नोति किल्बिषम् || 18.47 ||
translation: Better is one's own duty, even if it is destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.
question: Is it alright to do things out of force? Should we do what we are truly good at or what others want us to do?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सहजं कर्म कौन्तेय सदोषमपि न त्यजेत्| सर्वारम्भा हि दोषेण धूमेनाग्निरिवावृताः || 18.48 ||
translation: One should not, O Arjuna, abandon the duty to which one is born, though it may be faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, just as fire is by smoke.
question: Should we give up our work if we are unable to do it perfectly? Should we give up our work if we are unable to do it well?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: असक्तबुद्धिः सर्वत्र जितात्मा विगतस्पृहः| नैष्कर्म्यसिद्धिं परमां संन्यासेनाधिगच्छति || 18.49 ||
translation: He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled, he attains the supreme state of freedom from action through renunciation.
question: What happens to those who are unattached? What happens to those who are detached? What happens to those who are free from all desires?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: सिद्धिं प्राप्तो यथा ब्रह्म तथाप्नोति निबोध मे| समासेनैव कौन्तेय निष्ठा ज्ञानस्य या परा || 18.50 ||
translation: Learn from Me, O Arjuna, in brief how one who has attained perfection reaches Brahman—the Eternal, that supreme state of knowledge.
question: Where does Krishna talk about the process of attaining Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: बुद्ध्या विशुद्धया युक्तो धृत्याऽऽत्मानं नियम्य च| शब्दादीन् विषयांस्त्यक्त्वा रागद्वेषौ व्युदस्य च || 18.51 ||
translation: Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self through firmness, relinquishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.
question: How can we attain Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: विविक्तसेवी लघ्वाशी यतवाक्कायमानसः| ध्यानयोगपरो नित्यं वैराग्यं समुपाश्रितः || 18.52 ||
translation: Dwelling in solitude, eating sparingly, with speech, body, and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, and resorting to dispassion.
question: Does solitude help in attaining Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: अहङ्कारं बलं दर्पं कामं क्रोधं परिग्रहम्| विमुच्य निर्ममः शान्तो ब्रह्मभूयाय कल्पते || 18.53 ||
translation: Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger, and covetousness, and being free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful, he is fit for becoming Brahman.
question: Is ego a hindrance in attaining Brahman?

speaker: भगवान
sanskrit: ब्रह्मभूतः प्रसन्नात्मा न शोचति न काङ्क्षति| समः सर्वेषु भूतेषु मद्भक्तिं लभते पराम् || 18.54 ||
translation: Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires; he is the same to all beings, and obtains supreme devotion to Me.
question: What happens to those who attain the state of Brahman?
